You get a pretty decent head, 2 cm approx, on the initial pour but dissipates. The smooth mouthfeel reminds me of Christmas with the different combination of fruit and spice.  Very tasty indeed
Deep malty flavor and burned caramel is what i get on the taste. Nice aroma too..... Very good beer....

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2012 Geur lijkt op te lang liggende mandarijntjes; smaak in de eerste tellen bevestig dit, maar blijft lang hangen en verfijnt na verloop van tijd.  Mooie schuimkraag, licht gekleurd, nodigt uit om te drinken. #2 Ook kruidig, pepernoten bijna, licht waterig in smaak. Aroma plus 3, smaak blijft wat achter, zelfde rating voor de rest.
Bottle, 2 years old. Mahogany with a tan head. Malt, yeast, caramelized sugar, plum, brown sugar. Somewhat sweet, medium carbonation and body, caramel, nice long finish with a nice complexity.
0,3 liter fles.Ik had van deze dubbel veel meer verwacht . Maw het valt me zwaar tegen.

Dark red, brown head.
Strong aroma, dark fruit, faint alcohol.
Very fruity, dry, slightly sour, roasted malt, hoppy aftertaste.
Medium thick, decent carbonation.
Little one dimensional.

Ruby red beer with a small tan head. The aroma is malty sweet and fruity with notes of plum, caramel, apricot, brown sugar and yeast. The taste is sweet, spicy, fruity and complex, with almost no bitterness. Soft and creamy mouth feel, long fruity and slightly bitter finish with roasty notes a la tobacco.Still, to much malty sweetness for my palate.

Cola brown colour, firm beige head. Aroma malty, roasted malts, dark sugar,  overripe dark fruits, banana yeast. Malty sweet flavour, roasted malts, slight bitterness, some candy sugar, burned caramel. Finish somewhat sweet.
(Draught @ the monastery)
Pour is a nice cola brown color with a rather large tan head. Nose is of dark fruits, rather sweet. Taste is very much the staple of a dubbel, as one would expect from a trappist brewery.

Pours murky brown with small yellow fizz. Smells of dark fruits, yeasty, earthy, and malty. Tastes sweet malted, a bit like dark fruits, very little bitterness. Full-bodied with a smooth, slick texture and average mouth-carbonation, Koningshoeven Dubbel finishes surprisingly fruity, but it doesnt linger for long.

On tap. Reddish with off-white that quickly diminishes and maintain a thin layer. Aroma is to toasted malt, caramel, brown sugar. Flavour is sweet and long. On palate results dense and creamy, with flat carbonation and medium to full body.

Bottle 33 cl, Cracked Kettle. Pours deep red brown with a great creamy tanned head leaving nice lacing. Aroma is malty, sweet, caramel, hoppy and fruity. Flavor is malty, fruity, apples, sweet, bitter hoppy and a bit phenolic. Finishes bitter malty.
Pours cloudy dark ruby brown with small creamy head. Aroma is fusel alcohol, banana, and baking bread. Flavor of dark fruits, graham cracker, and nuts. Aggressively carbonated.

33cl bottle. poured in my favorite glass "Vapeur Cochonne". Hazy dark amber with a small tan head that goes off quickly leaving a fine layer on top.
Nose : Alcohol, smoky oak, irish cofee, cherry and pear. Banana. 
Sip : Foamy but not a mouthful. Sweet like caramel with a feeling of a nice dry liquor. On the end I feel chocolate/coffee like aftertaste. Surprisingly balanced and when served well chilled I might enjoy several glasses of this brew.
Outstanding beer. On tap at Monks Table. Big thick head with great malt backing, and a fruity middle. Almost peach-like. Loved this.

Fles 30 cl. 
Kleur: Rood/bruin. 
Brede onstabiele witte schuimkraag die snel verdwijnt 
Geur: Zoet, fruitig
Smaak: Licht zoet met een licht bitter nasmaak, die wel eventjes blijft hangen. Ik vind de nasmaak onprettig maar weet niet goed hoe te omschrijven.
Weinig koolzuur.

Pours a dark amber with a tan head that fades quickly. The aroma is very fruity with a bit of sweet malt as well. The flavor is also fruity, but well balanced. A hint of pepper and a nice bitterness. The finish is crisp, nice after taste. Light and tasty.

750 ml. Pours dark brown, maybe a slight tinge of orange. I like the aroma a lot. Soft carbonation. The taste has some plums and figs and caramel,  but it all seems a bit muted for a Trappist doobel. It kind of coats the tongue as well.

33 cl bottle, Rotterdam, Netherlands. Slightly hazy deep amber-brown. Bright aroma, minty hops and a caramel base. Sweet, then an immediate pepper bite that transitions to a long almost cloying finish.
Bottle from Provenance. Delicious caramel and conspicuous alcohol. Belgian spice flavour. High grade stuff.

33cl Bottle. Pours white head which diminished within a matter of seconds, virtually no lacing. Colour is of a deep red. Aroma of caramel dark fruits and alcohol. Starts sweet with honey and alcohol on the finish slightly metallic. Unfortunately a bit disappointing.

Bottle from Csakajosor.hu. Poured deep ruby, with a massive beige foam. Red grapes, yeast, raspberry, woodcask in the nose. Plum, dark chocolate, bubblegum, caramel, in the aroma. Sweet taste in a dense, oily body. Dark fruity, sweet aftertaste with hints of basil. Somewhat bitter, dry finish. I LIKE!

Bottle @ Home. Pours dark brown with a creamy offwhite head. Aroma of malt, caramel, sweet ripe fruit. Taste is malt, caramel, spices , sweet fruit. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, soft carbonation. 080911

Bouteille de 33cl. Couleur rougeâtre foncée, belle mousse crêmeuse mais moins de tenue que la quadrupel. Subtil équilibre entre arômes fruités, épicés et caramélisés. Superbe texture, comme toutes les autres Trappes. La soeur "soft" de la quadrupel. Trouvée à Vanuxeem - Ploegstaert.

Its caramel aroma is so strong you could almost call it caramelbeer. But its good at that. Pours a dark brown color with a rather white foam. Its aroma contains apart from the caramel a rather nice chocolate. Very sweet in taste and overall highly enjoying.
Meravigliosa dubbel, sinceramente non mi aspettavo tanto da questa birra, e invece molto notevole. Cioccolato al naso evidente, e in bocca ancora cioccolato e fruttato, enjoy...

Dark toffee/mahogany color. Thick creamy tan-ish colored head. Some lacing left behind. Smells of malt thinned out by alcohol. Big alcohol presence in the mouth, both in taste and warmth. Not the best dubbel Ive had. And this was fresh from the tap at the source.
(Bottle 01/08-2011) Low light brown head, dark amber color, caramel taste, medium sweet, medium body.

Pours a cloudy dark brown with a nice frothy light brown head. Aroma of dark fruits, yeast and caramel with hints of spices. Taste is quite fruity, with caramel, roasted malt leading to a warming alcohol flavour and a light bitter finish.. Lovely dubbel.
30 cL bottle: Appearance is a deep dark brown iwht a creamy off white head. Aroma is of spices, yeast and malt. Flavor is a mixture between some roasted malt, yeast and Belgian like spices.

Das Bier ergießt sich rötlich braun in den Kelch. Der Schaum ist etwas bräunlich. Gut. 
Malzig-fruchtige Düfte. Hefig und leicht alkoholisch wirkend. 
Im Geschmack ist eine gewisse Holzigkeit auszumachen. Vorwiegend aber malzig und schokoladig mit einigen Fruchtanteilen. Trockener Abgang. 
Gut gemachtes Trappistenbier.Test vom 26.8.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche
[Bottle] Dark mahogany hue, good head formation. Malty burnt toast aroma. Bready malt flavor, a touch of treacle, plenty of brown sugar, moderate spicy dry finish.
Cloudy brown colored beer, decent slightly off-white head. Smell malts, caramel and fruits. Taste a little sweet and a little bitter. Good balance between those. Medium body and carbo.

Bottle 330ml @ yngwie
Pours cloudy dark amber with a off-white head, Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, dried fruits and yeast. Taste is medium sweet and light to medium bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

33cl Bottle from Bierzwerg.  Appearance is hazy copper, brown color with minimal, tan head.  Aroma is sweet malts, some caramel, and yeast.  Taste is rather sweet on the front end with notoes of dried fruit, nuts, and sweet malts with mild yeast hints as well.  Palate is medium-bodied, slick texture, soft, bubbley carbonation, and a leathery, semi-dry finish.

Red brown, a bit transparent, nice soapy head... aroma is very malty with hints of whisky and some spices, some yeast, not to intense though, later on some apple appears... taste is malty sweet and bitter at first, but later on the sweetness takes over, finish is bitter and earthy with hints of malt... nice oily texture and soft sparkles but its body isnt as fat as id like it to be... nice fairly complex double that lacks punch

Hazy burnt orange, with an aroma of orange citrus and orange rind, with a huge earthy malt backbone and a touch of tobacco. Also a bit of Belgo yeast spice AND funk. Wonderfully earthy malt backbone on the flavor, with not as much orange as on the nose. Delightfully fruity yeasty tones, slight spice and citrus. Near perfect Dubbel.

On tap in Ciampino, Italy at Seigradi. Pours a cloudy dark amber light brown with a nice off white head. Aroma of fruits, caramel, sweetness, and malt. Taste of fruits, sugar, and yeast. Palate is bland cardboard. I could have done without this one.

This is really a remarkable beer from the Netherlands, most of the time this kinda quality beer can only be found in Belgium.
Great balance of sweet heaviness.

They really came close to match some of my favorite beers like Grimbergen/Affligem.

Its not as good though, but almost perfect!
Bottle 33 cl. A light brown colour with a short lasting tanned head. An aroma of malt, caramel, fruit and yeast. The taste is sweet with a bitter finish. A medium body and avarage carbonation.
brown, clear, minimal head, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, thick feel, soft carbonation, no real finish to speak of,

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2012 0.5 L Stone Bottle: faith it may be opened with pliers This is a beautiful brown colord beer. Aroma of fruits. Flavors of caramel and rasins. Dark candy sugar taste.. tasted again: 010811
Pours dark brown with tan head. Aroma of maple, dark cherry and molasses.  Taste is maple soaked malt with subtle estery spiciness. It ends with honey and subtle bitterness.

This is one tasty beer with a sweetish, caramel-like aroma. Simple yet inviting! The palate is simply delicious with good follow through from the nose and finishes off dry and refreshing with slight spiciness and warm.
Dark red to brown colour (depends on the lightsource). Sweet, caramel taste and smell. Nice and full body.
Servida al The Drunk Monk (Mataró). Dark red colour. Chocolat aroma, with long lasting fruity finish. Nice one..

Kräftig malzig-süßer Antrunk, minimal fruchtig, etwas hefig. Im Mittelteil leicht herb, das Bier ist sehr süffig trotz der stärker werdenden Würzigkeit. Im Abgang cremig malzig, etwas herb, langsam ausklingend. Gelungen! 	 
Test vom 12.5.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 11,10,11,11,12,11 - 10,90
Bottle. Fruity aroma. Nice reddish copper colour with medium head. Sweet fruity and spicy flavor. Well ballanced beer.
Out of a bottle.  Brown, good head.  Malty with the chalky taste of Belgian spices - even though theres none listed in the ingredients.  Its a good summer intro beer to those new to Belgians.

I tried this one on tap yesterday. Im familiar with the Quadrupel but I never tried the Dubbel (shame on me). So when I got it I was stunned by the deep dark red, brownish colour with a small beige head. Aroma has malts and alcohol. Perhaps bit of dark sweets like chocolate. Taste has syrup, raisins and plums with a bit of the alcohol coming back in the taste. La Trappe is definitely one of my favourite brewerys and remains being so after this beer.

On tap at Café Belgique, Amsterdam on 8 April 2011. Thought I would try this as I hadnt reviewed it on draught before. Turns out I hadnt reviewed it at all. Reddish colour. Diminishing cream head. Fruity but not too sweet. Some plummy / cherry notes. Subtle sour edge in the aftertaste. Quite tasty and satisfying.

Bottle at Ölstopet 2011. Dark brown, hazy liquid with medium off-white head. Smells of Belgian yeast, banana, caramel and fruits overall. Very Belgian. Tastes is quite sweet with medium bitterness. Medium bodied with light carbonation. Nice overall but not stunning.
At monastery De Koningshoeven. Netherlands. Poured brown in color with brown head. Sweet malty and grainy in aroma. Malty, sweet and quite boozy in flavour.
Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours a red-brown with a medium beige head. Lots of dark fruits and wood on the nose. Taste is raisins, fig, wood, alcohol and chocolate. Good beer
Frugtig brunøl ige et niveau over Leffes,  som jeg ellers holder af. Mums!

spina - Doolin Pub - Latina
Ambrata molto carica, carbonazione leggera, profumata allinizio con schiuma non molto presente.
deludente al palato, forse servita male.

Bottle.
Dark reddish brown pour, beige head.  Brown sugar, plum, and sweet malt aromas - flavor is lots of dark fruit.  Slightly dry - not my favorite from this brewery.

Flaske: Flot mørk ravfarvet klar øl med et kæmpe skumhoved. Duft af La Trappe husgær, sødlig frugtet. Smagen er lige ved at være for sød, men den smukke farve opvejer lidt for det. Udmærket øl, men for sød.

Bottle from Nelson Wine. It pours cloudy mahogany, with a thin fizzy beige head and moderate carbonation. The nose is wood, fig, date, currants, plum and pear-drop boiled sweets. The taste is caramel, cola, toffee, wood, grass, date, currant, chocolate, varnish and charcoal. It has a creamy mouth-feel, long woody finish. A high quality and very drinkable dubbel.

16 April 2011, bottle. mahogany colour, slightly hazy with big foamy tan head. nose is warm raisins, alcohol, and bread dough yeast. full body and mildly fizzy. I think this is a great dubbel. alcohol is prominent but not aggressive. an interesting purple grape flavour comes out, along side a hot cross bun taste. really good.

A gift, this 30cl bottles probably about 20 years old, it doesnt even say Dubbel on it, just La Trappe on a gold label with lots of Dutch writing about "pouring without shaking". Despite its age it poured an only slightly cloudy red-brown with even a tiny little bit of a fine white head. Hints of maple syrup and maybe a little coffee on the nose, a soft, warming and chewy body, a little oxidised but still with notes of sultanas, a little red wine and spice, and a dryish finish.

330ml bottle.  Pours a dark caramel with a medium head.  Aroma is yeast, clove and raisin.  Taste starts with clove, raisin and alcohol in the finish.  Full in the mouth to start but short in the finish.

From the corked 500 ml. bottle stamped 10:15-K11010.  The pour is a fascinating reddish-purple-brown with a fluffy tan head.  It is more red when held to the light. The aromas bring forward yeast, dark fruits like plum or grape, and roasted, smoky malts. A comfortable, medium body feel that holds its texture with little to no breakdown into carbonated bubbles while swishing in the mouth. The flavor is interesting and enticing with its soft beginning and sharper, hoppier ending.  Quite nice.
Genuine dark trappist beer with moderate flavor. Smells of nice sweet cherries and big star fruit. Taste is nicely sweet and malty.

330mL bottle, pours dark reddish brown. Aroma of dark fruits and caramel malts, with a dry red wine quality. Flavour is a perfect balance of dry dark fruits, caramel and vinous characteristics. Fantastic dubbel.
Bottle. Pours a cloudy red/brown. Aroma of malt, caramelised brown sugar and plums. Flavour includes the aforementioned plus dry red wine and raisins. Clean finish with a slightly bitter aftertaste.

Nice brownish, muddy red coloured body with a thin tan head that fades fast. Aroma of malt, light nuts and a touch of spices and a very mild sweetness. Medium-bodied; Deep malty and yeastie flavours throughout with some light raisin sweetness, but more of a yeast and wheat overtone. Aftertaste shows a little alcohol and a bit more sweetness from pit fruits and raisins. Overall, a nice mild dubbel with some light sweetness and perhaps more malt than others - still mild though. I sampled this 33 cL bottle purchased from AH Supermarket in Amsterdam, The Netherlands for 1,10 on the streets of Amsterdam on 02-January-2011.

11.2oz bottle poured into my Gouden glass...A medium brown, amber in the light. a boring tan head of only about a finger, falls quickly, bad lacing...A really light aroma, plums, sugar and alcohol, not complex enough for me...The taste is really boring, a watered down cherry coke, dark fruits, and alcohol...An amazingly light feel.

This is just lacking all respects.

dark brown pour, light beige head. aroma of minerals, bready, yeast, dark ripe fruit. flavor was quite bready, and had a large mineral flavor also. this was still quite fruity, and really was like liquid bread. nice stuff.
Aroma fruttato (pruga, frutti di bosco), complessa al palato ma equilibrata e morbida. Ottima.

Draught sample at Beer Bistro Toronto. Pours a red/ orange/ brown, small white head that has no retention and decent lacing. Aroma is fruity, a little plum and alcohol. Taste is sweet caramel and slightly of alcohol.

Kellemesen frissítő, édeskés ízű sör. A habja közepesen tartós, inkább szappanhab jelleggel (nagy buborékok jellemzik). A karamell maláta íze dominál a legjobban, festő malátát nem éreztem benne. A komló jellegzetes ízét hiányolom. A világ nem szűnt meg a kortyolgatása közben. Jó, iható, de az itteni ára nem áll arányban az élvezettel.

Cette trappiste est bel et bien bâtie. Elle est d abord d un beau rouge-brun foncé à la mousse fine comme on s y attend. Au goût les notes sucrées de fruits type cerises noires et cassis se mélangent à des notes plus automnales de figues, pruneaux et boisées. L alcool tient en longueur ces belles notes sans en déborder ni exagérer, bel équilibre. En fait je préfère presque la double à la quadruple. 
Je mettrai juste un bémol pour l originalité qui suit très (trop) bien la recette trappiste.
33cl bottle. Poured dark brown color with a huge tan head. Aroma is dark fruits, yeast and malt. Flavor is dark fruits and malt, bit too much alcohol present in taste, sweet finish.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: impressive, atypical ruby red colour, slightly sweeter than their quad, with a touch of bitterness bitter, raisins, prunes, caramel, syrup, liquorish and a lovely hint of redcurrant berries, medium body which works nice for this one

Big but quickly dissolving head over deep brown beer. Caramel, blackcurrant, cereal cloves. Quite a mild aroma for the fierce carbonation, but a good one. Delicious balanced taste, sweet and a bit sticky. Long aftertaste. (33cl bottle)

Neat little drink.  Pours a deep mahogany with lingering film of head.  I get big time molasses and raisins out of this one, with some soft funky yeast lingering in behind.  The raisin quality reminded me a lot of a big barley wine or something but without the chewiness and massive alcohol that made this a lot more drinkable.  Less potent, but more drinkable.

Clear red brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, dried fruit and yeasty. Flavor is rather sweet and moderate bitter. Light bitter and sweet finish. Soft and smooth. Lovely balance. 050311

The nose has cherries set off against a soft malty background. The appearance is an opaque, dark brown wtih a red hue. The head resembles cappucino and the head retention is good. On the palate there is more malt and cherries but bubble-gum appears in the middle section. There is a silky texture and considerable structure but a cleansing and more sour finish than expected. A very well balanced and complex beer.
Excellent dark Trappist beer. Gentle yet deep and rich flavour. Recommendable.

On tap; pours a brownish golden color-minimal head. Aroma some what sweet, almost caramelly. Taste, very smooth, sweet and very easy drinking. It was much better than I expected though not quite as good as some Belgium choices. Overall though, I would recommend this beer.

Dark brownish amber with a tan head that diminished quickly to nothing. Aroma of caramel, Belgian yeast, raisins and alcohol. Taste is sweet with a bit of yeast and alcohol. Not much depth to it, but reasonably pleasant. Body is medium-thin and moderately carbonated. It finishes with a residual alcohol taste. Definitely not a top notch dubbel.
La Trappe tasting. Dark brown body, tan head. Sugar, alcohol, raisins, chocolate. Some wine in flavour. Sweet oily texture.

Bottle. A nice aroma of malt, chocolate, light fruity, raisins. The pale beige creamy head is large with a normal duration. The body is dark brown. The taste is very malty, reminds me a little bit of an chocolate pudding, later it gets a little bit bitter. The body is medium strong and creamy with a soft carbonation.
Dark brown body with a creamy off-white head and amazing lacing. Floral, with fruits and caramel, namely kiwi in the aroma. Full and alcoholic mouthfeel, sweet and fruity taste. Nice.

A - little hazy very dark orange and amber
S - dark fruits - raisins, plums, light rum and syrupy malt
T - I got some perfume and oil taste, maybe badly stored before bought. However dark fruits in the body and winy and little dry end
M - medium to hight carbonation with medium body
D - not much drinkable since the perfume and oil taste, but I can bet other bottles or tap beer will be lot more better

head: beige , creamy 
colour: very dark brown 
smell: sour, malty , bitter, rock candy, yeast, licquorice, bit of abricots 
taste: almunds, bubblegum, malts, anis, bittersweet end , palate is dry, aftertaste is cake

Bottle 33cl. Pours a murky ruby colour with a small head and almost no carbonation. Smells fruity and sweet with also some hops and malts. Taste is very warm and can taste raisins and some fruits in there vaguely. Goes down very nice and warm with a good aftertaste and a warm feeling in the throat.

(750ml bottle shared with the Mrs.).  Pours cloudy mahogany with khaki head.  Aroma of caramel, candied sugar, alcohol and dark fruits.  Taste is sweet, but not overpowering.  Thin bodied with a silck mouthfeel.  Smooth finish.  I think this bottle is at least 1 year old.  There is an off-taste, but I think its bottle specific.

Bottle 0.5L.
Dark amber body, with an average, creamy, light-brown head, mostly lasting with a good lacing; average density of medium-sized bubbles.
Heavy malty aroma with complex notes of caramel, prunes, raisins and spices.
Intense sweet flavour with a light bitter note that comes up after a while.
Medium body with an oily texture; lively carbonation; alcoholic warming  in the finish.
Quite a satisfactory and complex beer.
On tap. Dark brown with little head. Slight aroma but taste is much nicer. A little blackberry or blueberry or something in there. Got better as it got warmer.
On tap a beerBistro, has a nice aroma, dark in colour, Recommend drinking this when it is warmer, this beer is meh when it is cold but very good when it is cool.
Bottled from Dutch cheese shop in Bratislava. Dark brown color with nice beige head. Aroma, dried red fruit, caramel. Taste, raisins, again caramel, orange. Alcohol is nicely hidden. Excellent beer.

Deep brick red.  Dark fruits, sweet molasses, and a touch of yeast in the aroma.  Flavor is along the same lines but with noticeable chocolate and a decent acidity in the finish.  Medium bodied.  Real nice.  Went great with New Years day pork and sauerkraut.

Draft at Hopleaf.  Deep amber brown with a patchy, soap bubble head.  Sweet deep chocolate aroma.  Doesnt strike me as a classic example of a Dubbel, but still quite awesome.  Some pungent underlying fruity tones..raisin, plum, prune.  Super malty chocolate tones.  Relatively soft carbonation.  Certainly has a Dutch feel to it. Excellent.

On tap at Beer Bistro in Toronto, served in a branded Trappist glass. Pours clear brown with a small tan head. The head fades to a thin remnant and leaves a small amount of fine lace behind. The nose has aromas of raisins, candi sugar, dark fruit, flowers and yeast. The flavour is moderately sweet throughout with lots of raisin and candi sugar complexity. On the palate, it is medium in body and somewhat syrupy in texture, with soft carbonation. Overall, this is a nice malty dubbel with lots of raisin and candi sugar, a hint of flowers and dark fruit. It is well put together and subtle. It is actually a nice sessionable choice. 2010-12-17

Bottle. Aroma is lots of caramel and malt, some liquorice and spices.
Flavour is the same with a touch of metal. Okay I guess.

06/12/2010 - 33cl bottle @ home
5 months old. Brown little clouded beer, beige non adhesive head, dissipates quickly. Aroma: oh the banana! More banana candy rather than the real fruit. Also apple juice. MF: nice carbon, light to medium body, bit watery texture. Taste: fruity, mocha, caramel. Aftertaste: sour fruits, caramel, banana (candy). 
Note: so I finally got around to taking some notes for the trappists. Ive been drinking them for years and usually when I did not felt like sampling something new and taking notes. Tasted them with 2 friends for a trappist review article in the student society magazine.
Dark brown with brown head. Nutty, fruity aroma.  Flavor is fruit, nuts, Belgian yeast.

Delicious round and mellow red ale. Quite a soft beer for the style, almost reminiscent of less belgian reds. Very light body and feel that dissipates in your mouth like water running through ones fingers.

Bottle 330ml. Exceptional beer. Aromas of caramel, chocolate, and lots of fruit (apricot, cherries). Taste is sweet, with a touch of acidity, long length, and dry finish. Palate is creamy, with a full body. Red, with a frothy white head.

Sötétbarna színű apátsági dupla, tetején egy ujjnyi vastag, tejföl-szerű, bézs színű habtakaróval, mely végig megmarad a tetején.
Édes-fanyar illata aszalt gyümölcsös és karamellás.
Közepes fajta teste sima és ragadós, igen malátás aromája karamellás, csokoládés, citrusos, íze konyakmeggyet idéző, csokoládés.
Keserű csokoládés befejezésében feltűnik némi fűszeresség és az alkohol is, amely a háttérben kellemesen melenget, utóíze csoki és fűszeres egyveleg.
Jó volt.

On tap at Arendsnest in Amsterdam, November 2010.

Clear dark brown with a small white head. Aroma was fruity with spices, malt and caramell. The same in the taste. Quite sweet.

Bottle, 33cl. Pours a clear and dark copper beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, sweetness, fruit, yeast and dried fruit. The flavor is close to the nose. The palate is sweetness and some alcoholwarmth. Overall a good beer.
On tap at bierbistro. Light brown with thin lace head.  Too cold at first, but the flavour came out as it warmed.  Sweet caramel malt and warm mouth feel. Fig and nut flavours. Pleasant.

330ml bottle @ Henriks. Dark deep brown body with a white long lasting creamy head. Nose is earthy, yeast and caramel also cold and silky. Lively carbonation. Quite sweet with a nice round and mild smooth ending

On tap at beerbistro (as Koningshoeven Dubbel Trappist Ale).  Pours a cloudy amberish brown with large creamy tan head.  Aroma is on the mild side - mostly ripe dark fruit.  Flavour is tart berries, dark fruit and hazelnut.  Fruit lingers in the finish.  Body is a little thinner than ideal.  But all in all pretty decent.

33cl bottle.
White foamy head.  Dark amber colour.  A decent double :-)

11/3/10.  Dark brown pour with light red edges with a big fluffy khaki head that fizzes away fast.  The aroma is dusty, funky Belgian yeast with lots of roasted brown sugar, banana, cloves, and a hint of alcohol.  Sweet brown sugar and roasted malts, dusty Belgian yeast, bananas, and a hint of sour and alcohol.  Pretty good!
Dark brown beer with disappearing head.Smell chocolate,nuts,dry plum,caramel,malty.Taste nuts,caramel ,raisins,chocolate,sweet. Long lasting caramel finish.A good dubbel.
bottle. Deep brown colour. Full-bodied, malty, hints of raisins, nuts, plums, caramel, roasetd malts. A pleasant experience.

Bottle.  Pours clear dark brown with an average, frothy tan head, medium retention with light lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (dark fruit, cookie, toast, nutty), light hops (woody), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of brown sugar, dates, and vanilla.  Flavor is heavy malt (dark fruit, cookie, toast, nutty), light hops (woody), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of brown sugar, dates, and vanilla.  Full body, medium warmth and carbonation, light creaminess with a dry finish.
28th February 2006  Warning! Early amateur rating! Flat red ale. Bitter start with a weird smoky aftertaste. Nothing special!

330 ml bottle. From Eindhoven, the Netherlands. Parallel tasting with La Trappe Blond/Dubbel/IsidOr/Quadrupel.
Dark brown colour with tiny off-white head.
Aroma: Dark fruits, caramel, chocolate, roasted malt, some vinousness.
Flavour: Dark fruits, mild hops, vinousness.
Flat and thinnish. 
Very simple for Trappist

330 ml bottle @ Ravintola Gloria, Kuopio. Rated @ 18.12.2009.
Clear reddish brown colour with a small white head. Aroma of fruits, caramel and mild hoppy. Medium sweet flavour with caramel malts, dark fruits and sugar. Medium bodied and a thin mouthfeel. Average Dubbel.

Bottle:
Light brown to off white foamy head.
Pours a clear dark brown beer.
Smell sweets, malts, nuts, some hints of dark fruits.
Taste is a nice mix of sweets and darker ingredients: barleys, (brown) sugars, hints of dark fruit (prunes and raisin), spices, hint of caramel and slight hint of alcohol. Niceley balanced.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: 750ml.  Robust aroma of dusty dates and prunes, smells of silence and divinity.  Dark cola amber, sandy tan head.  Cola nut on the sip, some hazelnut and toasted wheat with leather and sugar.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2011 Bottle. Reddish brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma: raisins, bubblegum, fruit, yeast. Taste: sweet and malty, dried fruits, candy, sweet pears. Medium-bodied, quite moussy. Nice dubbel.
Dark color.   Easy to drink.   Sweeter than I would have preferred.  Pretty smooth and drinkable.  I like the stronger La Trappe beers better (trippel and quad).  La Trappe is far from La Crappe.

Aroma of iodine and nailpolish with a slight beet sugar smell. Flavor is old prune juice, watered down with hard spring water. Flavor is very thin, but has a strong lasting flavor. This is not as much fun, or as awe inspiring as the Quadruple. Ill stick with the Quad.
Looks like prune juice and menstrual blood.  Smells sweet, tastes like carbonated pitted fruit, grape soda, with an after taste of dried dates.  It is refreshing and I like it.
Got on draught at maxs. Pours a dark brownish color. Smells of sugar. Taste is very sweet. Has a bit of alcohol in the aftertaste. Not bad

This beer had a dark brown and cloudy color with a big, foamy, dark-tan head that had good retention and some cling.  Featured a strong malt aroma with pine and grainy hops and some caramel too.  A sweet, malty caramel taste with some sour and bitter hop flavors too.  The body was somewhat wet with a lot of fizz and a lively mouthfeel.  Quite a good beer!
port and weak alcohol on the nose, carb is medium+, taste is port, plums, weak note of wood and a whiff of alcohol
A very fine dubbel beer,with a very smooth taste,so refreshing and tastefull,Really enjoyed every bit of its 750ml bottle.Pours a brownish colour and leaves a yearning taste behind.

Bottle, last year.
Brown and very cloudy. The head didnt last long.
Strong aroma, with hints of dried plums, maltiness, cherries and a bit of alcohol in the background.
Very full-bodied.
Very malty, with a lot of yeasty nots, nuts, fruits and caramel.

On tap.  Served a thick dark brown with a red hue.  Head was a short thick cream that laced the glass for the entire drink.  Aroma heavy with malts, licorice, raisins, yeast, brown sugar, and subtle fruit.  Moderate body.  Flavor heavy with caramel, malts, more sweet fruits, and sharp spices to lace the alcohol.  Well carbonated, moderate mix of bitterness and sweetness.  Finishes sharp.
Bottle 0,33ltr: Dark brown slightly sweet Dubbel with some caramel hints and taste of roasted malts.
Tipica dolciona industriale stile similbelga, e questi hanno pure il logo trappist. Birre del genere mi hanno davvero rotto le scatole..
On draught at Paters Vaetje, Antwerpen. Aroma of caramel. Sweet, brown-sugar taste. No real hop taste to finish. Quite nice.
33 cl bottle, pours dark amber, aroma is dark fruits and malt, taste is sweet malt with a hint of dark fruits, somewhat abrupt finish, decent dubbel though.

Was served On-tap in a La Trappe Chalice at a cafe/pub in Amsterdam. It had a deep amber color with a decent head. The smell was sweet and fruity. The taste was sweetness and finished with a bitterness. It has a medium body that went down easy with no real hint of alcohol. Enjoyable brew to finish the day with.
33 cl bottle. Dark copper with small lasting tan head. Flavour is malt, caramel, dark fruit, sweet, spices and yeast.

On tap at the Brick Store. Pours a dark brown with an ample head that eventually goes away. The smell is of sweet caramel and yeast. The flavor is sweet, but balanced nicely. The palate is slightly fizzy and very smooth. Overall, an excellent easy drinking beer.
Much better than the blond.  Creamy, malty, complex.  Dark fruits and caramel dominate the palate.  Abbey dubbels are among my favorites and this does not disappoint.

Courtesy of SHIG. Pours clear copper with full off white head. The aroma is full of apple and pear fruity goodness along with spikes of spices and yeastiness. The taste is smooth apple and pear sweetness as well as coriander, clove and yeasty spices rounding things out.
11.2 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark brown with nice tan head.  Aroma of caramel, malt and fruit.  Tastes of malt, yeast, fruit and a touch of chocolate.  Full body.  Very nice.

Pours copper ruby with a large tan head that quickly fades to a thin creamy covering.
Nose can only be described as spicy fruitcake: cinnamon, figs, candi sugar, brandy and sultanas are all apparent.
Similarly rich, sweet, malty flavours with Christmas spices adding a little complexity. Alcohol is just noticeable as in the aroma.
Body is surprisingly light for the flavours, the carbonation is unsuitably high.
caramel, coffee, resin, floral, ginger, cheese, brown, hazy, frothy, white foam, lightly bitter, light sweetness, medium body,oily feel, lively, bitter,

Aka: Koeningshoven Dubbel Trappist Ale. Tried at Pub Italia on Preston in Ottawa, Ontario. Poured a deep golden-amber colour with a mid-creamy tanned head. Had good foamy lacing and a 2mm top coated the brew and stayed. Carbonation was active with tiny miniscule bubbles. The nose was filled with nuts and hints of dark fruits. Taste was mostly nutty with a slight sourness in the start going to a grain aftertaste. Found some bread in the finish and a bit of alcohol. The mouthfeel was smooth with some mild tartness. Pretty decent lower alcohol trappist brew.
Pours dark, hazy brown with a thin tannish head. Spicy aroma with notes of nuts, earthiness, raisin. A bit acidic and fairly sweet. Fairly thick bodied and filling. Nice beer.
From a bottle poured a dark amber color with a fair amount of head.  Malty flavor with a quick finish.

Bottle from the Bayou. Pours a very dark red/purple color with a very small white head. A nice nose of vinous notes, lots of fruit. The flavor is a nice dubbel; smooth, rich fruity flavors, strawberries, but a darker chocolate or cocoa toasty flavor as well. Easy to drink and well made.
UPDATED: OCT 1, 2013 Très bonne trappiste au gout fruité, avec léger gout de caramel. Gout fort en bouche, fort caractère malgré une pétillance très légère.  Cest une bière très désaltérante.

Bottle.

A - Dark cherry oak color with a fairly large, bubbly, foamy, off-white head. Decent retention that settles into a thin layer of lace with thicker patches near the edges.

S - Strong dark fruit with a very vinous smell with grape, plum and fig being strongest. Some molasses and dark malt also comes out. Faint medicinal smell as well. Has a bit of a sweet, syrupy aroma overall.

T - Dark, sweet and toasted bready malt with some caramel and molasses and carob taste. Mid sip, some of the dark fruit comes out, with it being somewhat vinous and a lot of figs with some plum. Some spice comes out along with the dark fruit, particularly pepper but some clove and cinnamon. Hints of chocolate. Slight mineral taste near the finish and some alcohol taste.

M - Medium body with a bit above carbonation. Pretty creamy, but a touch watery as well. 

D - A very drinkable beer with a nice balance of malty/bread taste and dark/vinous fruit. Not overly powerful on the palate, but has a nice lingering taste.

Notes: Best before 10/2011. A nice Dubbel that is very well balanced. A bit more on the vinous side of dark fruit flavors and has a bit more of a mineral than I expected. Overall a solid enjoyable beer that I would happily drink again.
Brown with mid-size tan head. Sweet malt and fruity aroma. Its a little bit than the quadrupel.

14-MAY-2010, bottle @home, from "Ølbutikken".
Lovely brown with high head, that unfortunately dissappears right away:(
All the notes you would hope for in a double, dried fruits, figs, cane sugar, yeast.
Only better than most:)
Nice brown pour with good head. Nose and taste of caramel malt and nuts. Very smooth. Rated11/3/2000

Pours deep brown with off white head, aroma is some roasted malt, chocolate, and some nutty character.  Taste is nice balanced chocolate and coffee hints with some roasted character and a slightly dry finish. For a dubbel, great balance and flavor.

33cl bottle, dark elegant reddish amber color, small lasting creamy beige head, caramel and yeast aroma with dark fruits notes, sweet flavor, dry finish with nice aftertaste of spices, roasted and apple, very standard dubbel not interesting but pleasant

Bottle, 33 cl. Brown beer with a reddish shine, small beige head, no lacing. Aroma of roasted malts, light sweet. Taste is caramel, creamy, roasted malts in the finish, and spices on the background. Nice beer!

La Trappe bottle and chalice. Pours mahogany deep clear brown with a red shade. Vanishing thin head. Nose is sweet like that purple candy. Aromas of dark fruit. Raisins, berries, ... Taste a bit too sweet.

Dark amber/brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, toffee, & dark fruit; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, caramel, dark fruit, and subtle chocolate; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, a solid dubbel.

Dark amber red. Sweet aromas of caramel malt & floral hops. Slight bitterness quickly gives way to sweet toffee, banana, dried fruit figs & rasins. Smooth mouth &  sweet lingering finish. Too sugary, one only for me.

Pours a deep ruby body covered with a dense, yet quickly disappearing off-white head. Looks very inviting. Smell is yeasty, filled with dark malts, figs and cherries. Taste is delicious: molasses, figs and raisins combined with strong cherries and fruitiness. Such a difference from the La Trappe Blond. La Trappe Dubbel is definitely in the game.
UPDATED: JUL 10, 2015 Bottle.Pours murky brown with a tan head.Aroma of toffee ,malt and caramel.Flavor is malty with licorice ,toffee and caramel.Some residual sweetness .Medium body . Nice dubbel.
Bottle 750 ml.Clear red/brown color with great brown lasting head. Aroma toffee, sugar. Taste brown sugar, dark fruit. Full body, soft carbonation.
Dark tan with a creamy head. Banana aroma,with sweet malts and spice. Slightly sweet with a medium to thin body, short bitter finish.
A really solid dubbel with bonus points for being readily available. Lots of fig, plum, spice etc with a smooth finish. Not as complex as say chimay or westmalle, but cheaper.
Shared this one w/ SkyCop32. Picked up at Maruhn Getränke in Darmstadt. Pours a hazy medium amber. Aroma is lightly malty, hoppy, yeasty. Flavor is moderately sweet, alcoholic, roasty dark.
Pours dark brown with a light head. Aroma and flavor are sweet malts, like usually in trappist beers. Very nice.
sweet spicy,brown, clear, minimal head, light sweetness, lightly bitter, creamy, soft carbonation,

750 ml corked and caged bottle poured a clear reddish brown with a lasting creamy tan head. Aromas of toffee, dates, figs, cola, candy sugar and light spice. Palate was medium bodied and crisp with a smooth finish. Flavors of toffee, cola, fruittiness, brown sugar and light spice with a smooth lingering fruity finish.
Strong spiced banana aroma.  Deep brown with a hint of tan head.  Syrupy banana, cinnamon and brown sugar with roasted undertones.  A bit too banana and syrupy for my taste.

on tap @ smokeless joe. beautiful reddish brown with a thick tan head. wonderful dark fruity nose with ripe red fruit and yeasty esters. the flavour profile is classic dubble. really stunningly good. la trappe may not be the most sought after trappist brewery but everything ive had from them has been top notch. id drink this anytime i was in the mood for a dubble.

[2759-20100212] Tap. Nail polish malt aroma. Slightly hazy, dark brown amber body with a medium-lasting foamy light tan head. Fruity booze up front in the flavour with weird musky banana cardboard notes and an overly yeasty bread dough aftertaste. Medium-full body. Boozy.
(@ Smokeless Joes; Toronto, ON)
Pours dark amber. Fruity aroma with hints of spices and caramel. Flavour is brown sugar, malts and plums.
Redwood, khaki head fades to a white ring. Bubbly carbonation. Banana, nut, and caramel aroma. Heavy sweet into light sour with faint, short, bitter finish. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Lovely.

330 ml bottle.  Pours a murky, reddish brown body.  Off-white, foamy head dissipates to leave a lasting ring of fine bubbles.  Pearly carbonation rising to the top.  Aroma is of intense raisin and plum with some grape.  Well defined.  Brown sugar and spiced rum notes become evident in the flavors, as well as some fig and light raisin.  No alcohol is discernible.  Medium bodied, but the effervescent carbonation keeps it feeling light.  Lingering sugar on the tongue detracts slightly, but the lasting fruit in the nose is very pleasant.  Overall tasty, repeatable and clean.
330ml bottle - Rich dark amber. Dark fruit cake, very sweet with hot alcohol. A touch of banana too which gave it the feeling of being an amped up, darker version of the blonde. Fair - reasonable
bottle almond amber pour with off white foam, aroma of raw olives, belgian sugar, plastic, malty, flavors of brown sugar, prunes, bready malt, short finish

330ml bottle at Bières et Compagnies, served in a Tulip. ive been waiting a long time to try the only Trappiste not made in Belgium! pours a beautiful creamy deep brown with an off white head. aroma is dried fruit, plum, roasted malts, caramel and some scotch. taste is slightly sweet with no bitterness at all. this is a great beer to accompany a nice meal. it is full bodied with a creamy texture and medium carbonation. cant wait to try the Tripel now!

From a bottle poured into matching Trappist glass. Dark translucent amber colour with a thin, light brown head. Aroma of dark fruits with hint of alcohol. Delicate flavour with notes of dried fruit, caramel and bergamot and a lasting finish. A very good beer that holds its own against other Trappist dubbels - I also preferred this head and shoulders over the same brewers tripel.

On tap at Beneluxx in Philly, poured a dark red amber with a think white head that was gone in the blink of an eye.  Aroma consists of malts, caramel, toffee and chocolate.  Taste is sweet with the toffee and caramel coming through with a hint of alcohol.  Light bodied with a creamy mouthfeel.  Very little carbonation.  A nice Dubbel.

Dark brown with a slight red tinge and has a large slightly off white head. It is dominated by the smell of dark fruits, hops, and light barley malts with a subtle alcohol undertone. Unfortunately the taste does not stand up to the scent and is not nearly as complex. Good, not great.

Dark brown body and tan head. Fruity aroma of apple, figs, grapes and prunes with some spicy and caramel. Fruity flavor, sweet  little sour. A good beer to drink, a good example of an abbey dubbel beer.

750 ml bottle, chilled. Big head, light brown with minimal frothing and lacing, translucent and deep brown colour. Fruity alcoholic nose, with floral undertones and no hint of hops and slight hint of malt. Sweet slight taste of ripe banana and an apple undercurrent and no hint of sourness or bitterness. Full bodied with creamy texture, short finish, little carbonation and no hint of astringency. Overall very pleasant and fruity.
One of the least "trappist" beers. The flavour is not bad, but its not strong enough.

Bottle. 24.5 oz. Split with Vinny. Pours deep plum-brown with a creamy, frothy off-white head. Aroma of grapes, figs, plum, barley, roasted malts, and scotch. Dry, crisp mouthfeel with a moderate, yet satisfying body. Tastes incredibly smooth after opening up for awhile. Finishes powerfully. Excellent dubbel.
big fruit aroma, amber, brown, hazy, brown foam, medium bitterness, medium sweetness, full body, slick feel, lively, long finish,
user_location: Cambridge and Kladno(Czech Rep.), Cambridgeshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle. Dark pour with thin white head. Very winey grape aromas, dry, fruity and sweet. Taste is quite fruity, lots of plums and grapes, some alcohol. Smooth mouthfeel with a decent alcohol presence.

Great body, and fruit, strong taste in order to simulate a classic trappist beer. Of course is missing a real procedure to be a real flamish abbey beer... too industrial. Please I accept comments. Salud !

Bottle. Pours a hazy, dark, reddish brown with a finger of tan head. Aroma is very fruity, mostly prunes. Yeast is also very present, along with a herbal spicy side and some chocolate notes. Fairly sweet, with a medium to low bitterness in the finish, that saves it from being too sweet. Its a bit too fizzy for me, also it has got this mineral sting on the tongue to it that I dont like at all. Would have been great with smoother carbonation and less mineral flavours.

2009-06-05  10 grader, tapp (Delirium, Göteborg)
UTS: Härligt mörk rödbrun med fint skum
D: Jäst (inte lika påtaglig som andra trappist), torkad aprikos, vanilj fudge
S: Jäst, torkad aprikos, vanilj fudge
ES: Lätt, lite kärv - som rödvin
Storebrosan Quadrupeln - var bättre, kolla!

330mL Bottle. Rated blind. Twelfth out of a set of 12 Abbey Dubbels. Aroma is rich with spiced 

white figs, cooked pears, and pale caramel. Zested tangerines fall in. 

Pours a dark red-copper, clearish, with a settle, super-soft head of 

tan. Flavor is zesty and super fruity. Beautiful almond paste, eggnog, 

and mulled spices. Juicy yeast esters, a twinge of hops, and great 

caramelized sugars mingle for a beautiful sensation. The best for last! 

This was far and way the best example in my book. Great spiciness from 

the yeast, wonderful chewy dark malts, balance from refined alcohols, 

and all around tightness. Stunning. GUESS: Chimay or Rochefort

330mL bottle.  Pours a hazy amber-brown with a thin off-white head that quickly diminishes.  Aroma is malty and sweet with slight hints of yeast.  Medium bodied and quite lively on the palate.  Fruity flavour with noticeable sweetness and a mildly sour aftertaste.  As with the Tripel the last mouthful teases you.

Serving date: 2009-02-11. Served in snifter.

330 ml bottle with a logo and the word "trappist" molded into the glass. Interesting to note that there are two different freshness dates on the bottle. One is on the label (best before end of March 2011) and one is on an extra label (best before end of 2011) added by the Swedish importers. A rather significant difference between the two dates, but I think this one will be great quite some time after 2011, so its really no big deal.

Dark ruby color, going towards dark brown. A small 1,5 cm tan head that looks rather creamy settles just a little to quickly. It leaves minimal lacings.

In the nose, theres sweet malts and general spicy aromas, but most of all a delightful smell of fresh fruits. Some faint notes of chocolate as well.

Some phenols up front in the taste, but in no way sharp or harsh. Then some spices coupled with sweet and a bit vinous malts and fruits (definitely cherries, and perhaps fresh figs). Milk chocolate (that becomes more prominent towards the end) adds more sweetness. In the middle it gets a little tart. In the slightly dry finish there are warmth from the alcohol, herbal flavors, faint malts and just a tad of bitterness. Overall, the hop character of this one is really restrained. Very well balanced flavors.

Medium to full body. Rather smooth and calm, despite plenty of carbonation. Slightly chewy.

This is a great, slightly vinous, beer. Its very complex, but most of all its so well balanced. Very pleasant mix of sweetness (mostly from fruits) and spices, phenols and tartness.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

Bottle from The Trappist. Pours a brown with a hazy color. Notes of fig and nut. Flavor has same nuttiness, as well as some dark fruit, and apricots. Has almost a smoky flavor. Has a golden raisin flavor.
300 ml bottle dark red/brown color smells sweet and spices tast sweet and spices with a little bitter

Pours murky reddish brown with a tan head with good retention. Aroma of honey and malts. Flavor is sweet, a bit bitter and slightly watery but well balanced. Low carbonation. Decent bittersweet finish.

Bottle. Pours a hazy brownish copper colour with a bubbly light tan head that doesnt last long. Nose is sweet with notes of toffee, cola, raisins, cherries and brown sugar. Flavour is also sweet but has a strong malt presence as well and has hints of toffee, oak, chocolate and dark fruit. Medium to full bodied with an almost sticky mouthfeel and a fair amount of carbonation, this is a particularly good dubbel, maybe too sweet for every taste, but a near classic nonetheless.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2013 Small bottle. Caramel, rapidly vanishing brown head. Nose of chocolate and pruney malts; some alcohol and grasses. As you might expect, very carbonated mouthfeel. Its filtered, so I cant imagine that would settle over time. Tastes like it smells. Fruit and alcohol finish. Would lose to an Italian soft drink mixed with vodka. [2.0]Bottle. Mid brown with a coat of beige head. Prunes, raisins, grass, some chocolate. Dry finish with unpleasant herbal notes. Fizzy, vacant middle palate.  Similar experience, less grumpy rating. Looks like this one is not for me.

Pours an opaque chocolate brown with a small tan head. Aroma is of chocolatey malts, a little bit of maple, and a little grass as well. Flavor is quite chocolatey, and that makes up most of the flavor profile, alongside a little cream. Thick viscosity, good carbonation. Nice one. Overall, excellent.

0.33L, medium stable light brown head, hazy light brown to deep red colour,  aroma of brown sugar and caramel, flavours of prunes, raisins and brown sugar with  hints of dark chocolate and bread, not to sweet with a very light bitterness. light but pleasant dour aftertaste. quite good but certainly not spectacular.

Nose is plums and brown sugar with just traces of belgian yeast. Flavor is heavy on the plums up front, a pleasant bready  fig/yeast combination as it warms a bit. There is a  noticeable alcohol burn that detracts from the overall taste from cold to warm. Not my favorite trappist (not close) but decent.
Quite good, not the best, too sweet, nice looks, alc character well performed, has this belgian orange peal characte as well
UPDATED: SEP 23, 2011 33cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex brew, balanced, hazy, good head, good Trappist

750 ml. bottle. Obviously not a good bottle as it pours with no head and is completely still. Ill evaluate what I can, rate it accordingly and acquire another bottle for re- rating at a later date. Body is clear, dark amber with an (SRM 15).....nose is dried fruit, cherries, raisins, also molasses....taste is sweet malts, toffee, caramel, then dried fruits mentioned finishing with a light molasses sweetness...mouth feel and carbonation are not rated. I think this might be a really great beer. It will be interesting to taste the difference carbonation makes.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2009 ~ Purchased this 750-ml bottle from Franks Beverage in Glen Cove, NY. Pours a deep red brown color with a decent sized head that subsides rather quickly. Each time a bottle of a Trappist Ale is opened, and I take a sniff, its always a memorable experience. There is such a unique aroma from this beer that I cant stop sticking my nose inside the glass! Strong hints of dark fruits, malts, and caramels tantalize the senses. The taste is complex, but everything pulls together rather pleasing. The taste is of bread malts, figs, and grapes. At almost 7% ABV, I polished this off with no problems at all. Wonderful execution on the style, and will undoubtedly seek this out again. 

I usually will not comment on how other members rate their beers (because everyone is entitled to their own opinions), but, with that said, how can some rate this a C, or even worse, a C-? I understand there are better dubbels out there, but come on now, seriously? I wish some would just give this beer a little bit of the respect that it deserves. Damaging ratings ought to be withheld for garden-variety American-style lagers. ~

16.9 oz crock-Pours adark amber light brown with a nice off white head. Aroma of fruits, caramel, sweetness, and malt. Taste of fruits, sugar, and yeast. This full bodied brew is very well balanced and tasty.
330ml bottle, Morrisons. Good dark ruby, malty, rich tasting ale. Ripe fruit evident, alcohol not too overpowering. Pleasant and smooth, my first experience of a Duth trappist ale.

25cl Bottle. Dark brown color with a nice medium beige head. Aroma of caramel & toasted malts . Sweet malty flavor with caramel and some fruits. Medium body, not very complicated. Very digestive & nice beer. La Trappe is not well known in Belgium and is often well appreciated by my guests.
Pours dark ruby red color with creamy tan head. Aromas of raisins and candy sugar. Moderately sweet raisin flavor with some candy sugar and a touch of yeast. Medium body with lively carbonation.
750ml - Aroma has tons of fruit, chocolate, cherry with a nice malt and yeast finish.  Flavor matches.  Palate is creamy and smooth.  A tasty brew.

Pours a dark brown with a creamy tan head. Smells of fermented fruit with a leather/tobacco smell. There is low carbonation in the beer, so the subtle flavors seem to come through which is sweet fruit and some spice. very good beer.
Pours a deep amber brown color with a tan head. Aroma is caramel, plum, sugary, fruity, and spicy. Flavor is fruity, grain, plum, grape, and spicy finish.

Draft at Ebenezers. Pours a lighter red brown, translucent. Nose is stone fruit, chocolate, caramel. Very easy drinking with the same characters coming through. Yeast doesnt contribute a ton, balances the sweetness somewhat. Decent.

Bottle at Beer Bistro in Toronto.  It was listed as Koningshoeven Dubbel.  Dark reddish brown pour, khaki colored head.  Dark fruits, sweetness shine though.  Caramel flavor, with just a hint of spiciness.  Pretty good overall.
Julios Belgian Beer Festival. Sample. By the time I got to this one I was seeing double. Rating it to keep track but dont have any particulars.

Bottle. Dark brown color with a lovely huge beige head. Aroma of caramel, toasted malts and some dark fruits. Sweet malty flavor with caramel, sweet plums, alcohol and lots of fruits. Some spicy yeast in the finish. Medium-bodied. Decent.
Later note: gets better as it gets warmer. Added a point for flavor and overall numbers.
I liked this beer. But I dont think I qualify to comment it anymore than that.

A nice dubbel, light with a good Belgian fruity, phenolic sweetness.  This beer pours a dark mahogany, translucent without the murkiness I was expecting.  The head dissipates quickly but sprouted nicely and left a bit of lacing and, at least, a fair ring around the outside of my goblet.  The aroma has a strong phenolic band-aid note, although its not unpleasant.  There are also strong Belgian stone fruit flavors, a touch of earth and a splash of rum.  Its a fruity, sweet beer, like a quad without depth and punch.  Again, that sounds critical and thats not entirely meant.   I dont always want to drink big heavy quads, but I still prefer them in terms of ratings.  While its more drinkable than a quad, it still tends to make my mouth turn when I take a large sip.  If nothing else, Koningshoeven deserves an award for packing this much flavor in a 6.5% abv beer.  It might not be the most complex Belgian flavor, but its a big, assertive sweetness.

(bottle - 330 ml) Dark red pour with a creamy tan head. Aroma is light and fruity with some hints of citrus, raisins, and yeast. Flavor is sweet and malty at the start with citrus and dark fruit notes near the middle Finish is clean and dry with a lightly sweet aftertaste. Very fizzy and a bit thin, but really tastes good.

Nice creamy beige head above a dark reddish liquid, aroma is quite yeasty with some lemon and mandarine, some dark fruit is present as well, feels quite dry, with intense yeasty flavors, some fruits like cherries, raisins, quite alcoholic with a hoppy finish. Again body is medium compared to its style.

The beautiful dark color and head had me very interested in this one, but it smells horrible, like something spoiled or rotten. Since a lot of the ratings mention this sort of aroma, Im guessing this isnt a bad bottle. Flavor has a sickly sweet note. So disappointing, since I like their tripel and quad.

Well i am suprised this is la Trappe dubbel. I tasted at a irish pub in Fiosele as the name Dominus Dubbel. I said wow what a nice beer which i dont know the name just like trappiste. Brown colour with a nice head. Malty and hopps are well balaced too. such an anaother good dubbel. A bit of suprise for me.
Clear golden with tiny white head. Sweet yeasty aroma with caramel and malty notes. Sweet fruity flavor with caramel and mild hoppy notes.

33cl bottle. Boy this is lively! Barely cracked the cap and the thick brown foam was leaking down the sides. That aside, it pours a glistening ruby with a gorgeous, big, lasting beige head. Tangy, fruity, yeasty aromas. Plenty of malt and a hint of chocolate. Sweet, malty flavours of spice-coated fruits and tangy yeast with a chocolate bitterness. Delicate mouthfeel, soft carbonation with an ample dose of heat in the throat. Mmmm.

Bottle. Reddish brown bodu with a medium bubbly tan head. Sugary aroma with lots of caramel and dark fruit. Lots of caramel in flavour together with dark fruit, marzipan, chocolate and light tobacco notes. Medium bodied.

Draft @ Beer Bistro; Labeled as Koningshoeven Dubbel Trappist Ale:  Poured a dark red with a nice head.  The aroma was fruity and sweet malts.  The flavor was roasted malts, cherry licorice, hint of hops, and some other dark fruits.  Overall, my first from the Netherlands and it wont be my last.

Nice reddish-brownish colour with a weak head. Reminded me a lot of Brit ales.
The smell is totally there covering evrything from strawberries to cumin... cardamom, some lemon, even some cherries, brilliant!
Unfortunately, the taste doesnt go anywhere near the smell, settling for bitter yeastiness with coffee/toffee hints (very subtle) and some very subtle hints of fruit. Nice that it isnt so terribly sweet as dubbels usually are.

Rubyred, creamy head, long staying until 1 cm rests. In the nose its sweety, with caramel and candy. Much carbonized, sweet,some bitter hops, hints of roasted nuts. fairly long finish, with blackberries. Nice

Another Vegas trip special

Poured out a decent sized bubbly brown cap that crackled like a fire. This all died down to quick. Dark brown / red brew. Great aroma - very lively and upfront yet smooth and pleasant. Nutty with almonds being the most notable, licorice, roasted malts, prunes, weak medicinal blend (very weak), brown sugar, a hint of nutmeg (old) and more dark fruit. The taste is also very good and very tasty pleasuring my senses in a way that only soft kitten fur will do - preferabaly fresh kitten pelt mittens. Raisins, spice, roasted malts, toffee, port, nutmeg, some dark fruit and ample sweetness. Goes down smooth, nice lively carbonation, leaves the mouth soft and happy. Ends with a slight nuttiness and the faintest of bitter lingerings. Excellent brew that is very well balanced and shows off its wide range of flavours and aromas nicely.

Pours a clear nutty, amber with thick light tan colored head. Aroma is very caramely and brown sugar syrup. Vanilla extract presented an almond extract there too. Flavor is very mutty balanced with caramel/brown sugar. Malty flavors definitely there. A very subtle chocolate/coffee mix coming across (very light). Body is light but full. honey present in this beer too.
330ml Bottle from Corks, Bristol. Reddish-brown in colour with next to no head. Sweet red fruit and caramel aroma. Flavour of barley sugar, stewed fruit> Easy drinking with a light finish. Ok.

Bottled.
Brown with off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt and dried fruit. Flavor is caramel malt, coffee and yeasty fruit.

330ml Bottle, dark brown with a creamy head. Bubblegum and sweet malt aromas. Very sweet all round, almost too much for mine. Not really much depth of taste, mostly plums as has been said here by many. A little sticky on the lips too.

Not too shabby. Aroma has some warming notes of black cherry, plum, candy sugar, toffee, yeast. Flavor is similar,with dark fruits upfront followed by sweet malt and then a nice relaxing warming from the alcohol. Pretty tasty, although the price is a bit much for 7%.

Pours cloudy amber with yeast and other particulate matter floating about.  The head is thin and fast to fade.  Looks just like coca-cola.  Aroma is of Cherry, perhaps cherry sorbet.  Some notes of dark fruity malt.  A bit of funky yeast also is detectable.  A mixed fruit juice box flavor first hits the tongue with some alcohol that could be covered better and a bit of Belgian spice that is not overdone.  Lively carbonation makes for an interesting experience with yeast and malt covering the mid to tail end.  Good because its a bit different.

Koningshoeven Dubbel at the Thirsty Monk in Asheville. Nutty, malty flavor with traces of yeast. Dark fruits as well. Lightly sweet, but not overly so. Faint carbonation was perfect for the style. Just the right strength without being too alcoholic. Mild alcohol finish.

Poured into a La Trappe chalice.  Rich head dissapates quickly leaving a swirling galaxy of soft bubbles and brandy stewed pears.  Very fruit, stone fruit and caramel syrup with a restraing pepper spice.  The alcohol gives a sense of texture and bolsters the fruit.  A light dusting of cacao powder and a touch of percieved oak dry the palate out.   Of all of the Trappists, this is the lightest in carbonation, and certainly built of fruity esters cooked sugar elements.
I had this on tap at the Thirsty Monk in Asheville, NC under the Koningshoeven Dubbel Trappist Ale name. Beautiful ruby red with a slight apple/pear undertone without being sweet... absolutely yummy.
BOTTLE: brown/red pour, sweet fruit on the nose, just a tick of hop. Taste is malty-sweet & fruity. Decent body. Good stuff.
On tap at Beer Bistro. It pours a beautiful ruby red, wonderful ripe fruit aftertaste, with a clean smooth finish. Essential that it is served in a trappist glass to experience the aroma.

Ive drank this from those way cool  500ml stone corked cement bottles several  times , much as  Henry the 8th would have : Poured into a La Trappe goblet.,  Complex malt profile...caramely but reseverd sweetness..bananas and silky palates. Good ass shit.
Bottle 0.33 l. Deep brown colour, medium head, very rich sweet fruity aroma, plummy, slightly caramelly, malty and fruity palate. Long sweet aftertaste...

Pours a very attractive dark amber with a creamy, fading head. Sadly, there is very little on the nose. Thankfully it more than makes up for it in the mouth! Creamy, rich, but not too heavy mouth feel. The taste is vanilla, brown suger, baked apple and caramel. A very tasty drop
Looks very good, nice brown color. Taste was less fruity and fresh than La Trappe Quadruple but still good.
Has virtually no nose and the flavor is very bland. Hopefully I just got a bad bottle.

11.2 ounce bottle - $4.79 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Its been a good five years since Ive last had a La Trappe, so lets see how theyre doing these days! I vaguely recall either a 3 of 4-pack with a glass (that later broke). So many misty, watercolored memories!

Appearance: Pours a dark brownish-red, almost antique brick-hued body with a frothy, though somewhat short-lived, light beige head.

Smell: Dark malts and dark fruits tossed around in, appropriately enough, some dark syrup. Notes of dark sliced bread slathered in dark caramel and splashed with a bit of good, clean alcohol.

Taste: Dark, noticeably bready malts with a sweet, hearty brushing of both dark caramel and Dutch stroop. Meager hint of simple chocolate. Fruity mixture of dates, Concord grapes, and figs. Some woody hints along with a spicy dusting of finely ground pepper. A bit of alcohol heat on the semi-sweet, fruity, spicy finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium-high carbonation.

Drinkability: Paired well with the 1920 silent film "The Parsons Widow" directed by Carl Th. Dreyer. Still though, its not exactly the best Belgian Dubbel on the block, as its beaten out just barely, at least for me, by both the Rochefort 6 and Chimay Red.
Bottle. Another one I have enjoyed many times. I had it this time out of the crock. Dark amber brown colour with frothy beige head. Sweet caramal, cinnamon, dark fruits, wood and yeast.

750ml Bottle:  Aroma of yeast, slight caramel, slight candi sugar, and slight malts.  Poured deep orange/deep amber/brown/caramel in color with a large, beige head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Slightly cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of minuscule particles throughout.  Flavor is medium to heavily sweet.  Tastes of dark ripe fruits, caramel, slight tobacco, malts, candi sugar, slight wood, and slight yeast.  Medium body.  Moderately dry, slightly sticky texture.   Average carbonation.  Sweet, dark ripe fruit, caramel, and slight yeast finish.

Head dissappeard quickly, but that might have been my glass. Foam was a nice brown. Smells sweeter than it actually is. I tasted whole wheat bread in the middle of my mouth. Taste lingers for a while. Nice
Opaque cloudy brown with a small beige head. Fruity malt aroma. Rich, ripe dark fruit flavor. Sweet and heavy on the alcohol. Very good.

Bottle. Pours a hazy tea-brown with a golden head that displays good retention. Very yeasty fruity aroma, but toffee and toast come forward as it warms. Heaps of figs and plums in the flavour, with underlying sponge toffee malts. Very tasty, medium body that feels heavier because of the generous flavours and the sweetness.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Very good Dubbel.  Pours a chocolate brown.  Nose is chocolate and malts.  Taste is sweet, very little bitter.  Chocolate is the running theme that I noted.

25.4 oz bottle. Trappist brewery number 6 of 7. Sadly, I fear this is my last stop in tackling all the trappist breweries for a while, as Westveleteren is so difficult to obtain. Alas, I drink. Pours a dark brown with dark red around the edges, not opaque, but dark, with a small beige head that disappears faster than I can type. The smell is potent, as I could smell it during the pour. Smells of raisins, malt, light hop, some other dried fruit, and maybe chocolate. Very complex smell. Tastes of raisin, chocolate (which I dont understand), some malt, and thats about it (nothing like the smell in terms of complexity). Bubbly bite to it, with a medium body, and a funky after taste. If you want a trappist dubbel, I suggest Chimay Red or Westmalles, but this was interesting nonetheless.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2009 Dark brown with a touch of orange or amber. An extremely tall head that leave lacing all the way down. Rich aromas of roasted malt and yeast, with chocolate, grapes, dried figs or raisins.
The flavor is dryer than expected. Lots of chocolate and raisins. Very rich malt, not heavily roasted, hops not noticeable. Finish of chocolate malt, dried fruit. A touch of sweetness, but the overall impression is dryer. It may be the hops that are kicking in at the end. Something feels missing, though, something seems bland. Very sophisticated. A nice change from sweet trappist dubbels. nice indeed.

Poured a soda like brown body with a thin tan head. Aroma was slightly chocolatey, very fruity like grape juice, citric-pear, caramel, a fresh herbal quality, salty, and almost sour. Flavor was sweet dark fruit, strong malt, caramel, subtle chocolate, rooty, some vanilla, citric, and a bitter woodiness. Palate starts soft but quickly feels overcarbonated, and theres a little too much alcohol in the finish.

Bottle at Bishops Arms, Karlstad.
Pours a deep brown color with a dying head. Not sure how old this bottle is, but I guess it has been standing for a while at least. Aroma is vinous, fruity and malty with notes of caramel and dried plums. Flavour is sweet, fruity and quite vinous. Theres notes of dried plums, raisins and caramel. Mediumbodied mouthfeel, quite smooth, and the carbonation is low. Very nice sipper, maybe just a bit too sweet overall.

Felhős,vörösesbarna színű sör vékony gyorsan apadó habbal.Illata mazsolás,gyümölcsös.Ízében érezni egy kis karamellát,aszalt gyümölcsös süteményt és a komló kesernyésségét az alkohol édességével és melegségével.Utóíze pörkölt malátás,keserédes,enyhén száraz.Kellemes lefekvés előtti ital a szép álmokért.

750 mL from Raleigh WBF. Pours a clear deep brown with a generous tan head. Aroma of rum raisin, caramel, dark fruits. Taste is similar with a black cherries. Maple syrupy body that is fizzy to creamy on the palate. Very nice overall.

Deep reddish brown in color, little to no head, very little carbonation. Nose vaguely sour, citrus, light hops. Taste slightly sour, some citrus, also light cherries, burnt coffee, underlying hop notes.

Pours cloudy medium brown, with a one-and-a-half finger, beige head, very good lacing.  Smells of apple, leather, caramel, and a little nutty.  Medium, velvety body, strong carbonation.  Delicious, with tastes of apples, figs, caramel, citrus, and some floral grassy hops flavor.  Well balanced.

30cl bottle poured into a Westmalle Trappist glass.  Pours dark brown with very little head.  Smells like bubblegum.  Tastes like bubblegum and hops.  Sweet with just the right amount of bitterness.  Despite the candy taste, I really like this beer.  Good brew.
Uncorked, pours burnt sienna with beige head. Brown sugar aroma leads to very bready flavors, flour and fig. Lean body and yeasty mineral noted.

Dark ruby pour with nice haze and a large foamy off white head. Aroma of dark fruits, raisins, bread, a very pleasant nose. Flavor of dark fruits, bread, malt, vanilla, maple and brown sugar. Nice syrupy mouthfeel. Personally, think this one is underrated.

Bottle marked as Konings Hoven Dubbel. Pours with a small tan head over a dark brown, hazy body. Head fades somewhat quickly. Aroma of dark fruits, cherry, caramel, chocolate, soggy malts and rum. Taste is ashy, chocolate, brandy, raisins, cherry, dark fruits, cotton candy and earthy. Lively bubbles and a creamy mouthfeel.

Pours a murky purple brown with a one to two finger creamy light tan head. The nose is sweet, dark candy sugar, rummy, raisiny, fruity, nice yeast esters Flavor has a nice dark earthy character to it, nice yeast feel, bubblegum esters, fruity, mild spicy feel. Tasty dubbel but just missing a little something to make it great.

It poured a hazy dark red liquid with a big foam, but didnt leave any lacing on the glass. It had a nice fizzy smell of bread, dried fruit (orange) and peppery spices. The first taste hugged my tongue and it was allot smoother than I expected. The taste was very similar to the smell with the peppery spices and dried fruit. Very round and well balanced which made it easy to drink.

T.h.t. 05-2011.
A dusty scent accompanies ethyl acetate and nail polish remover. Thereby too sweet.

Bottle. Will have to re-rate as my notes are full of the match I was watching and some gobshite who was winding me up instead of the beer. It was a good dubbel, one of the styles where I rarely dislike anything. The usual dubbel experience and I liked it. Sorry beer people I should really try harder.

This pours a hazy very dark brown color with a thick tan head that settles down to a thin layer. The aroma is rather nice with licorice and some plums, figs and raisins. The flavor is rather weak and too simple and overall quite thin. Licorice up front with a flat dark fruity flavor following, some cardboard in there, touch of sherry, and the finish is somewhat empty. Hmm, this grew on me a little after a few sips and I admit Ive had the bottle a little while but I thought this one would be better.

750 mL bottle.  Dirty brown pour with a medium fizzy tan head.  Aroma of dark fruit, caramel and yeast.  Medium body with malt and yeast present.  Middle of the road dubbel, which means its still very good.
250ml bottle from Volo. Pretty much a typical Trappist Doubbel if you ask me. It was good, but what Abbey Dubbels arent? I may purchase this a few more times.

11.2 oz bottle with an ABV of 7% on the label. This beer is a very dark brown with maybe some red tints with a lingering tan head. The smell is very fruity, chocolates, and also vinegar. The taste is malty and fruity but it smells better than it tastes. If you like dubbels, this delivers.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-20-2008 06:13:30
Pours copper amber with off white head.  Aroma is malty, caramel.  Taste is caramel, raisin/dark fruit, molasses, spicy/phenolic, with some honey in the dry finish. This was a great dubbel.
330ml bottle. Poured a dark coppery brown with a tan creamy head. Burnt caramel aroma with a licorice aftertaste. Smooth and tasty - a good sipping beer to savour and enjoy.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2009 Bottle 33cl. Nice Dark amber colour beer, the head disappeard quickly. Taste is nice with deep malt flavour. The beginning smells as chocolate/malt with fruit / licorice aroma. The end is a bit astringent from typical trappist yeast very fruty, smell like an apple .

Bottle, 33cl -  Slightly hazy dark brown beer with a large beige head. Aroma is malty with notes of rye bread, yeast, dried fruits and nuts. Flavor is roasty malty with hints of nuts, banana esters and dried fruits. Aftertaste is dry, and bitter. Medium bodied soft beer.
golden-brown, caramel, nuts, alcohol, light sweetness, medium body, creamy,
(330 ml bottle) Head disappeared very quickly, even when drafted right. Deep aroma with a tangy taste. Palate is sour, bitter and sweet.

330ml bottle and 500ml bottle or crock. Filtered, then bottled with yeast and sugar.
First brewed in 1987.
Ingredients: Water, Barley malt, Hops, Yeast.
11.2 oz bottle.  in the states so its Koningshoeven trappist. dark with a nice head. rich, full body. will come back for more.
Appreance dark brown and a aroma of some fruits and yeast. It is a good beer, but not as complex..

# 999 
ersma: den holländischen trappisten habe ich mal als würdige nr. 999 auserkoren. 
dunkle, rubinrot-braune farbe. erstaunlich viel schaum für ein trappisten-bier, also mindestens ein halber mm. 
geruch ist süßlich-hefig, leicht säuerlich. aromen von schoko, kaffee, waldfrüchten und nelken. sehr komplex und intensiv. 
der antrunk ist sehr perlig. hefig mit deutlichem kaffee-aroma. dazu nouancen von kakao, röstmalz und ingwer (!). marginal nach alk. die mitte ist spritiger und herber. die 6,5 volt mag man dem bier nicht glauben. der abgang kommt deutlich röstmalzig, würzig, mit erdigen aromen. 
die flasche kommt mit trappisten-üblicher schlichtheit daher, ist gerade darum aber durchaus gelungen. nur das papier der etiketten wirkt etwas billig. 
fazit: ein lange gelagerter, ausgereifter trappist ist immer ein genuss. und dieses bier bildet da keine ausnahme. unbedingt probierenswert.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2009 341ml bottle. gets out of the bottle as soon as you open it. Be ready with your glass ! Pours dark brown with big brown head. Head sparkles and fades fast. Laces a bit on the glass. Nice aroma. Some sweetness, dark fruits and some nuts maybe. Roasted malt also. Quite discrete taste. A bit acidic and metallic. low carbonation. Quite nutty taste. It seems the last one was better than that. Still got 2 bottles, will revisit ! Rating #34 
Re-rate 090510. Aroma is quite sweet, alcohol, a bit vinous. Some not too dark/sweet fruits, cherries maybe. Taste is a bit discrete. Not metallic (only a small tiny hint maybe). Hints of cherries also. Medium carbonation. Aroma 7 to 8, Flavour 6 to 8, Overall 12 to 14. Nice beer !!

Unique tasting Trappist, the only of its kind of Dutch origin. The smoothest and sweetest of all Trappists, yet still packing enough character and dubbel oomph. My favourite, most of the time... Change with a regular pils or a Westmalle Dubbel in between to keep your palate appreciating its sweet strength ;)

(Bottle from Morrisons, Diss) Poured dark red with ltitle head. Aroma of sweet malt and red fruits. Taste of more caramel malt with red fruit, cherries and toast. Hint of vanilla and flowery hops. Clean tasting with a strong fruit backing, great and tasty but not the best of trappist beers Ive had.

33cl bottle into Trappist glass. A dark brown ale with a moderate beige head. Aromas of caramel malts with a hint of fresh cherries. Tastes fruity and malty with quite a sweet finish. Medium bodied with a smooth drinkability. Lacks the complexity of flavours I associate with other Trappist beers.

Bottle: A bit unclear, rather quickly vanishing off-white head, ruby-amber coloured; caramelly and toasty nose with a fruity background; moderate to solid bitter-sweet flavour, medium bodied. a distinctive fruity touch and traces of cacao in the drier bitter-sweet finish. Pleasant..........

Light brown creamy colour. Brown-mahogany colour. Aroma is malty, fruity with caramel, spicy and light alcohol notes. Flavor is malty too with dark fruits and light caramel tones, ending in a sweet candy finish. Medium to full bodied.
