Cloudy brown hue, with a tan-colored head, yeasty, fruity, raisiny, plummy nose, with a sweet chocolatey, winey, faint accent, with a hint of candi sugar, molasses, and some toasted, caramelized malt aromas follow though on a medium-bodied palate with a sweet toasty, caramel malt, fruity, chocolatey character, with some cookie dough, plummy, figgy, raisiny, datey flavors, with some toffeeish, caramel, molasses accents, leading towards a malty, fruity, raisiny, plummy, mild chocolatey finish.

Dark, mahogany red brown, a finger of smooth creamy tan head, plums and cherries.  Sweet but simple malt aroma, some dark candi sugar.  Taste is big bold prunes, sweet beet sugar, a light bittering and alcohol finish.  Straightforward but good.
Lacks hop, but not a bad dubbel. I thought they had lost their Trappist rating! I dont believe they can still call their beers Trappist beer.

[33cl bottle from Morrisons.] Reddish brown with a dense cream head, rather lively when first poured; rather sickly aroma, with caramel and yeast to the fore; really nice chewy malt flavours with lots of caramel and nuts and a trace of bubble gum; light fruity finish - not over sweet. Very pleasant apart from the aroma.
Dark Brown color with a rich creamy head. Medium bodied, sweet malty aroma with fruity and caramel hints. Fruity taste wih lots of yeast. Nice , slightly inferior to Westmalle Dubbel.
Bottle at home. One of the best beers Ive enjoyed recently. Very good oatmeal flavour, light taste, not too overwhelming.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2009 750 ml, thanks lithy. Dark brown with a lasting head and sugary lace. Aroma of brown sugar, spicy molasses, cocoa and light berry. Flavor is the same, but more so. Medium body is watery and finishes dryish.

Too red. This is lousy. Actually its not too bad. Once again smells like hard candy. Tastes like rancid hard candy. The only difference between this and their tripel is this is darker, less carbonated, and slightly better

Bottle. Pours dark brown/black with a large-ish tan head. Aroma and flavor are both mostly molasses (I think?), light fruits, slightly roasted malt, and hint of yeast. Not a bad dubbel, but not really among the best; could use more yeast and at least a hint of hops.
Dark maroon with explosive tan head.  Aroma of peanuts and malt.  Flavor of almonds, caramel and malt with a slight bitter finish.

[Eyes] Redbrown color, light carbonatiom, some yeast in liquid. good head! 

[Nouse] the aroma: brown sugar, banana and fruits. Smells amazing!.

[Mouth] Full and goood taste!!!. In deep i found yeast, vanilla? gentile bitterness and alcohol notes. Good belgian dubbel beer

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-23-2008 23:40:31

Ruby-brown beer with a small lacing beige head. Nice aroma of fruits(plum and dried fruits), caramel, a hint of alcohol. Medium body, fine liqueric and fruity flavors with roasted tastes. But i expected more from a trappist dubbel...
Color is ruby brown, with tan foamy head. nose is fruity. Flavour is sweet with fruits and raisins. Rlatively high carbonation and alcohol is not hidden. Forgettable for a trappist dubbel,

Pours a hazy orange with diminishing head. Sweet caramel aroma and also underlying fruity notes. Flavour is caramel, dark fruit (plums and raisins) and orange. Medium bodied and sweet, alcoholic finish.
This is a good Dubbel as it pours golden but has an aroma of several fruits, especially cherry.  This is more watery than expected, but still a great beer and worth trying.
Bottle.  My least favorite of the La Trappe offerings.  Pours an amber hazy body with a tan head.  Sweet caramel, and toasted grain, over ripe cherry and grape, candi sugar and subtle alcohol.
Tom entre o vermelho e o laranja, espuma densa. Sabor acentuado, ligeiramente adocicado.

Dark brown colored brew. Dark fruits and some sweetness in the aroma. Flavor of caramel, dark fruits, some burned malts, some sweetness. A bit too watery, could be thicker and have more strong flavors.

Shared with Pyrozoid.  Light cloudy copper poor with a thin beige head.  Aromas of dates, grapes, cherries, red wine vinegar and caramel.  Medium body, creamy, good balance between bitter and sweet.  Flavors of ripe dark fruits added cherries, candi sugar and nutty.  Classic dubbel.

Bouteille de 33 cl - Dégusté avec french tickler - Une biere de couleur rougatre-caramel avec aucun collet. Odeur d’alcohol, pommes, framboises et sucre. Gout tres sucré, pommes au gout également, prune mure.

(Bottle).  Aroma is yeasty and fruity.  Dark red body, light tan head.  Flavor is surprisingly somewhat bland for the style, though not unpleasant.  Ripe fruit, sweet, but a little watery.  Not much finish.
Reddy brown beer with large tan head. Caramel odour. Caramel, coffe, honey, cloves and toffee. Wonderful for the style.

Bottle pours opaque brown/red with very little white head. Aroma is nutty and some dark fruits. First taste is somewhat sweet with dark fruits being the main flavor then there is a nutty flavor present as well. The finish is clean with slight linger of sweetness and nuts. The alcohol is hidden very well.
bottle from total wine. reddish pour.  Small light head. Aroma is yeasty,syrup, honey, dark stone fruits.  Flavor is yeasty, sweet, raisins, alcohol.  Nice beer.

Bottle.  Pours dark hazy red with a minimal head.  Smells of fermented fruits, molasses, sweet.  Tastes of thick and dark fruits, cherries, plums, boysenberrys.  Some thick moasses flavor present, maybe some almond.  Pretty smooth.

Sample @ BBF 08, Boston.  Pours a hazy red with a small head.  Aroma is dark fruit, malt, and candi sugar.  Taste is the same, with noticeable plum and raisin going with the malt.  Very smooth, and a nice offering on the whole.  Glad I could try it.
Very nice, it smells like old things, which is good in this way. The aftertaste is ust wonderful, spicy and delightful.

Bottle 30cl.
Pours a murky ruby colour with a small head and almost no carbonation.
Smells fruity and sweet with also some hops and malts.
Taste is very warm and can taste raisins and some fruits in there vaguely.
Goes down very nice and warm with a good aftertaste and a warm feeling in the throat. Good Abbey dubbel.
Bottle, thanks ekstedt. Dark brown with an off-white head. Light, fruity aroma. Somewhat thin taste. Medium bodied.
Very malty, thick mouthfeel, nice and sweet, tastes like a nutty fig or raisin, delicious!

bottle.my second la trappe beer. im starting to like these abbey dubbels. pours dark ruby red with beige head wich quickly turns into a small foam. aroma is very strong and  impressive. taste is complex with sweet and bitter notes. still got some bottles left.
Smelt sweet. Colour of coke with a large of white head. Sweet and syrupy but not much flavour it was smooth and thick.

From the corked stone bottle.  Nicely packaged beer that doesn’t disappoint.  Pours a murky brown with a light tan head.  Smells wonderfull....spice, hops, cedar.   Tastes slightly sweet, really is nicely balanced with bitterness.  Excellent.
caramel, toast, brown, sparkling, tan foam, full body, average carbonation, long finish,
Stone bottle. Clear dark red-brown colour with almost no head. Ripe fruits aroma. Also fruits - maily raisins in taste - rather sweet. A bit alcoholic bitter aftertaste. Low carbonation.

(Draught at Old Bank, Turku, on 2008-08-29) Dark reddish brown. Clear. Hardly any head. Light malty nose. Full bodied palate with little carbonation. Chocolate, bitterness, fruitiness and slighty berry like flavours in taste.

500mL Bottle. Pours a red beer with a fast disappearing head. Aroma of spices, with yeast and malt. Sweet beer though most Dubbels are. Tastes similar to its aroma. Cherry-Fruit flavours evident. This Dubbel seemed lacking flavour and was short finishing compared to others. Perhaps I was too wowed with the bottle and expected more. Very drinkable though.
Like all trappist beers; this one is very flavourful and well balanced. Darker fruits (prunes, raisins), roasted malts, caramel, coffee. Finish is a tad bitter. Excellent

A little hazy ruby/brown colored beer, with a small beige head. The aroma of yeast and malts with some dark fruits. The taste of sweet caramel, with cherry fruits. A smooth and little thin beer. It’s not a bad beer at all.
Bottle. Pours very dark orange with a beige head. Aroma is fruity and yeasty. Flavor has apple, spice, and yeast. Nice.

Bottle, as Koningshoeven Dubbel.  Pours a reddish brown, with a thin tan head.  Faint aroma of sweet fruit.  Flavor is brown sugar, toffee, dark fruits, and a bit of yeasty tanginess.  Delicious.  A phenomenal Abbey Dubbel; I find its lukewarm rating to be quite puzzling.

Poured dark ruby with 2.5 cm dark tan head.

Aroma is "holy banana smell" with an addition of water pipes.  Which worked for me, to tell the truth.

The mouthfeel is slick with lower than average carbonation.

The taste is banana, toffee, cookie dough, with a touch of high alcohol warming.  The aftertaste is strong with unsweetened cocoa and grapefruit.

Awesome.

heavy aroma, cheese, dark fruits. dark brown small brown head, flavor dominated by dark fruits, raisins, booze.. glogg, christmas spices. palate is too watery, aftertaste is dominated by bitter alc, which draws down my overall rating.

bottle 33cl
Amberish/brown color with white head.
Aroma is earthly yeast and of dark fruits (cherry or prunes). Grains.
Taste is malty and fruity, lightly sugary and a little bitter/sour finish.
Well balanced beer, awesome flavors.

Pours fizzy with small, quickly dissipating tan head. Deep brown colour, aroma fruity, spicy and slightly woody. Flavour rich and sweet, some spiciness, very smooth. Palate slightly sticky, alcohol evident. Some bitterness on the finish. Nice dubbel.

Bottle @ home. Pours deep brownred, with a thin off-white head. Aroma of roasted malts, caramel, some alcohol. Taste is soft and subtle, with roasted malts, brown sugar and some raisin. Sweetness is balanced by a nice slightly bitter finish. Good dubbel.

The bottle pours deeeep cinnamon color with soft medium sized tan head that settles quickly. There is a sweet aroma of brown sugars, subtle roastyness, and syrupy fruits. Soft carbonation with sweet flavor and slight bitter bite. Just a little bit spicy. The finish is smooth with sugary retention. Good brew

Pours a brilliantly clear, deep crimson colour with a rocky tan head that retains very well. The nose is of aromatic, toffee-sweet malts and notes of honey and cherry. The flavour is earthy, yeasty (bubble-gum) and fruity, with plum and fig notes, light caramel sweetness, minerals, bubble-gum yeast, some dirty barnyard notes and some warmth from the alcohol. The mouthfeel is slick with a nice medium carbonation and a syrupy finish.

poors a brilliant dark brick color, very clear and carbonated. Poured a large head. aroma consists of very strong honey with hints of cherry and plums. Very smooth and pleasantly carbonated, Tastes contains hints of honey, fig, plum, and strawberry. a very good well made beer.

50cl Bottle. Short-lived, though effervescent and exuberant, head, and dark mahogany on the pour. Extremely appealing notes of honeyed-treacle to the nose, and similar on the palate with undertones of hops and yeast. Reassuring mouthfeel, with a profound morish quality. Very decent beer

Robust and luxurious head. Round presence and full mouthfeel. Carbonation is soft and pleasant. Not like a Unibroue fizziness. Very little heat. Not overtly malty and of course minimal to non-existent hoppiness. Less spicy and more thick than a Chimay Blue. That Belgian yeastiness is present throughout. Very enjoyable.
300 ml bottle. brown colour. creme head. smooth caramely tatste. not to alcoholic taste
Bottle.33cl. Clear brown ale with a creamy white head. Sweet caramel aroma with orange, nuts, and smooth alcohol.  Heavy aroma,
Bottle-Memphis. Poured a dark red with little head - the lack of carbonation was surprising - plummy nose and rummy finish.  enjoyable

pours a dark brown with lasting head.  alcohol is the first thing you smell when you put your nose in it.  there is also some molasses and yeast with some fermented fruit as well.  taste is of fermented fruit and yeast. not much alcohol taste which is nice since it is so strong in the scent.  overall, a very nice beer.

Pour was cloudy dark brown with a frothy tan head. Aroma is up front alcohol with caramel, malt, and strong fruit characters.  Flavors are well balanced of fruit, malt, slight hop characters, and more alcohol.  Carbonation is very full and pleasant.  alcohol is also noticable.  Good brew.  Would buy again.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2008 scura schiuma media piuttosto persistente note caramellate maltate tostato in bocca buon corpo malto e decisa tostatura caramello piuttosto aromatica
 dominus da 75  la schiuma e meno persistente stessi sentori un po più povera

(Bottle 33cl, SuperBest) Pours almost clear, mahogany color with a medium, mostly diminishing head. Earthy aroma with notes of prunes and alcohol. Sweet taste with hints of prunes and roasted malt. Medium bodied.

No 247
Rated: 07.11.2007
Bottle brown, 750 ml
Appearance: Head is huge, dark cappuccino like brownish - yellowish, pillowy, almost creamy head, dense, very frothy, body carbonation is rather soft, head is decreasing to a small froth so mostly diminishing but not rapidly, after some time. Body colour is natural rubby and texture is hazy to murky. lacing of the head is almost non - existant, very nice, juicy, fresh colour.
Aroma: Wet stone, earthy hops, barnyard, alcoholic nose, bananas, sweet fruityness, a hint of cherry, some plums, coffee, aroma has something heavy and unpleasant to me, i dont know exactly what it is but something barnyeard - old piss like or sweat, burned sugar, roastyness or at last toastyness, rather no wheat, some hints of malted barley, wine grapes, red wine.
Flavour: Yeasts and strawberry, caramell, burned sugar. brown sugar, cherry, plum, grainy, some alcohol warmth, malted barley&wheat, banana, bitterness, nice combination of hops and roastiness, full, rounded, nice taste, crispy, carbonation on palte is felt, finish duration is long, grapes, red wine, burned malted barley, generally flavour is more accidic, full and pronounced more than Val - Dieu because of strong cask wood notes. Body is full, like you would bite the grains, fruits, hops and cask wood.
Palate: Body is full, texture is syrupy, smooth, carbonation is soft on palate, cask wood is dominating with its accidity at the end.

Bottled. Pours dark amber with a light brown head that almost forms a thin dirty yellow line where the head meets the beer. Aroma is malty, bread, belgian yeast, and some sweet bubble gum notes that remind me of Crest Sparkle toothpaste. Flavor is sweet belgian yeast with a hint of bubble gum, and some dark fruits. Very smooth with a good mid ranged body.

Appearance: Very dark brown. Nice head.
Aroma: Malty, fruity.
Taste: Malty, fruity. Smooth.
Info: 330ml bottle, 16/2-2006, 75/300

Very active aroma with a charcoal traces. Good lasting head  and a really nice color. The taste is present for quite a while and is bitter, sour and a little salty. Has a oily texture and a lively carbonation. You can feel a metallic taste in your mouth.
A brown little reddish coloured beer with small off white head. Malty yeasty aroma. Full little sweet palate. Ending is bitter, herby and dry.
UPDATED: SEP 2, 2012 dark brown amber coloured body with a off white head a fruity malty roasted aroma a spicy malty caramel fruity sweet  taste with a sweet  bitter finish

Incredibel taste, roaster barley malts and a bit herbal hit at the end. aroma is scarce, and appearance does not fit with a good trapist, is too much carbonated and the foam quicky disapear, leaving a simple liquid in the glas, however flavor is great.

This dark brown ale poured with a thin brown head. There is an initial deep caramel malt flavor that belies the complexity to follow as the beer warms. The spices and fruit flavors become evident, along with a carbonated mouthfeel. It is a bit light for a dubbel, but is also more refreshing, as the commercial description indicates.

750ml bottle from Willow Bend Liquors (Tampa). Pours dark brown with a one finger tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty, with notes of caramel, toffee and hints of molasses. Flavor is sweet, malty, earthy, robust, faintness hint of chocolate as well.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2009 Dark ruby, beige lacing head. Nose is peppery spices, little fruits, cellar, cheese and vegetables. Flavor is a tad sweeter with spices and slight liquorice. Ashy and syrupy  finish, some dark malts. Light palate for the style. Its ok, but lacking in every aspect.  
*Aged (bbe 01-2009) bottle has sweet madeira fruitiness, little cheese and butter. Candi sugar shows quite a lot, but nothing disturbing, no nasties. Still pretty mild, and still just ok.

11.2 oz bottle poured into trappist glass- poured 15% transparent when held to a light source, brownish black color, high-medium carbonation.  Off tan head bubbled away rather quickly.  Aroma of figs, darkened malt, caramel, and chocolate.  HIts the mouth with a medium body, very dry from start to finish, the heavier smells come through sharply on the palate, sweetness and a sharp varnish like taste come in on the finish.  Very complex, but that takes away from the overall taste in my opinion- too many things going on leads to chaos and distracts from actually enjoying a brew.

33 cl bottle from Berlin: Gushed out of the bottle when I opened it. Pours cola brown with a thick fading beige head. Big caramel, varnish, dark fruit aroma. Taste is pretty dry considering. I thought it would have been sweeter. Big alcohol, varnish, caramel, raisins, figs. Good beer.

25/05  0.33 l bottle from belgianshop.com. Had nice murky copper brown body with medium sized, long living brownish head. Quite ugly aroma, some roasted malts combined with note of saltiness, but not nearly as much as in Wit from same brewery. Flavor a bit better, sweetish caramel, however notes of that salt spoil the entirety. Also, its pretty thin bodied,  finishing very simple and short as mixture of sweetness and saltiness.  Different dubbel for sure, but still dont like it as not quite well made.

Bottle shared with and courtesy of heavy (thanks!) The Blond and the Trippel have been available in Croatia for years now but their dark cousins have always been mysteriously absent (the Dubbel might have once been imported but it definitely hasnt been imported recently). So, it was interesting to try those two. This one poured a nice red brown body with a thick off white head that went away slowly. The nose was pretty straightforward but somehow not easy to define. a maltiness that falls somewhere between caramel croquant and orange and some salt. The taste was somewhat simple and lighter than expected but well put together. A sweet breadiness and maltiness, caramel, some salt a but herbal something too... ugh.. my notes are becoming unreadable. All in all, I didnt mind it much.

Bottle: dark red color with tan head.  Slight aroma of brown sugar, carmel and molasses.  Wonderful smooth malty taste with thick but subtle sweetness of carmel and brown sugar.  I love beers like these.

Pours a clear amber-brown with a foamy tan head that recedes slowly and leaves some nice lacing.  Very light aroma of malt, yeast and fruit, but with some weird metallic thing going on.  Fortunately, that did not come through at all in the flavor.  Lots of malty sweetness with friuty overtones and a bitterness at the end.  Pretty good stuff.
Bottle: Floral, compex body and taste. Matly with a nice background sweetness. Bready and doughlike.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2008 Sampled at the fête de la bière in Martigny, Switzerland. It pours a dark ruby beer with a mocha head. The nose shows a burnt component. Hints of banana, white pepper and yeast. Rather strong. Some glue and manure appearing - a dissapointing aroma. The taste is of alcohol, burnt plastic and malt. No subtle components. Hints of banana and white pepper. Sweet and full bodied. Malty finish with hints of mint and burnt plastic. A very dissapointing dubbel.

0.5l crock.  Pours with an average head, deep brown with a little red.  Not really full bodied or thin, somewhere inbetween.

Nice fruity dark ale, with a nice sweetness and pleasant after taste.  Not bad at all.

330ml draught 
6.5% ABV 
I tried this beer on May 9, 2008 at "Smokeless Joes" in Toronto, Ontario on tap.  The beer was a beautiful dark brown with some plum coloured hints and a thin, rocky, tan coloured head.  The aroma was sweet malt, with some yeasty tones, as well as chocolate and cherry hints.  The mouthfeel was medium bodied, mildly carbonated, and slightly creamy.  The flavour was caramel malt, some other fruit flavours like cherries and plum, and a little hoppish bitterness to round it out.  I loved this beer.
Bottle: Floral, compex body and taste. Matly with a nice background sweetness. Bready and doughlike.
Thanks to ghawener.  Drank it at pollos house.  Pours  dark amber, creamy head.  Medium bodied, malty, bit sweet like cherries, dry finish.
Mine was the Dominus Double 0.7l bottle in Spain Madrid. Dark brown red with medium head. very good and complex. Sweet cherry and a bit sour. a hint of chocolate and many other things I cant name...
Ruby with a creamy, off-white head. Cherry and nutty tones. Fruit, malt and caramel in the mouth. Medium to full body with a balanced finish.

Pours an almost opaque dark red with a moderately thick head even after a gentle pour.  However, the head quickly dissipates and has very little lacing.  The aroma is sweet, with notes of caramel malt and dried fruit.  Taste is similar with sweet caramel notes and flavors of dried cherries.  Unfortunately, the alcohol doesnt seem to blend well with the other flavors and it leaves a decidedly alcoholic aftertaste.  A good beer overall, but not a great dubbel.

11.2 ounce bottle in generic goblet.  Dark reddish brown with lasting flat head and lace.  Dark candy sugar, raisin, and bread aroma.  Brown sugar, toasted caramel, and raisin sweetness, fruity, medium tobacco bitterness, lingering sweetness.  Medium body and carbo.  Pretty nice.

0.33 l bottle. Ruby color with fluffy fading head. Sweetish aroma with chocolate, licorice, caramel and hint of dark fruits. Sweetish toasty flavor with chocolate, licorice and caramel. Smooth beer with no depth.

Had tried this before in a bottle and recall being underwhelmed, so thought Id try this from the crock !
 Pours a dark brown with a tan head that completely vanished. Sweet, vaguely spicy aroma. Flavour more of the same with some fruit and nutiness present and a slightly bitter sweet finish. Lacking in any real character though, and again disappointed by this. 
Not a good dubbel.

Koningshoeven is one of the Trappist Breweries, so you can be assured of a certain critical level of quality and respectability. It certainly brings that, as well as an intangible pleasantness and cerevisial happiness. Its a quiet Trappist, but thats a point in its favor as far as Im concerned.

Served in its own goblet.
Caramelly brown -- quite pretty to look at. 
Pleasantly sweet -- never cloying, just the right amount of sweetness for a Dubbel.
At 6.5% ABV, its not so rigorous on the gullet, although Ive never tried multiple servings in one go. 

To sum it all up, a quote from the Missus: "Its like a hug in a bottle."

Bottle at Le Bistro des Bieres Belge. The color is dark reddish with a dark beige head. The aroma and flavor are of sweet fruits and caramel added. It has a nice sour finish to it that makes it very pleasant.
dark mohagany appearance with strong white head.  flavor of some dark candy sugar but finishes with a grape-like winey characteristic.  not gret depth, could benefit from more alcohol

Bottle (330ml). Poured a very deep ruby brown (almost black) with a large, fluffy, tanned head which was mostly lasting. Aroma was of sweet caramel malts with sweet dates, raisins with some Cadburys Curly Wurly chocolate. Flavor was a mild bitterness with sweet toffee malts, raisins, dates, chocolate (mild) with a light peppery finish. Hide its alcohol content very well. Medium bodied with medium carbonation, syrupy texture, dry mouthfeel and a good finish.

Pours dark brown, opaque with an obnoxious amount of foam. Settles down to a 1 inch light tan head. Aroma of dull darker malts, grape and plum.  Tastes like smooth rich malt, nuts, hops, and dark fruit sugars. A little burn going down. Mouthfeel is medium, and a little thick but not too much.  It has a good bite. Finish is a little heavy.

Dark ruby with a dense head. Caramel, toffee, chocolate, and biscuits dominates this very nice dubbel. A very lively mouthfeel with a lot of tingling carbonation makes this one of the better dubbels Ive tasted.

Bottle - 330ml. Pours a dark amber/brown hazy body with a thin off-white foamy head. its well balanced malty/hoppy aroma carries sweet and fruity hints. Taste hides the alcohol pretty well. Ends with a long bittersweet finish. Good Dubbel.

BOTTLE: Koningshoeven Dubbel, nice tan head.  Floral aroma, slight lacing.  Flavor is nice, not overly sweet, a hint of vanilla at the back of the tongue.  Palate is not overwhelming, somewhat bubbly but short finish.  Nice beer but clearly not one of the best trappists.
Bottle at Rhino, westend Toronto. Dark Brown with cream head. Fruity yeast aroma. Bubbly caramel taste, not as sweet or refined as Quad.

Rate from May 07Bottle from Tesco. Dark brown, thin tan head. Candy sweet aroma of brown sugar and malts. Taste to match, with a touch of spice. Dusty finish of spice and alcohol. Odd waxy mouthfeel. Good, but theres something amiss.

Dark, dark copper... less pear and apple, than the blonde, less oily as well. Much milder though, as both the Blonde and the Dubbel seem to lack "fizz" or bite as say an Orval or Chimay which Ive been led to believe was a cousin. ANyhow, this beer was generally pleasant to drink, but Im still struggling on what food I could pair this with properly. It has the taste of the apple between the skin and the tougher part, namely where it ripens first. Huge head when poured delicately, although dissipates quickly. (Bottle Pour 3/29/2008)
Dark brown beer, small head. Fruity, yeasty and a bit chocolaty aroma. Good sourrish and sweetish taste with raisins, figs and some chocolate. Bitterish finish, nicely balanced.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2009 33cl bottle from Systembolaget. Pours a dark brown, almost black color with a suprisingly small light-brown head that vanished fast in the glass. The aroma is sweet with notes of bananas, raisins, and hints of sugar. The flavor is fruity with notes of bananas, apples, raisins, yeast and malts. The aftertaste is quite short.
Bottle. Red brown with firm mocha head. Dark fruit, raisin and malt. Medium body.  Sweet finish. Overall a nice dubbel.

Not a bad dubbel at all. Pours a light mahogany color with a medium sized tope head. Nose is of dark fruit and malt and sugar. Taste is green apples dark fruit and sugar. Very crisp and clean. I like it.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2008 Clear(ish) red pour with a thick round of head. Decent retention, nice hue, but no lace. Aroma of mashed-up cherries and baby powder. Flavors are largely cherry but with a solid malt backbone and an off-dry, tart, slightly hoppy, overipe fruit finish. Its at least semi-filtered so none of the thickness or depth that might make it marvelous but is still a decent drinkable Dutch dubbel.  vintage version from around 1999 or 2000, aged about 8 years has a nice sweetness...
UPDATED: MAR 3, 2008 No head misty red/brown pour,good carbonation,aroma spicey,plum,raisins,flavour malt,raisins,plum,good mellowness to this drink.Finish is sweet and mellow.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2008 This pours really well, a dark amber with a ridiculously thick orangish so I was really looking forward to good things.  It just doesnt live up to it.  Its a bit tart and unbalanced and the palate is oddly watery considering the thickness of its head.  Certainly drinkable but I wont go out of my way for it.

Bottled purchased in Fairfield, CT under the name Konings and directed here. Pours a very dark amber color with a small swirling head. Appears to even be some very some particles in there. Smells of alcohol in a very strong way in the beginning. I think I should have stored it for a bit to age it - I feel it would have been better. I also let it warm a bit and it brought out a much better aroma and taste on the palate. Certainly getting a little fruit on first taste with banana seeming to come out. Really? the beer got better and better as I went on drinking it. Finished very nice though a bit bitter and sour.
Bottle 30CL Nice beer, red colored, nice trappist beer. Very refreshing :)

Sampled as a bottle of Koningshoeven Dubbel.  This dubbel once poured was hard to put down.  Flavors of caramel, fruit, oak, and strong alcohol undertone.  Held up well on the trip from Holland, and I even gave it a few months cellaring for good measure.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2008   Bottle picked up from Morrisons, 11-02-08   Pours very red in colour it actually looks like the colour of old blood. Some sweet toffee banana chewy sweet flavours, nice soft carbonation, lovely dark fruits and dried fruits, spicy on the nose, quite smooth the alcohol is there but never intrudes, I really liked this beer.   Had this again 23-03-08 Many thanks to Barry for providing this beer   Warm nutty aroma, dark/reddy brown with beige head, molassess, marzipan, oft sweet banana again and another solid   3.7

Bottle.  Pours brown leaning towards the red and quite hazy.  thick beige foam dissipates quickly.  Aroma, Banana, caramel and brown sugar, and dark fruits with some hops in the background.  Flavor is earth with some dark fruits, and some hops trying to peak through.  Finish is dry.  For a 7% this is hidden so well you dont even feel the warmth.  Not bad, but definately not my favorite trappist by a lond shot.

Bottle- Pours a murky brown liquid, with a dense beige foam. Brown sugar, dark fruit, caramel malts, and candied fruit fill the nose, and are backed up with some leafy hops. Flavour profile is figs/prunes with caramelized fruit and bready rye sweetness. The hops are here and are subdued, allowing more sweetness to come out, but it finishes drier than expected. No detection of the alcohol in this dubbel. Bottle at Chaucers Pub.

A hazy dark brown beer white a rich beige head. Aroma is very yeasty and fruity, notes of coffee. Taste is also very fruity, notes of bitter chocolate, roasted malt. Spicy and dry end. Lively and warm mouthfeel.

Konings Hoeven Dubbel Trappist 33 cl. bottle...Pours a crimson-brown (if that makes any sense) with a light-brown head that quickly fades. Heavy fruit, caramel, and malt nose...Got raisins, & candied fruit on the flavor w/ a touch of bitterness/bite at the back of the palate. Good solid dubbel...

Pours a deep brown with amber hightlights and a thick beige head.  Aroma is of bananas flambe.  Also has a light smokiness.  The taste is fruity with banana again but also raisins and figs.  Some chocolate as well.

This is very dark, slightly brownish red with a big, dense lasting tan head that dissipates to a thin foamy head but leaves no lace.  The aroma is dark, burnt caramel, wheat bread, leaves, and a hint of pears.  The taste is sweet at first, gradually becoming more bitter near the finish, burnt caramel, raisins, brown bread, with an aclholic quality.  It is reminiscent of a lighter, more burnt-bitter relative of barleywine, while being less rich and oily.  Its nice and interesting yet pretty easy to drink.

Pours a dark purplish-crimson color with a medium sized, foamy, light tan head.  The foam settles to a thin film, with a quick swirl yielding nothing but runny, sudsy legs that rejoin the body.  The aroma is fruity and malty, with dried figs, plums, and dark berries showing atop notes of toasted caramel and light candied sugar.  The flavor is quite a bit drier than I expected, with dehydrated fruits playing a huge role.  Figs and plums again assert themselves, while caramel malts play more of a background role.  A trace amount of fumy vanilla vodka is preset deep within this one.  Medium bodied, this one is quite sharp on the roof of the mouth, finishing kind of sour.  Not bad, but nothing special either.

Poured a nice brown color with a small head that faded into lasting lacing.  Smell was very fruity up front.  Taste was smooth, light fruit, hints of yeast.  Nice drinkable trappist, not the best belgian but certainly not the worst.
Bottled - koenigs hoeven. A pretty good dubbel that had a sweet taste and a shiny reddish color, actually probably one of the few good dutch-made beers Ive ever had.
Medium hoppy aroma.  Large creamy, lt brown head.  dark red colour.  lt sweet/bitter flavour.  Light alcoholic/syrup palate.

Excellent dubbel!  I brought a bottle back from Belgium and waited until today to drink it.  I should have brought more.  Although it is Dutch, it still has all of the flavor and character of a trappist dubbel.

Bottle.  Koningshoeven label.  Brown pour with garnet highlights.  Frothy, ivory head.  Dark fruit and malt nose with an almost sourdough-like yeast note.  Creamy and sweet mouth feel with very little flavor.. There is a bit of dark fruit as well as a nice yeast note but it comes across as watered down.  Bummer.
Very rich flavor with hints of sweetness, but still quite dry on the finish.  Bit like a drier birch syrup flavor.

33 cl. bottle. Pours a clear garnet hue with a thick tan head. Sweet, maple syrup, vanilla almond smell. Medium bodied with decent carbonation. 
Taste is rich, malty with dates, figs, and maple syrup. Alcohol taste is in the background. Hop flavor is absent. 
A great dubble here.Feb 2005
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Konings 7% bottle - nice deep mahogany brown. Fruity aroma, not strong. Tastes fruity and very yeasty, maybe some bitter hop. Very mouth filling feeling, a sweet harsh feeling going  down. Dry, fizzy, slightly sweet finish. An ok beer, but only average for a Trappist.
Dark brown, with a brown tinted head that dissipates quickly. Thin body. Metallic aroma. Tastes smooth with fruit and not much yeast. Slight bitter end.
UPDATED: FEB 22, 2008 Dark brown with a nice creamy head. Thin bodied beer. Taste is of black cherry almost. Very delicious.

It pours a cloudy dark brown color with a medium sized beige and creamy head. Rich aroma of plum, black cherry, orange, caramel and dark chocolate. Very sweet flavor with a mild bitterness, almost no track of yeast. Bitter finish. This could be better if it was more refreshing, but its not, as you dont have to drink it that cold.
Dark brown with medium creamy head. Aroma is malty with overripe fruits and yeast. Sweet flavor with roasted malt, toffee and fruits. Finishes with little bitternes.

Bottle: Cola in color, large rocky off-white head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Soft bready nose, minor dark pitted fruit, yeasty, smells 

like a Koningshoeven. &nbsp Semi-sweet, bready, very soft dark pitted fruit. &nbsp Not as heavy as many other examples, and in fact its a 

little on the milder side. &nbsp Very fleeting, finishes very quickly. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate at best. &nbsp Good start, but 

falls off rather quickly. &nbsp Finishes clean, very minor breadiness and dark pitted fruit. &nbsp Good, but on the lighter side.
As Koningshoeven Dubbel Trappist Ale.  11.2 oz bottle.  Pours a dark ruby color. Aroma of malts and earth   Flavors are spice, raisns, grape marked by some alcohol.
pours a clear brown with mild head.  sweet fruity raisin aroma.  sweet fruity raisin/plum front with a mild finish.  mild aftertaste.  good light water palate.

11.2oz bottle, courtesy of Degarth. Has the Koningshoeven label. First thing noticeable upon pouring is a huge, rocky light tan head, with exceptional retention and lacing. A never ending layer of foam sits atop the beer when things are all said and done.  Body is a rich maroon color that is nearly opaque. Nose contains fruity esters - plums, dates, raisins, figs, juniper berries - yeast, peppery spices and some earthiness. Also pick up some floral hints at the very edges of the aroma. Fore is very red wine like, peppery spice, tons of dark fruits and berries, with a constant backing from the yeast and a nice sense of biscuit or bread dough. Medium bodied, perfect mouthfeel for the style. Slight astringency. This one was very fun and interesting to drink, nothing spectacular but very solid and knows what it wants to be. One of those beers that feels very solid when you are drinking it, but the rating turns out much higher than it seems since the sum is greater than the parts. Finish is medium length, very juicy, fruits and yeast running all the way through, finishing with a nice drying kick to carry things to the end.

Essa cerveja trapista escura tem uma espuma cremosa, marrom-clara e com duração relativamente longa. Seu corpo tem transparência normal, sua densidade é fina e sua coloração, marrom. Com aromas complexos, apresenta nuances de caramelo, notas cítricas (puxando para a laranja), terra e maçã. No primeiro gole já se percebe um forte amargor, que envolve a língua com um corpo médio e uma textura oleosa, permeada com uma carbonatação ativa. No final, o sabor torna-se levemente adocicado e depois metálico. Apesar da miríade de características, a Dubbel peca por tornar-se enjoativa devido às suas características
Amazing as a draft but I will review the bottle.  Good overall balance, fresh taste, a bit too carbonated.  The biggest drawback was the $6.70 price for 16 oz!

bouteille brune de 11,2oz, bue dans un verre La trappe

belle bière brune avec léger reflet rouge, très effervescente la mousse brune a disparu très rapidement, nez frais de caramel, de malt, la bouche est ronde, un pointe dalcool, une touche épicé, rafraichissante et très agréable.

pours a dark ruby/ brown with a bthin beige head that quickly dissolves into a lacing that lasts throughout.  Aroma of dark berries, roasted malt, yeast and alcohol.  High carbonation up front that loses its intensity as the beer wamrs up.  Sweet hints of raisin, plum, grape, black cherries and malty chocolate/caramel  with a slightly dry finish..

750ml bottle with English label: Konings hoeven Dubble Trappist Ale. Dense dark brown color with a slight tan head. Intense malty, estery aroma. Big body with a full mouthfeel. Raisiny/molasses character. Nice even dry/sweet malty flavor balance, lacks complex yeasty notes of other Belgians. Dry finish. Very nice flavor.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours a clear purple with a medium greyish head and a fruity, yeasty nose. Taste is pretty sweet, caramel, raisin,brown sugar and alcohol. Nice long bitter finish. A decent dubbel, but not the best
[Sampled in 2003.] Indeed a nice dutch beer with notes similar to other belgo-dubbels, but lacks in intensity of flavor compared to them. But always worth to sample!

The Koningshoeven is a testament to the rich elegance found in well brewed beers.  The price may make your wallet shiver, but your tongue will adore you for it.  An appetizing fragrance of banana, vanilla and custard takes an inconoclastic stand against "dessert first" intoxicating the drinker with a strong breeze of sweet scents.  This is accompanied by a healthier celery shine, though it too is ultimately drowned in a delicious spate of chocolate and heavy cream aromatics.  As the beer vents its aroma from the muddy brown liquor through the thick, dark beige cap, enticing and inviting, I cant help but plow my lip into the head like a snow plow in a flash blizzard, piling up a mound of thick foam and taste sensations on my lip and tongue.  Respectively.  The sip begins with a trickle of banana and chocolate, evocative of a banana split sunday, before the fruity esters subside into ignominy.  After this sweet prompting, the chocolate persists with a new inkling of malts to further darken the quickly deepening taste.  Then the flavor resurfaces back into a lighter, fruitier stage, marked most curiously by the taste of artichoke hearts and a chalky palate, only to lightly land on a soft, pensive yet decadent chocolate aftertase, running with rivulets of deep, dark sweet flavor.  Permeating through the whole flavor storyline is a stalking and quiet hint of hazelnut which, interwined with the chocolate and sporadic fruit flavors is a wonderful flavor adhesive.  All of this rests on a blithe palate, light and carefree despite the rich flavors.  A contradiction, perhaps, but as such also mystifying.

Least favorite of the Trappist beers. Definitely an oak taste that may be appreciated by wine lovers. The aroma is great with a hint of banannas. Good color. Poors with a 1 finger head that reduces quickly leaving a lace along the sides of the glass.

Bottled (7% ABV). A hazy dark brown beer with a disappearing creamy light brown head. The aroma is fruity with mainly notes of plums and some light touches of chocolate. Rather malty. The flavour begins sweet and finishes with a moderate bitterness. Fruits, chocolate and light coffee are detectable. Good mouthfeel, medium body, average carbonation, light acidity, quite long aftertaste. There is something missing (maybe some hops?) to be really a great beer,but at the end is enjoyable.

(Bottle, Monks Café, Stockholm) Dark reddish brown colour with creamy, pale brown head. Fruity, malty nose with notes of caramel, marzipan, chocolate and underlying notes of coffee and moccha. Malty taste with marzipan, toffee, chocolate and fresh notes of coffee and slightly spicy hops. Elegant beer with superb balance.

33 cL bottle. Pours hazzlenut brown with a golden hue and a collapsing orange/brown head. Aroma is sweet caramel malty with a mild underlying fruityness and a minor yeast note. Mouthfeel is only mildly carbonated. Flavour starts sweet with clear caramel malt notes but quickly turn into a more fruity sweetness. Along the way a note of nuts and dried fruit can be sensed before the beer descends into a soft malty finish with a mild bitterness and a bite from the yeasty spice notes.
Bottle. Pours a hazy ruby with thin head. Dark cherry aroma and flavour. Sweet full-bodied finish.
Very sweet overall.  Some nice dark fruits and dried cherries.  Earthy and yeasty.
Without that strong aroma that Belgian Trappists have, this beer has a bit of a sweetness to it. It is softer than Belgians. Good, but not my favorite Trappist.

Had on 7/29/2007.  Labeled as Koningshoeven.  Aroma is a spicy scent with a nice sweet caramel back tone.  Color is a rich amber with very good carbonation and a thick tight head.  Taste is light yet sweet.  Starting with a light/medium body it goes down smooth with a fluffy feel.  Finish comes on with easy sweet malt flavor that has good tones of Belgian yeast, then a gentle bitterness that leads to a somewhat dry yet mildly sweet end and after taste.  This is not the best Dubbel I have had but still a beautiful beer.

Nose of malt, bread and dates. Pours a nice reddish brown/mahogany translucent beer. Decent carbonation. Mouthfeel is soft, sticky and malty. Taste is sweet with notes of fruits and malt dominant. Nicely spiced. Taste finishes with a roastedness and some alcohol intrusion. A good beer.
Cerveja trapista - minha primeira. Coloração rubro escura, quase preta. Espuma densa, caramelo. Cheiro caramelizado, suave - bom. Gaseificada. Retrogosto amargo. Sabor caramelo gostoso.
Bottle @ Gollem, Amsterdam. Reddish brown color. Rather weak in the body as weel as taste. Bit watery. Aromas are all there but just lacking.

Nice looking opaque chestnut with a good cream head, leaves good lacing.   Smells like dough with some sweet citrus thrown in.   Flavors arent as rich as other dubbels, and the body is a bit too thin as well.   Nice balance, but nothing really good going for it besides a nice appearance.

Well lookie here. I found me a "La Trappe" dubbel. My understanding is that the La Trappe is the old label of what is now the Koningshoeven line. Either way...onward! 

Pours an extemely dark ruby brown with minimal head after a minute. The nose smells like my mothers chocolate chip cookies. Touch of cherries. Sugar is there, but that is part of mommas chocolate chip cookies. Malty subdued flavor that has a caramelized sugar edge to it. Seems to be lacjing something. Perhaps this bottle is beyond its life. Feel is thin to standard. Not all the way bubbly, but still seems to be missing something. Drinkable I guess. I am wondering if this bottle is too old.
Dark sour appple with a bit of bite in the nose. Taste is similar but acidic and jumps on the tongue. Sticky medium-full palate.  Minor underlying alcohol throughout did not distract. Very good beer.

Deep ruddy brown, dark and hard to see through.  Sweet pruney malt.  Dark malt, but not roasty and barely any chocolate.  A bit of astringency?  Creamy soft relatively highly carbonated a bit thicker than average.  Roast comes out in the flavor more.  Pruney swetness.  Diacetyl, a bit of alcohol, a bit of acidity.  Lingering prunes and roasty astringency.  Not great, but okay.
Dark brown beer with thin but durable beige head. Slightly sweet aroma and not very typical . In the flavour sweetness is gone and there are roasted flavours. This is more porter than trapist?

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2016 Deep copper tinted brown beer with a medium white head. Aroma is yeasty, with plenty of fruit. The flavor was moderately sweet, lightly acidic and lightly bitter with a long, lightly sweet, lightly acidic/tangy finish. Medium to heavy palate.

This Abbey dubbel pours a deep reddish color from a 33cl bottle. Large sized beige foamy head, with good retention and nice lacing. Aroma is malty, brown sugar, dark fruits and sweet. A medium bodied dubbel. The malts are fruity and sweet, touch of sherry and port. The hops are earthy and mild. Lively carbonation. Lots of malt sweetness and some chocolate. Kind of one dimensional. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and sweet. Aftertaste is sweet.

Bottle labeled "Koningshoeven Dubbel Trappist Ale". Beer poured with absolutely no head whatsoever (okay, maybe a wee little bit)...very little lacing. Smell was winey with alcohol present. Taste was atypical of other dubbels Ive had...VERY winey taste with apple/cherry undertones. This beer is a "wannabe" as someone called it below. Very unimpressive.
Bottle 330ml. Brown color with a nice beige foamy. Aroma is roasted malt, some chocolatte notes. Flavor is roasted malt, sweety and a little bitter. Mouthfeel is roasted malty.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2009 
Name: La Trappe Dubbel
Date: December 01, 1997
Mode: Draft
Source: Taco Mac, Sandy Springs
Appearance: dark cloudy amber, good light tan head
Aroma: sweet malt aroma with a touch of floral hops
Flavor: rich malty flavor, slight fruity character, lots of candy sweetness, touch of bitterness, hint of tartness, goes through stages as it warms

Name: Koenigshoeven Dubbel
Date: April 20, 2005
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting
Appearance: opaque brown, thin tan head
Aroma: sweet dark candy malt aroma
Flavor: rich malt flavor, touch of spices, hint of chocolate, a slice of fig, tasty

Name: La Trappe Dubbel
Date: August 10, 2006
Source: Wild Wing, Marietta, tasting
opaque brown, big creamy tan head, lots of bready yeasty character in the final pour from the bottle, unchanged from 97

Name: La Trappe Dubbel
Date: August 11, 2006
Mode: bottle
Words: aged
Aroma: smokey oxidized dark fruit aroma
Flavor: nice chocolate flavor, light sweet fruity flavor, the fruit comes out better after a couple of years

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.7/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: **4

Name: Koenigshoeven Dubbel
Date: January 02, 2009
Mode: bottle
Source: tasting
Aroma: sweet and fruity aroma, dark caramel with a touch of chocolate, nice fruity esters
Flavor: rich and fruity flavor, lots of sweet esters, touch of chocolate, light spicyness, nice dark fruits

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Ove
Pored dark brown with a touch of red. More Syruppy and less carbonated than other Dubels Ive tried. Nice

750mL bottle, no date.   Clear ruby with a 2 1/2 finger fairly creamy lasting beige head.  This isnt as dark as most dubbels Ive come across.  Powdered sugared raisins, brown sugar, and scorched caramel are the most up front.  There is also some light roasted malts and Belgian yeast.  Flavor has the addition of hazelnut and some slight acidic tang from maybe some grape characteristics.  Dry finish.  Fairly smooth medium body with moderate carbonation.  I enjoyed this more than the tripel--quite nice.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Draft...a rich brown ale with an apple-like aftertaste. There are some sour flavors to go along with the sweet. Carbonation less than what Im used to with this style. Overall not bad, but not my favorite Abbey Dubbel.

Pours a dark copper color with an off-white head.  Aroma is of plums, toffee, caramel, and molasses.  Not as strong as Im used to with the style.  Flavors are pretty much the same with the dark fruits, toffee, molasses, and carmel being the stronger flavors.  Pretty good but there are better beers from this style.
Nice dark color with a fruity aroma of plums... very rich taste with hints of chocolate and berries ... smooth and hides the alcohol well....

Pour is a dark red with a average tan head.  Aroma is nice dark malts and some yeast with some alcohol showing up.  Flavor is a touch of dark fruits and molasses with some toffee.  Finish is kinda watery though.  An ok rep of the style and what i would consider a starter beer for those new to the style.

Pours mahogany with a deep red hue and tight light tan head.  The aroma is light with some dark bready malt and light yeast, and thats it.  Medium body that starts smooth and rich and gets thinner with lively carbonation.  The taste is very subdued for a dubbel with some toffee and toasted malt with a bit of earthy yeast.  The finish has some sharp sour traits.  This is very mellow and unassertive for the style.  Fair example.

330 mL bottle.  Translucent ruby brown with a very acceptable head.  Aroma is plums & raisins, roast malt, and spice.  Taste is similar, with the addition of caramel and black coffee.  Alcohol is well hidden, and the beer is nicely carbonated.  Smooth and full.  A good one.

Dark browish/red with a tan head.  This smells excellent, like ripe dried fruits (dates, cherries & raisins).  The tast on the otherhand is quote dry and I noticed hints of tobacco.  This was yesty spicey and malty, with a roasted aftertaste.  I sampled this in a 750ml, Koningshoeven bottle.

pured ruby brown with a decent head. nice malty, bready aroma. chewy malt and yeast flavors. some sweetness with a hint of hop citrus.  alcohol is barely noticeable. medium to full mouthfel in that it was slightly thick and syrupy. very nice dubbel.

330 ml bottle. Copper colour with a red hue. Crystal clear. Throws a really tall off-white creamy head that clings to the glass. There is obviously a lot of carbonation. Crispy dry yeast aroma, which indicates that the beer has a fairly low final gravity. Belgian malt character. Dry and not really much body, except that there is a little sugary malt flavours left. Syrupy aftertaste. Hops are there but they are very subdued. Could have used a little more body.

Bottle, 7%, Pasteurised/Filtered
Deep brown with ruby highlights, veracious carbonation and tan head. Aromas of thick sweet dark malts, with some dark stewed or dried plum and stewed rhubarb? Falvours are intense sweet light malts, with a hint of roastiness/hop bitterness midpalate. Pretty damn good really.

Dark ruby red body, with a thin layer of creamy tan foam. The foam lasts the entire beer even though it gets little thinner.
Aroma is mostly of fruity, plum not much more but nice.
Flavor of fruit plum and som woody notes.Not really an hopprecens but nice anyway
Palate is very warming and thin but creamy.

Pours an amber-brown with a small ring of foam and minimal lace. Very metallic aroma, sweet with no detectable hops. Tastes very watery and sweet, with a hint of light cherry soda pop. Some sweet teryaki, definitely munich malt in there, and a warm fruity finish. Very thin body with low carbonation (tiny fizziness). This is weak, watery, and not at all like the Quadroupel that I enjoyed from La Trappe. Disappointing!
Tan head and ruby colur. Wonderful plum notes. Medium body. Deep dark and wonderful!!!

Bottle - July 2007. Ripe fruit, pruney, ripe bananas on the nose. Fruity, warm and inviting aroma. Hazy caramel color with a rather thin creamy tan head. Malty, toffee flavor, sweet but not cloying, rummy with a fruity ending. Medium full MF with some chewy malts. Aftertaste a bit short. 
Nice, malty dubbel but a bit too unidimentional.

Bottle. Pours hazy dark caramel, thin off white head that quickly dissipates. Aroma is port, plums, raspberries, grass. Very sweet aroma with hints of acetone. Flavor is dried fruit, wheat. On the watery side, weak body. Disappointing.
Dark colour, white head. Aroma and flavours of dark fruits. Nice balanced bitterness.

Courtesy of Kurtis Sea. Big tan head that sustains. Decent lace. Aromas provide a roasty chestnut and hint of caramel. Tastes are similar with a hint of cola and sour grape. High carbonation and full body. Good.

33 cL bottle. Wonderful aroma of dark fruits. Something of raisin bread. Opaque, dark color with a tan head. Thin to medium bodied. Sort of a dark bread taste, with some stewed dark fruit; not prune though. It coats the mouth with dark flavors, but it is not burnt or sweet. Suggests an overaged cask of Bombardier - tending towards earth. Arguably some yeast along with the dark bread. The finish is relatively dry, suggests dark flavors, and it is simply wonderful. I dont have an adequate vocabulary to describe the complexity. Id like to suggest fruit cake, but thats just too light and too bready. This is its own wonderful thing.
aroma of fruit and malt but also a little coffee, great brown head on a copper body. great fullbodied taste, everything i would expect from a dubbel. my favorite la trappe.

750 ML Bottle-Poured a deep amber/red color w/a moderate beige head. Classic sweet Belgian aroma. Bread dough/yeast flavor on the front end w/ traces of dark fruit/plum, cane sugar, raisins, & dark rum. Had some spicy kick to it. but nothing crazy. Good earthy mouthfeel w/traces of peat & grapes. A little hot, could have used a little time to smooth it out. Solid Dubbel.

Bottle. Pours with a copper color. Aromas are typical of a Belgian double, some dough, and some fruit. Flavor is fruity, with hints of caramel and bread.
Failry subtle yeast flavors and a solid body and mouthfeel.
750 mL bottle.  ruby brown with foamy beige head.  Aroma of dark fruit, caramel, licorice, and yeast.  Taste of fig and raisin, candy, and vanilla notes.

750ml bottle corked and caged. Factory date code stamped on back label. 
Deep red brown, with a thick creamy tan head.
Aroma is malty, plum, fig, light rum, a touch of yeast.
Flavor is a bit yeasty, with some dry earthiness, and light fruitiness.
Finish is short and medium dry.
Brown color, with a medium head. Aroma: Malt. dark fruits. Palate: Malt, plums, sweet.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2007 Bottle, pours with a small brown head, dark fruit and high alcohol aroma. Dark sweet fruit reminiscent of figs and dark grapes. Alcohol is not as present in the flavor. A decent dubble.

Tap at Pizza Port Carlsbad.  Mahogany pour with the remnants of a tan head.  Malt, yeast, dates, and fruits in the nose.  Velvety mouthfeel.  Earthy and yeasty, with a sweet malt, plums, and some banana esters.

Bottle. Ruby mahogony beer with a big light beige head. Big malty, yeasty, plummy, figgy aroma. Yeasty, malty, slight banana flavor with spice and some dark stone fruit. Medium bodied. LIngering earthy, yeasty, malt. Could be a little richer, but not bad at all.
Bottle 75 cl as Dominus Dubble. HAd it previous also on draft. A very fruity and nice double. A real good trappist
Bottle, 33 cl. Dark reddish brown with almost no head. Aroma hoppy, sweetish, fruity, roasted malts. Medium body. Taste = drinkable,  malts, little yeasts, sweet.

750ml Koningshoeven Dubbel bottle @ Hamiltons shared with my pal Josh in from San Fran.  Pours dark ruddy brown with a 1 finger tan head.  Candy sugar aroma, slightly sweet. Taste is sweet and malty with a slightly cloying candy sugar taste.  Pretty good, not so hot overall, has some kind of taste that really doesnt fit me all that well, but got better as it warmed as most belgians tend to.

bottle - Pours amber with a thin, lingering head.  It has a dark fruit aroma.  Im picking up grapes and possibly some plums.  The flavor is really fruity with yeast and malt dominating.  Its medium bodied and has a smooth finish.  I really liked this one.

Bottle. Creamy off-white excellent fully lasting head. Amber cloudy colour.
Moderate malty and hopy aroma. nice powerfull butter fruity flavor with strong orange notes. Oily palaye. A little fizzy.

Bottle: Ruby mahogany color, light head and lacing. Nose of metal, starchy sweet malts and a yeasty doughy essence. The flavor is nice and malty, much more turbinado/jaggery esque int he flavor than in the nose. The finish is plenty chewy, but is still stale and imported tasting. A bit oxidized.
Stiff frothy head. Coffee-brown color. Slightly fruity, the carachteristic stale  belgian flavor, but not too overwhelming. Quite drinkable.
This is a real nice dubbel.  Brown in color with light creamy head with minimal lacing.  Hints of filbert nuts, bread & fruit

330ml bottle.
Light, but rich red colour. Steady creamy head. Sharp and sour aroma - no distinct details. Fizzes on the tongue, slight bitter taste then a huge sweet fruity malt washes over the tongue and leaves a very long finish. Some almonds.
Dark brown with nice tan head.  Yeasty, fruity aroma.   Nice fruity taste.  I think its better than most give it credit for.....

Starts with a malty caramel flavor that gives way to a milder flavor with some fruitiness as well.  A fairly simple trappist but still quite good.  Their quad is better and more complex, so it gets my vote.

$2.99 for this 33cl.  I really like this Dubbel.  I will admit it isnt the best of them, but it doesnt claim to be.  Dark red/brown like the others have said with a healthy head.  Drinkable, carbonated, smooth and fresh.  Im giving a high rating in spite of the simplicity.  I could drink it all the time.

This rating is for the Dubbel, however the label differs slightly.  As an official trapp brew, I was slightly dissappointed by the simplicity of the palate.  Typically, I am accustomed to multiple levels of flavor.

However, this brew had a strong hue and a delicous nose - overall not the best but I would buy again.

Dark red brown colour, thin quick fading head. Great balanced aroma with a little malt, hop and spice present. Warm, rounded taste with some caramel sweetness and malt. Clean aftertaste making it very drinkable.
Body is red-brown with a great begie creamy head. Beautiful !! The taste and flavor is malty and has a fresh fruityness to it. Sweet. Little thin.
Bottle. Wonderful deep red colour with big head. Nice kind of sweet taste, a bit fruity. Too little body though and taste dissapears a bit too quickly. Had better beer of this style.

Bottle pours a deep mahogany/brown with a full lasting creamy tan head.  Aroma is brown sugar, apples, cinimon and dark pitted fruits.  Flavor was similar, apple butter and dark malts.  Very little bitterness, smooth rich feel, lively carbonation.  great example of the style.  
Thanks Jordan.

Bottle:  Amber ruby color with a large beige head and nice lacing.  Nose is fruity, malty, yeast, wine, and a bit of raison.  On par for the style.   Tastes sweet with dark fruits, malt, and a crisp finish.  A little caramel sweetness with the maltiness smooths it out.  Thank you Jordan for sharing this.

Dark Brown with Red Hue and Sandy Head.  Dry Malt, Yeast and Spiced Aroma.  Medium Mouthfeel...Nice and Creamy...and Quite Smooth.  Wonderful Layers of Malt...Very Aromatic Even While Drinking.  Cinnamon, Cloves and Nutmeg Dance On your Tongue While Sweet Dry Malts Do the Lions Share of the Work.  Nice Bready Quality to it.  Overall Just a Really Drinkable Dubbel.
[bottle] Clear ruby red colour. Large and thick head. Fruity and spicy aroma. Malty and dry, spicy (nutmeg, cinnamon?) flavour.

Bottle.  Luscious dark malt nose, plums with dark fruit, subtle spice, and faint brown sugar.  Deep dark dull red body with strong carbonation and an excited tanned head.  Sweet taste of dark fruit.  Bubblegum and plum.  Velvety malt doesnt match the carbonation, and body is too thin, even for a dubbel.  Aftertaste is kinda bland.  Very slightly warming.  Wow, didnt think I was going to kill this - its good! - but its just a little too uninteresting.
Bottle - Served in Trappist glass, nice nutty and fruity aroma, little head, deep complex flavour, very hard to put my finger on all the flavours, enjoyable

Bottled: Beer served too cold, excuse me while I give myself an uppercut. Poured a deep copper with a tan medium head. Quite active carbonation, the aroma  featured stewed fruit, plums, brown sugar, grapes and alcohol. Flavour was similar - stone fruit, leather, alcohol up front and a touch of pepper. Balanced by a light bitter finish. Quite nice but not quite up to some of its trappist brothers IMO.

Bottle. 11.2 fl. oz. Koningshoeven Dubbel.  Dark reddish-brown color with off-white, frothy head. Sweet, raisin yeasty aroma.  Medium to full bodied with a  very dry texture and lively carbonation. Sweet flavor with some lingering bitterness.
Coffee color, no head. Hazy with yeast particles. Sweet, berry aroma and flavor. Fizzy, medium bodied. Malty and tart finish.

Bottle. Aroma is wonderful. Lots of fruit. Grapes, cherries, figs, some pear... all sitting under a blanket of caramel malt sweetness. Appearance is a nice clear amber, with a steady big head of white foam which laces beautifully. Flavor is sweet but well balanced, a touch of alcohol punctuated by the aformentioned fruits. Palate is very nice, hearty and balanced.

Pours a red/brown color, with a tan head that disipates too quickly and leaving a poor lace. Primary smell is wet earth, then you find later the subtleties: cherries, cocoa, licorice and spices. Rough roasted flavour, though the body is lighter than expected and mouth of cocoa, licorice, plums and fruits. Sweet finish.
Not exceptional in any way. Amber with full off-white head. Kind of sweet, with notes of dark sugar and apricot in the taste. Aroma is pretty much the same, sweetish and full.

Bottle at De Hems, London. Pours brown with ruby highlights, fading tan head.  Aroma is cherries, sweet candied fruits, slight spice - predominantly ginger, cloves.  Taste is much the same, with dark stone fruits, candy sweetness, and a slight acidity. Very carbonated, almost over the top - not sure if it fits the profile here, at least I know I didnt enjoy it. Better than average but not in the upper echelon for the style.

Labeled as Konigns Hoeven.. this is definitely not the delicious La trappe Dubbel I remember. Nice purple brown appearance, and delightful aroma of cherries. The flavor.. where is it? If anybody knows where it went please email me. Not impressive.

Aroma: pears, sweet, sweet malt, candisugar, dried apricot. Funky, exotic fruit esters  banana. 
Appearance: very beautiful, deep red. Browntinted, very thick, fluffy head. 
Flavour: very well balanced. Sweet, malty full-bodiedness, some bitterness aswell. Perfect chocolate and wheatlike aftertaste. Slightly sourish and vinous. Some mustiness. 
Palate: very nice mouthfeel, very thick and longlasting. Invigourating. 
The bottle says 7%

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2007 Appearance: dark brown color, with reddish tones. Great head, rocky, of beige color, dense and very persistent. Beautiful.
Aroma: very sweet, malty, toasty, bitter chocolate, candy, liquory and winy. Berries, peaches and banana. Spicy of clove. Relatively complex. Low hoppyness.
Flavor:  complex, sweet, toasty malt, candy, chocolate and grain coffee. Fruitiness of figs, berries, plums and banana. Reminiscences of coffees liquor and vintage wine. Spicy of nutmeg and clove. Sweet toasty start. Warming and light dry-hoppyness finish.
Palate: Medium body, creamy and semi-oily texture. Low carbonation.
Advisable beer, with a beautiful head.

Bottle from Systembolaget. This comes across to me as a mediocre/sligthly better than average example of the style. Quite harsh in a way. Good maltiness though. And yeah, whats up with no yeast in my bottle?

Sampled March 2007
Pours with a brilliantly clear, dark amber, purple-plum color.  It is topped by an initially three-finger thick, amber-tinged, tan head.  The aroma has a musty, almost woody spiciness to it; notes of clove, a touch of allspice, damp bark, cola nut, and perhaps a touch of wet cardboard.

The beer is fairly sweet, yet has a subtle dusty chocolate note.  Quite a bit of fruit is here as well, with predominantly a raisin / fig note that is accentuated a bit by the light malt sweetness.  There is a touch of cola character here as well as a more typical clove character and a touch of ginger in the finish.  Really though the dark, concentrated fruit note are the dominant flavor here.  This brew never approaches sticky though, and is in fact quite light overall and fairly easy drinking.

Not a bad beer, and considering that Dubbels are my least favorite Belgian-type beer, well it is even drinkable
Bottled.  Clear mahogany colour. rich beautiful creamy beige head. Fruity and yeasty a light touch of almond and toffee. Medium bodied with spritzy livel mouthfeel. Low bitterness. Rather gentle.

33cL bottle.  I really liked this dubbel.  It poured a clear, coffee color with nice carbonation and an off-white head.  There was a nice warmth and sweetness in the flavor with a great, abrubt finish.  I recommend trying this beer.
Yeasty, apple skin aroma, some sweetness.  Pours a deep reddish amber.  Sweet malts, caramel and brown sugar, apple skins, yeast, some banana.

Bottled. Hazy reddish brown with a rich long-lasting white foam. Almondy, yeast, prunes and raisins in the aroma with notes of straw and metal. Sweet malty and yeasty flavour of banana, almond and milky chocolate. Light bodied for a Dubbell. Almond, light chocolate, nuts and dust in the finish.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2008 Bottle (33 cl) from Systembolaget. Hazy copper with a lrage beige head. Complex, roasted malt aroma with fruity, earhty and yeasty notes. Medium bodied and smooth. Dry and bitter finish with some mild sweetness.
Bottle. Reddish brown colour with a medium off-white head. Sweet yeasty aroma with tropic fruits. Sweet fruity flavour.

Pours a beautiful deep amber brown color w/ a full, semi creamy froth.  Aromas of dried dark fruits and dusty granite. Meium nectar w/ ample residual effers. Its very effervescent and explodes on the palate. Right away this brew is balanced. Sweetness factor is nil. Dry and very brisk. Flavors of bitter cocoa in the foreground supporting a myriad of nuances. Nectarine, plumb, rasins, coffee bean, and tobacco. The finish is bittered abundantly leaving my palate with a velvet blanket. Drinks better as she warms where more fruit and a mild sweetness developes.
Deep brown colour with a smokey fruit nose. Deeply smokey malt with a hint of blackcurrent and spice

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2008 Original rating 4/1/2007:  Dark, murky brown with a quickly fading head.  Sugary sweet aroma, thick with candi sugar.  The taste is... well, barely there.  Pretty watery and just a little sweetness.  Not bad, but it doesnt offer much and is really a disappointment.  7/4/5/3/13   Re-rate 3/27/2008:  Dark copper color with a large head.  Strong yeasty aroma, lots of fresh bread and sweet malt.  The flavors are much stronger this time around.  More sweet malt and bread, with a fair amount of spice (primarily cloves).
Bottle. Fruity aroma. Nice reddish copper colour with medium head. Sweet fruity and spicy flavor. Well ballanced beer.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2007 Pour was a pleasant dark copper with tons of ruby highlights.  The head was off-white and two-fingers plus in height.  The aroma was restrained which is unfortunate as it had tons of character.  Dominated by what I would call stone or rocks.  Some definite floral (lavender) and spice with yeast noted as well.  The flavor was malt and faint spice with even fainter chocolate.  Enjoyable, just incredibly restrained.  Mouthfeel was a bit watery.

Bottle. Redbrown beer with huge palebrown head, long lasting. Nice aroma sweet and fruits. Good taste sweet with malt notes. A light beer compared to many other dubbels but very wellcomposed and drinkable. I liked it very much.
K03J6 330ml - Dark, dark red under large dark tan head composed of small bubbles.  Sugary, spicy nose.  Toffee and nuts on the front, malt and some hoppy bitterness on end.  Nice.

From bottle. Fresh bitter aroma of fruit. Great deep red colour with a nice off white head. Nice rich flavour, smooth and slightly spiced. Caramel and liquorice mixed in. Good finish with a slight tangyness. Lovely beer. Has character.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2011 Had this in the Netherlands, Excellent abbey dubbel. Great appearance, fruity aroma, trappist yeast... not as complex or strong as other abbey beers which makes it excellent for beginners (and experts).

Re-Rate.

Ok so I was unexperienced with taste 4 years ago. Had this on tap @ the Maproom again last week.  Poured a dark amber with a tan head that lasted for ever. Aroma of dark fruits, figs and carmel malts. Taste is similar with a nice belgian sugar finish. Quite good for a dubbel. Really easy to find around here. Would buy again.

Serving this bottle at roughly cellar temperature. Roasted malts, nuts and some dark fruits on the nose, plum and cherry possibly, with a bit of sweetness in there. Surupy dark brown body with some off-white lace. Body is not as rich as I would have wanted. Flavour is quite well balanced, some toffee and nuts, drying black coffee, a tannic dark cherry quality in there. Not as rich as other examples of the style, which is a bit disappointing. Still a very nice beer regardless!
Bottle. Very dark brown colour. Very small head. The flavour is not sweet, but not exactly dry either. Perhaps a little sweetness in the fruitiness along with roasted notes.
Definably fruity--almost no head with sweet (dates?) aftertaste. Still prefer Rochefort when it comes to Trappist ales, but this is not bad.

Very nice.  Ruby reddish brown body with a big (but quickly dissipating) head.  Aroma was chock full of fruits, from peaches and grapefruit to figs and prunes.  Flavor is a bit fruity and bready, but light and not too sweet.  Maybe not as nuanced as some Belgians Ive had, but very good.

An excellent beer. Aroma of dark fruits, licorice, malty and almost some kind of nut bread aroma. Appearance is a dark brownish/reddish hue, small off-white head. Mouthfeel is a little lighter, perhaps a bit too carbonated but still nice. Flavor is raisins, alcohol, nutmeg and some yeast. An excellent example of this style.

Excellent abbey dubbel. Great appearance, fruity aroma, trappist yeast... not as complex or strong as other abbey beers which makes it excellent for beginners (and experts). Great beer. (Have to get another and re-rate it for my memory is not that good for tiny details).
Sampled while in the Netherlands. A very nice brew with a strong aroma and nice dark brown appearance. Head when poured was thick and tasty. Flavor was tremendous. A great beer.

Interesting beer. Intense and persistent taste of toasted malt, much more of  coffee and chocolate. Short while extreme carbonation, but does not compromise the set. Absolute lack of aroma. But, in compensation, the cream is thick and consistent........................................ Bem interessante essa escurinha.
Gosto intenso e persistente de malte torrado, muito mais do que café e chocolate.
Carbonatação um pouco excessiva, mas não compromete o conjunto.
O que mata um pouco é a absoluta falta de aroma. Mas, em compensação, o creme é espesso e consistente.
Hop Leaf, Chicago.  On tap.  No head, almost wine-y in texture and flavor.  Not what I would have expected from a dubbel.  Wonder if a bottle would have been different...

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2007 It is the strong Dunkel than I remember to have taken. Palate accented of coffee, caramel, toasting and, over all, chocolate bitter taste (pure cacao). Perhaps therefore its palate tent to the sweet one. Very good aroma and cream, however too carbonated. Pretty color (brown). I detach as weak point the bitter taste that is in the tongue, extreme to mine. Very subtle aftertaste. Evident alcohol.

Bottle. Amber red color with a large fizzy good lacing off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramael, chokolate, moderate yeasty, brown sugar. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and modrate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle (form Bitter Virtue)> Fruity and toffeeish on the nose with mild yeast. Slightly sweet with mild tartness. Very smooth with the sweetness more restrained than in some beers. On the whole unimpressive but quite drinkable.
I did not really care for the flavor.  For some reason all i could taste was sweat.  No idea why.  Other than that, it looked quite nice, but still I ended up disappointed.
Bottle. Red/Brown amber colour with a average off-white head. Aroma and flavour of caramel, chocolate, dried fruit, spice and malt.

Bottel. Dark red-brown colour with a nice big creamy off-white head. Aroma of caramel and malt, slightly yeasty with spices. Flavour is sweet and bitter, good maltiness, caramel, some spiciness and fruitiness. Bitter-sweet finish. Very tasty beer.
Abit of a disappointment after the Blond, but good nevetrheless.  Chocolate and caramel predominate.  Not really to my taste.

Pours Dark Brown with a thin tan head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel, brandy, malt and fruit. Very nice. Tastes sweet, hints of chocolate. Nice carbination. Very aromatic and drickable. Could be a favorite!

300ml bottle.  pours deep brown with a ruby tint; the head is puffy, of average size, and of average retention.  honey, banana, and caramelized brown sugar (is there such a thing) dominate the aroma. the aroma is very refreshing and pleasant, without jamming the senses with complexity.  while the taste is parallel to the palate, it adds depth with caramel, medium hops, and an almost velvet finish.  high in drinkability, the alcohol is disguised through a complex character.  this is a very pleasant ale.  one indeed to savour.
Pours dark brown with a surprisingly thin head.  Aroma is pleasant but not overwhelming. Some fruit in the taste, as well as a little bit of yeast.  Very good.
Brown colour with medium white head fruity tast aroma of honey.malt and caramel a light bitter finish fine beer.

Bottle. Dark amber with beautifull almost lasting off-white head. Fruit explodes out of the glass - its almost perfumed. The malts are more present in the still rather fruity flavor. Average finish with a little end-note of bitterness. Seems a little out of balance - the fruits almost hides the malts and the hops.

Bottle - poured into a Chimay Glass. Immediately notice the re/brown colouring and "murky" look - big fan. Wonderful fruity aroma (banana?) - very noticeable. Flavour while very good not as full bodied as some others I have tried previously. Very enjoyable and competetively priced - certainly have again.

Deep brown colored beer, with a ring and a thin cap of beige foam. Moderate lacing. Mild malt and even milde tart plum in the aroma.

I taste a sweet caramel malt with honey, dark candi sugar, and plum brandy. Flavorful to be sure, but a little too short-lived to be considered excellent. Medium bodied, very smooth, with way too little carbonation.
0.33l bottle from supermarket in Amstelveen. Nice deep brown color and medium beige head. Fruity aroma. Sweet taste also some yeast, not much hops.  Very drinkable beer.

Bottle at Bar & Cigar, Oslo.
Lots of fruit and malt, a full flavour beer if there ever was one. Not much hop presence, but somehow the sweetness is not cloying. A very enjoyable beer.

Nice, nice, creamy head. The aroma is alluring with notes of malt and fruit. Flavour, well I admit that La Trappe has a very, special place in my heart, I simply like their beers!! I get notes of syrup, ripe, dark fruits, malt, caramel and a light bitter finish. It is a very full-bodied beer - really nice.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2007 Bottle best before G104, so I am guessing 3-5 year old bottle.  Old label, nice bottle with logo on the glass, and the old cap (all better the the new bottles).  Unfortunately, the rest of the beer is still disappointing (I guess some things never change).  Poured into a De Ranke wine like goblet glass.  Pours with no head and no lacing.  Color is brown, cannot see through it but lots of clarity on the edges.  Aroma is present, whole wheat brown russian bread (not wheat), grainy.  Its an aroma I found in a lot of Belgian Dubbels that are second or thrid tier.  Taste is a watery candi sweetness, some dates.  Everything in general seems to have faded.,  Finishes with a stale bread aftertaste.  Some grassy herbally flavors as well.  Rerate: Best Before 2008 ceramic bottle brought over from Holland.  I figure this is a slightly different beer, just slightly, 7% says the label.  Mainly, the beer was a little out of wack, lots of sweetness, over the top and cheap.  It had a candi base but seems like it went somewhere else with it.  Not bad you would think with some time but as it shows above not good either.  Maybe there is a middle ground somewhere in time but its too small to make a different.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Bottle Labeled Konings Hoeven Dubbel - Pours dark brown with a fair offwhite head that stays well and laces.  Aromas of chocolate, raisin, roasted malts, yeast.  Flavor is chocolate, raisin, lots of yeast, some roasted notes, a little candi sugar.  Palate is soft and well carbonated.   Not bad.. Cool thing is this one was $1.25 at the Andersons because they couldnt figure out the price..
Dark mahogany red pour with ample head.  Rich strong sweet brew that will make your liver quiver if consumed too quickly.  Fine Dubbel.  Very drinkable.

Very murky redish-brown body, many particles and a tan head that is as short lived as my new years resolutions.  A simple but effective mix of sweet liquorice candy, caramel and earthy berries.  Far behind these main flavours I get some floral nectar, some figs and some medicine (cough syrup).  Limited hops presence, to say the least.  Soft carbonation.  Doesnt feel special or unique but still highly drinkable.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2007 Sweet, smooth, thick and brown. A little bit too much fruitiness (banana, melon) on the nose and taste, otherwise very good and highly enjoyable. Good smooth carbonation and mouth feel. I remember the tap version having a bit more fruitiness than the 0.33l bottle I had.
