(30 cl bottle from a friend from Holland) Clear red brown color, huge tan head. Sweet, raissin and cheeze, alcohol scent. Sweet sugary alcohol taste, candy sweet aftertaste. Low bitterness. Smooth mouthfeel.

Deep reddish-brown with a fair amount of yeast particles.  Heavy sugar, apple aroma.  Taste is very bready with some fruit.  Aftertaste leaves something to be desired.  Not bad, but could be better considering its a Trappist.
[bottle from tesco] cherry colour with medium head. caramelised banana, slight hint of pear. medium to well bodied. slightly acidic with a slightly bitter finish.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2016 Dark brown, almost cola like with a nicely formed thin head. Meaty, malty nose with some candied sugars. Fairly similar to taste but again intensity errs on the side of caution and finishes a touch weak. Quite fizzy to my palate. 2016 tasting remarkably similar although fizz levels were definitely lower. (e3.0 @ Café Arendnest 2006, e2.50 Amsterdam supermarket 2016)
33cl bottle. Nutty cereal aroma. A good head. Hint of chocolate. Medium to the palate with average to lively carbonation. Fairly complex. A fairly decent brew.

Pours dark, cloudy, reddish/brown with a nice tan head. Strong yeast and dark fruit aromas. Upfront yeast and fruit flavors, slight spice,  with nice slight hop bitterness on the finish. Palate is medium, well balanced, creamy, and crisp.

high alcohol content, but thats to bwe expected with these types of beers.  The alcohol didnt overwhelm, and the pour was as smooth as the flavor.  Although I liked the quad more, this one is a great beer in its own right.  I recommend you try this one, but make sure you grab a quad to complare.
user_location: The United States of Texas, Texas, USA

text: Deep red with amber hints, nice head fades slowly, bordering on creamy.  Aroma is of fresh baked bread.  Flavor is also of freshly baked, dark bread, with some faint, undefined dark fruit undertones.  Maybe cherries?  The sheer depth of the flavor is nice, perhaps not the most complex, but clearly rich and satisfying.  I liked this considerably more than the tripel, as I think the bread flavors hang better with a dubbel than a tripel.  Good stuff.
love these beers , dark almost mahogany colour, choc malt on the nose, sweet, lotsa alcoho; on backbone but still balanced. great beer

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2009 Cloudy medium dark brown hue under a light fizzy cap. Aroma of lightly honeyed malts leads into like flavor - flavor augmented with some deep fruity tones and a pleasant crisp foretongue carbonation and subdued hint of lingering hop bitterness. Full and rich, like something between chocolate and ripe fruit. A solid 14 overall. ** slight addnote ** further sampling, surprisingly solid body, a wonderful note of apple amidst the rich malts and fig/raisin flavors. Kind of dopplebok like in the wet hay / honey character. nice beer! Im partial to this brewers products.

Brownish red with a creamy, albeit low, tan head. Malty aroma with chocolaty orange and some chilly freshness which might be hops or perhaps the winter cold messing with my nose. Mayybe also a hint of alcoholic spicyness...

Although the alcohol doesnt really shout at you it doesnt feel very well masked. Not what I usually expect from an abbey that isnt stronger than this.

Feels fairly thin but roughly sweet, malty chocolate that has a bitter aftertaste is the main thing. Not sure about the hops but they do show, I think.

dark brown beer that pours with a bit of a disappoint head for a trappist beer.  aroma is sweet and malty.  flavor is sweet, needs more hops, and slightly spicy from the yeast.  good palate.  dissappointing for a trappist beer.

Round malt aroma is sweet without being cloying.  Plenty of rich chocolate.  Opaque rich brown body is topped by a low but lasting, fine bubbled, off white head.  Chocolate and big malt sweetness are joined by a fairly pronounced bitterness.  Piquant alcohol perks up the palate at the finish.  Medium body with moderate carbonation.  Sampled at Mondial 2006.

a dark brown..low-medium head...good good lacing...slight choc-yeast smell...nice flavours, and quite bitter for a dubbee...kind of unique and complex...went well with kaas (cheese). has a tad alcohol in taste, but very nice.

Bottle: Previous samples of the La Trappe range had me relishing the chance to exxamine another. Their Triple is one of my favourites of the style, however, its been quite a while since I have had a Dubbel like this. Dark mahogany to rust brown with a yellowy head that fizzed initially, but grudgingly decided to stay eventually. In the nose stewed prunes cames to mind first, further forays revealing some spicy cloves and cooling, medicinal alcohol notes over a banoffee thickness. This theme carries through flavour-wise, however, I have to admit, at a much lower standard. I got a immediate hit of banana cake and chewy, spicy tofee, and some pleasant bitter herb notes play nicely to begin, though by the end they grate somewhat. Quite breadlike in a way. I also found the carbonation a little over done and prickly.

A bit like a bock for me. Poured a virtually clear dark brown with a smallish head. Quite malty, with some molasses and licorice notes. A little fruitiness from the yeast, but not as much as I was expecting for a dubbel. On tasting some caramelly banana comes through pleasantly though. Sweetness is well restrained, but the bitterness dwells somewhat which, with a relatively thin body, seems to stick out like dogs balls. Different abv from the details above (7%) - seemed pretty well contained. Maybe theyve changed more in the recipe than that?

BANANA!!! That is what i thought of this beer! The aroma is heavy with banana, and not so heavy with hops and malts. The flavor has easy touches of chocolate and caramel, but it never got as obvious as I hoped for. The banana is of course still represented during the rating of the flavor, but this time accompanied by some sourish notes. The beer has a good creamy caramellish and chocolate-full palate in the start, but it quickly turns watery and sourish, leaving the dreams of a Westmalle-Dubbel competitive beer, behind. The aftertaste is easily malty, with a lot of alcohol (actually too much, for a dubbel). It starts out really great, but ends up only above average.

Bottle at Paters Vaetje, Antwerpen. Dark chestnut brown with a rich, creamy yellowish head. Caramel and fruit aroma, but served a bit too cold to enjoy fully. Sweet caramel and raisins flavours. Medium body, fluffy mouthfeel. Lacking the punch of its stronger brothers it still provides decent complexity, if on the sweet side.

Robin red? Not sure about that but it looks pretty good. Deep coppry colour and a thick caramel head give the appearance of a good Belgian of its style. A melange of the usual stonefruits you find in these beers but the surprise comes when you taste it. Smooth and sweet with a subtle oiliness that distinguishes it from many others that have a demonstrable astringency.  Clean fruit and nut chocolate bar flavour that delights the palate. My bottle says 7% btw. Either way, it is an excellent beer
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: Deep reddish-amber (almost purple) color... initially a large head, but fades quickly, leaving behind a chaotic pattern of tan micro-bubbles on the surface.  Aroma of fresh plums, raisins, apples, caramel, sweet malts, and yeast.  Huge flavors of sweet malts, caramel, dried fruits (plums, cherries, raisins), fresh fruits (apples, pears, grapes).  Unbelievably silky smooth mouthfeel with a somewhat honey-like viscousness.  Amazingly drinkable despite its heaviness.  Finishes extremely dry with a pleasant sweet-but-hoppy aftertaste.  One of the best dubbels Ive every had--possesses all of the qualities I look for in the style.  Completely amazing.

(Bottle BBE 01/09; ABV 7%) Fruity (banana), caramel, berry-like and slightly yeasty aroma with a hint of alcohol. Red brown colour, hazy and large, brownish, very slightly lasting head with fair lacing. Sweet, fruity (banana), berry-like, caramel, slightly acidic flavour. Lively carbonated, medium-bodied and slightly alcohol palate. 06/10/06

Beer pours deep coppery-brown with a very thick tan head. The head is fantastic- thick, uneven, amazing retention, lots of both very fine and medium sized bubbles. The aroma is very heavy with malts plus some yeast and some caramel. Hints of dried fruit, too (dried sweet cherries). The flavor starts off with lots of malts - a spicey malt profile. There is some caramel and hints of roasted flavors. The middle and finish of the beer are dry - but still very malty. Some hops and some carbonation zip hit the end. The after-taste is yeasty. The body of the beer is strangely thin and not susdy (at first it almost feels flat on the tongue, despite the healthy foam).
bottle. brown color. large dissapating head. deep dark fruit aroma. taste of raisons and a bit caramel.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2008 7% corked ceramic bottle. My first Dutch monk, so to speak. Uncorks impressively with a puff of fruity smoke. Glugs musically into the Rochefort tulip. Is it worthy? Apparently so. Hissing beige froth atop a mahogany, red-haloed body. Powerfully fruity,strawberryish nose. Sweet berry-like caramel, with just enough balancing licorice bitterness. No hops or alcohol. A little thin for the style, but the silkiness compensates. Possibly a touch too sweet, but just about holds its own against some of the belgian big boys.
(Re-rate) Outlandish yellow suds piled on ebony. Ruby tints. Head irregular and receding to a slick. Nose brazen liquorice, candy sugar, lurking herbal hop, almond, more outspoken banoffee pie banana esters than is sensible and monkish. Definite noble hops and banana like a dunkelweizen. Drinks like a toned down,  liquorice and candy-packed Kasteel Donker. Bready but a bit slick and sugary for this rater. Lacks the yeasty bite of Rochefort, Westmalle, Westy, but some bready, nutty, chocolate-accented overlaps. Nice beer, overly sugared Trappist

One of the last bottles from Koningshoeven 4 pack in Memphis. Im very disapointed that the local distributor is dropping this brand. This was one of the better Dubbels available here in Memphis. It will truly be missed!

After my humble opinion, what a great beer. Reminds me a bit like the St. Bernardus only a little bit less tasty. But still a very nice beer. Aroma was caramel, bread, lecheries and maybe bit of raisin or dry fruit. Colour was dark brownish and head was creamy. Never seen such and fine foam before. Impressive. Flavour was heavy sweet, light bitter, and maybe hints of spicy flavour in the middle. Body was medium to full and texture was very creamy. Carbonation very lively and a soft finish with a good aftertaste in mouth. Overall a very excellent Dubbel beer.
Dark colour with a taste that reminds caramel. Slighty sweet and yeasty. Mouthfeel not strong but deserves to try it as the glass is one of the best.

Bottle form the SAQ, poured in a trappist glass. Pours a dark brown body with a medium beige head that doesnt last long. Aroma is a mix of sweet malt, faisins, plums and caramel. Taste is malty and sweet with notes of dark fruits and cognac. Mouthfeel is too thin for the style, but this is a good to very good beer anyway.
Bottle: Pours a dark brown body (w/ mahogany highlights) and an average-sized beige head. Aroma of mustiness, raisins, and sweet malts. Flavor of raisins and plum. Smooth mouthfeel.

On tap @ In De Wildeman, Amsterdam.
Pours clear plain brown, small beige head. Strong caramel aroma. Taste is caramel as well, moderately sweet with some yeast and spices. Minimal hopped, and a rather thin mouthfeel. Drinkable, oh yes, but I miss the complexity a trappist dubbel should have.

750cc. bottle.  Moderately opaque, medium brown color.  Ephemeral light beife head.  Yeasty, a bit corky in aroma.  Light bodied, unfortunately thin feeling.  Moderate to plus carbonation.  Peppery, yeasty flavors.  Modest alcohol.  Decent at best.

750ml bottle. Pours black with a thick off-white head. Aroma of malt, yeast and black cherry. Some caramel too. Flavor is about the same, rather malty. Dry finish. A bit carbonated. Alcohol really present for 6.5%. Good one.

Bottle from Koningshoeven 4 pack. Poured dark brown with a large fizzy off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate toasted caramel malty tart fruit aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture. Medium balanced malty flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration.
Not much smell in this one, pretty good for an belgian beer, some bitterness, fudge and the usually strong alcoholic taste

Bottle. Looks quite dark but in my Westmalle glass the foam seems to enjoy itself to the max. This is a beer with a delicate aroma of malt, roasted peanuts and cognac. The beer itself is wonderfully fluffy, with full flavours of tickling raisins in the beginning, turning towards port to finish with nuts, rum...mmm.... yummy. The aftertaste looses its bitterness after a few sips. There is something which quite doesnt fit in this one, like the flavour attaching when you make homebrews with dirty equipment. But maybe its this bottle, and its not strong, but barely noticable. Fantastic stuff!

Mahogany with a nice cap of tan head. Dark, spicy ginger bread aroma. A little bit of wet grass. Spicy rye bread flavor with some vegetal, medicinal notes. Nice palate, light but not too thin. Really some good flavors here, just not particularly clean.

Koningshoeven 4pk.  - purchased in Norman at hob nob robs.  Fantastic nose pours dark red with tan bubbly head.  I used a Chimay glass which felt right.  The taste was right in line with many of the Belgian Trappist ales with a bit more chocolate/caramel maltiness.  Very nice.
Bought it in a  Koningshoeven 4pk with a Trappist Glass.  Dark amber in color.  Zesty malt aroma. Flavors of dark fruits like plums or figs. Light texture. Very fizzy. Slightly warming.

Strong, caramel-filled aroma.  Very strongly fruity, with raisins and plums.  Somewhat spicy.  The flavor is not nearly as complex or full-bodied or sweet as the aroma.  It leaves me feeling like it could have a bit more meat to it, and is in fact, pretty thin.

Bottle from Santa - a refreshing, light bodied Dubbel - very earthy, cellared aroma - musty, cobweb-like smells - kind of stale in the flavor, though - however, the light sweetness, gentle dark fruit and lively carbonation make it a fairly good belgian ale to be enjoying on this hot summer evening.

Vinuous aromas of strawberryalcohol, tannin and some mustiness.  On tasting, the fruit leans more towards a peach/nectarine/celery.  Natural sweetness and a drying finish differentiate the palate from others.  Lots of ruby color to the beer and a nice, tan head, too.

Dark brown pour with thick, tan head that reduces itself to floating islands of bubbles. The aroma is sweet, filled with cotton candy and ripened fruits including plums. The flavor is toward the sweet side with notes of candy, caramel, strawberry and plum. Slightly bitter finish with a touch of alcohol. The body is thin, the finish short. Average dubel.
Pours a very dark brown with a nice froathy head.  Aroma is nice with hints of malt, caramel and chocolate.  Flavor is very simialr with a so what bitter finish.

Dark brown colored pour.  Smells yeasty and malty.  A little darker than I thought it was going to be.  A nice woody smell and taste.  It went alright with a steak, but I could have enjoyed a bottle of wine much more with a steak than this beer.  Its good, for sure.  Its not the best dubbel Ive ever had.

The aroma has butterscotch, sugar, yeast, chocolate, grass, and some basement smells. The appearance is hazy red brown with a decent head. The flavor has all the elements of the aroma but its also a little odd. It is malty with some bitterness, cola, and alcohol. The palate is smooth but thin. Overall its alright but not one of the best Dubbels that Ive had.

Bottle:
Dark red colour, with anice creamy foam. Aroma of dark chocolate and citrus, malt,ashtry, and a nice bitterness in the end. Sweet cocoa, dark chocolate,a little bit of coffee in the mouth, nice balanced with a medium bitterness in the finish. Medium body. Nice beligium ale

Unknown vintage.  No best by date.  11.2 oz bottle.  The beer pours to a garnet red body with a thin fizzy head.  The aroma is sweet yeasty green raisins.  The flavor is bready, yeasty, clover honey, green raisins.  Decent palate but a little sweet and cloying.

Aroma is caramel, butterscotch, yeasty.
body is a dark brown with a tan colored head.
Taste is sweet like coca cola, with caramel, yeast, a bit of honey, and grapes.
Nice suprise
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a medium off-white head. Malty and sweet. Notes of caramel and chocolate. Also hints of dark fruits.
Robe brune claire surmontée dune mousse beige timide. Arômes de fruits, de levure et de caramel. Saveurs de malt, de caramel, de fruits et de levure. Un peu aqueuse.

330ml bottle (bb. 03/07) while watching Germany against Poland on TV. Deep brown red-tinged. Creamy off-white head that fades away after a minute. Sourish aroma with elements of yeast. Comprehensive flavour with an interesting combination of sweetness and sourness. Notes of coffee, chocolate and dark fruit. After a while in the glass a more yeasty taste comes forth. Medium to lively carbonated. Dry and rather abrupt end.

Bottle brought back from Brussels.  Log cabin german raisin aroma.  Looks like cherry wood with beige tufty.  Raisins, cherries in flavor, full flavored, dark wood palate.  Even elisa likes it.  No yeast in bottle.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2006 Pours brown/in light has red hue. Consistant tan colored head. Malty, chocolatey scent. Creamy sweet body with hints of dark chocolate roasted malt and a metallic character. Rich in flavor with a subtle dry finish.

A very good Trappist beer.  Dark reddish colour with good malt and fruit flavours.  Poured a nice head which settled quickly.  A mild hop finished the taste.  This beer had good carbonation being quite acidy.
Dark red colour. Chocolat aroma, with long lasting fruity finish. Nice one..

Bottle. Beer was clear, dark amber-brown colored with a large, frothy, light, diminishing head. The aroma was malty with moderate notes of raosted grain; Hoppy with moderate notes of herb; Yeasty with a light note of dough; Light notes of diacetyl and moderate notes of cardboard-like oxidation. Not nice. The flavor was moderately sweet, lightly acidic and lightly bitter with a long, lightly sweet, lightly acidic/tangy finish. Unclean aftertaste. The body was light-to-medium, the texture was watery-to-velvety and the carbonation was lively.

Bottle. Poured a reddish brown with a tall, frothy, tan head that left light lacing. The head settled out with time. This is one of the few beers I would prefer colder as is turns blah as it warms. The initial aroma found sweetness, banana, and raisin. As it warmed the aroma went to a mix of dark fruits and alcohol. Initial flavor was sweet, honey, and cherries. Again as it warmed the flavor went to a mix of dark fruit. Short aftertaste. Light body and slightly tingly on the tongue.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2006 dark murky brown with no head.  dark malt, alcohol, prunes, plum, and cherry aroma.  spicy licorice, cherry, plum, brown sugar and caramel flavor.  sugary.  so far this is the best ive tried from this brewery.

Poured from the bottle, a deep reddish brown, lots of carbonation and a slightly off-white thin head. The aroma is yeasty, with plenty of fruit (sweet oranges) and some peppery spice. Very carbonated mouthfeel, yeast again strong in the flavour (and honey), but with a syrupy smoothness than sticks to the tongue.

10:58 K23K1. Konings hoeven label. Pours dark mahogany into a trappist glass.  Conglomerate head quickly recedes to the rim.  Medicinal fig notes.  Full bread, date and fig flavors with a quick, but warming  finish.
Aroma of chocolat, caramel malt, spices, plum, smoke. Spicy, caramel and malty flavour, mouthfilling malty with a long finish

33 cl bottle.  No best before date.  Deep copper tinted brown beer with a thin tan head.  Some yeasty chunks because I wasnt paying attention during the pour.  Sweet plummy aroma, brown sugar, brown bread, warm baking spices (cinnamon and nutmeg).  A peachy fruitiness as well.  Smells like peach cobbler.  Sweet berry and a lightly yeasty aroma as well.  Flavour matches the aroma pretty well, some toffee and caramelized fruit, plummy but not overdone.  Really silky texture with flavours of kettle caramelization, rye toast.  As it warms the flavours and aromas become even more intense.  Sweet, but not sugary with loads of bready and fruity notes.  Long warm baked fruit bread finish.  Very enjoyable brew.
Dark almost black brown with light brown head.Very fruity smell, pleasant to the nose. Sour at first with a tingly fruit finish.
Dark red color, foamy thick head. sweet one with a nice bitter bit. some fruit fresh,...nice one.

red brown colour. At first I taste a lot of smoke then perhaps plums (fruit). In the end its filling and has a fine finish. Personally the plum & smoke combination is a bit too much for me! Defenetly not a trappist I would prefer if I had to pick from all 7 breweries!

Pours a light crimson brown and has a soft thin mocha colored head.  Aroma is is a bit acidic...not much else...even as it warmed.  Slight bits of yeast and fruit...kind of a miss if you ask me.  Flavor is much fuller than the aroma.  Dry malt, candy sugar, roastiness, and pepper.  Very sweet.  Mouthfeel is sufficiently thick.

Bottle.  Strong plum, molasses aroma.  Orange/reddish brown cloudy color with small head.  Moderately sweet molasses malt flavor - lightly smokey.  Smooth finish - just the lightest hint of bitterness.   Nice smooth dubbel.

Murky brown red with some spices and yeast floating about. Well carbonated. Sweet  malty smell of dark fruits.  Good bite for a dubbel.  Malt and spice combination.  Not sure of what variety but its nice. Mildy sticky.  Not overly complex band certainly not plain.

Berry raisin and caramel in the scent.  Awesome looking ruddy brown with red highlights and a firm head.  Thick in the mourth.  Very rich full and complex taste.  Smoke, caramel, bitter dark chocolat, alcohol, spice.  Perfectly Ballanced.  Damn good.
11.2oz: Pours a dark brown/black color w/white-tan head. Aroma of molasses, flowers.  Fizzy taste, molasses, slight flowers, dry aftertaste, not bitter.  Warm mouthfeel.

Chocolate pour with a bit of red and a grayish head. A yeast filled nose that has a little bubble gum and alcohol in it.  Sweet flavor that is reminiscent of a Twix bar. Bitter twang of yeast snaps me back in the finish. There is a touch of pepper and another spice here, clove maybe. 
Ap-3 ar-6 tas-6 pal-3 ov-13

Bottle. Poured a good ruddy-brown, but with a thin head.  Cherry and raisin sweet malt flavor with some alcohol.  Moderate mouthfeel- the brew _looks_ like it should be heavier than it is.  If you find the palate a little thin, I think the flavor should still carry you through.
Bottle.  Dark brown pour with a thin laced head.  Brown sugar, caramel aroma.  Sweet fruity flavor to it.  Pretty good.

Bottle, 50cl. Nice bottle/label. Pours a dark brown with reddish hints liquid, with a yellow head, very creamy and long lasting. Aroma is sweet and spicy, with malt and caramel also present. Flavour isnt as complex as i thought it would be: very smooth, malty and spicy. I also detected some cork in flavour. I must confess i was expecting a little more from this Dubbel. Nevertheless, a rather decent one.
Really enjoyed the overall beer here. Lacked a bit in the taste department, but that could have been a stuffy nose on my part..although it smelled great, so maybe not. All around very strong abbey.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2010 Bottled, 33cl. Deep reddish brown with a small beige head. Nice aroma with dried fruits, raspberry, black currant, spices and some alcohol notes. Flavor isnt bad too, with cellar notes, prunes, candi-sugar and a little bitterness. Sweet, lightly fizzy mouthfeel. Long-lasting bitterness in the finish. Rating: 7-3-7-4-15-3.6. 060322Bottle. Unclear, orange-brown body topped by a finger-thick beige head. Dried fruits, sugars and caramel on the nose. The flavor is sweet, with dried fruits and caramel. Some alcohol warmth, and a good bitterness towards the end. Full-bodied. A nice one indeed. 100409

330ml brown bottle. Colour is reddy/chestnut brown. Sparse tan head, light covering of tight bubbles on the surface. Raisin, fig newtons and dark malt with some sweetness in the aroma. Flavour is malty with more raisins and brown sugar. Malty finish with a bit of a nutty note, faint yeast. Remarkably mild carbonation, medium body.

Quality Dutch Trappist dubbel. Chestnut with a slight haze and a tall souffle-like beige head. Good head retention. Smells like a musty wine cellar  - jammy merlot, cobwebs, standing water (do cobwebs smell? Ah, what the hell.), plus faint molasses. Theres a spicy gingery note, too. I liked that aroma a lot. Come to think of it, it reminds me of the McLaren Vale shiraz from Saturday night. Medium bodied and very rounded. Soft carbonation - lovely. This is much more subtle than the bockbier. Theres some licorice root bite to the finish, but otherwise its a very smooth customer dominated by molasses and dried fruit. Quite peppery in the swallow with some burnt wood in the finishing mix. (30cl bottle, IBS Perth, bb Nov 2007)

Deep in color and flavor, with a body on the light to medium side.  Tastes of brown sugar or molasses, with maybe a hint of cherry or some other fruit lurking beneath.  Tasty in a subtle way, highly enjoyable.

Much foamy and bulky head, medium persistence. Much dark brown and impenetrable color. Elegant and darkest. Muh rich scent, extremely alcoholic with notes of parched malt, liqueur and wine cellar. Much stinging and lively taste; much perfumed and in the nose. Notes of cloves, licorice, alcohol and must. Long and persistent end.

Pours a deep reddish brown color with a nice and fluffy tan head. Aroma is strongly molasses with some banana poking through. Sweet malty flavor with hints of caramel, apple, and banana. Little too syrupy tasting to for my taste.  Thick beer with a lively palate. Not bad.
Brownish colour with a medium light brown creamy head. Aroma and taste of fruits and spices. Good palate.

Black in colour. Rich creamy beige head. The aroma consists of sweetly burnt malt with caramel. It has a sweet flavour of burnt malt and a sweet & sour aftertaste.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2006 Aroma is fairly sharp and features dark candied fruits, sweet breads and mild spicey notes. Opaque red/brown body holds a two finger thick, creamy tan head. Fore is candy sugar, yeast, spice, sweet bread, bannanas, apple, crusty churros and apple fritter crust. Quite damn flavorful with a very silky/creamy mouthfeel.

Think this was a bad bottle.  Would like to try again and re-rate at some time.  Pours dark almost black with no head.  Aroma was apples and other fruits with some spicey aftertaste.  No carbonation at all.
Pours a murky amber colour with a big white head. Very littel hops taste, but instead a fruity, spice taste that has a fullness

Agreed with Shag on the banana nut bread feel.  I found the aroma pleasant enough.  Got a few cloves and yeasty flavors out of it, some banana, and something a little darker... darker fruits maybe... something intangible perhaps.  Either way, excellent.

all though it was rather light on the palate this beer had full flavor.  A dicent malt mix of fruits, caramel and bread notes blended in smoothly on the inital taste, finishing with a mellow alcohol finish.

The beer poured a murky brown color with a large head. The aroma is dough, banana nut bread, and caramel. The flavor is rather sweet with a rather thin body. The flavor consists of nutmeg, caramel, nutmeg, and bananas. It was pretty good.
light brown color with a slight wash of dirty brown head.  large alcohol and egg aroma to it.  Smooth and smokey malts in this decent brew.

A tasty little devil that managed to restore my faith in the beers of the Kings Garden monastery of La Trappe. I obviously should have waited until I had tasted the four before rating them as this had the same toffee and caramel flavour similar to all of them, pity this was the only one that managed to balance it. Slowly poured it produced a wickedly dense and creamy, sandy beige head that settled in for the length and clung firmly to the glass. The body of beer a deep ruby red with the clarity of honey. Predominantly fruity aroma; zesty plums and berries, biting spices and a little nutmeg. Smooth and well rounded In the mouth with the dessert-style gooey toffee notes, which are initially quite pronounced, quickly balanced out with a mix of rich, dark chocolate, zesty cherries, burnt wood and slightly nutty, roasted malts. A light vinous note comes into play as it warms and follows through into the dry, malty bitter, chocolaty swallow that was easily the highlight of this one. It had after dinner beer written all over it. Not exactly one for a bender, but two or three would suit a good couple of hours as it was a delicious slow sipper. One of the best from this newly re-administered Trappist monastery. Lovely!!! (30cL, BBE 11/07, Intl Beer Shop, W. Leederville)

Dark brown. Small, short lived light tan head. Roasty malt, caramel, dark fruits, candi sugar, subtle alcohol-aroma. Flavors are rich malt, caramel/toffee, dark fruits, sugar, yeast. Roasty aftertaste. Medium body. Lighter than expected. Very smooth. Easy drinking. Nice brew.
La plus douce des trois abbeys, délicieuse et facile à boire. Impressionnant pour un pays que font Heineken.
Dark brown colour with a slim tan head. Fruity, sweet and malty aroma. Malty, caramel and liquorice flavour, also somewhat of a medicinal taste to it. Quite highly carbonated and medium bodied

Dark red body under a thin white ring of foam. Sweet licorice aroma with notes of anise, bread, and toffee, as well as some banana. Deep, strong, sweet taste of sourish wild berries (huh?), marzipan (just said it was sourish, didnt I?), and licorice. Aftertaste is vaguely bitter and roasty, with lingering sweetness. Some alcohol is detectable. A good dubbel, although perhaps a bit weak.

I had La Trappes dubbel on tap at In de Wildeman in Amsterdam, and took my time waiting for it to warm up. I noticed the fluffy beige head quickly reducing to a thin film, yet it produced amazingly sticky lacing - much like the Quadrupel. In fact the whole appearance was very reminiscent of its big brother, pouring a clear but deep ruby tone. The aroma as well hinted at the familiar pears and sweet cream found in La Trappes showpiece. However the key element in the nose was a strong dried banana fragrance, almost like opening a package of bar mix. In the blend I also found coffee, white raisins and pine, maybe even coniferous sap. The flavor reverberated the dried fruit aroma, especially banana and white raisins which are immediately apparent. The velvety palate and soft carbonation complement the flavor and provide smooth texture that finishes on a sweet creamy note.
Bottle 33cl. Nice dark mahogany colour. Creamy brown head. Aroma of oak and maple syrup. Quite sweet, moderate bitter taste. Medium long aftertaste. All in one a very pleasant beer.
Pours ruby red with a thin tan head.  Smells of cherries, grapes, raisins, and roses.  Taste is sugary with sweet cherry notes,

pours a reddish-bronze color with a decent sized creamy beige head, aroma of belgian style spices, citrusy fruit, and yeast. the flavor is caramel-like and sweet, with a small yeasty bitter finish. good crisp tasting beer.

Bottled, creamy light brown head,
light sirup aroma.Harmonic Sweet and
round.
Bottle. Creamy light brown head. Red unclear body.  Sweet spicy aroma. Caramel fruit flavor. No bitterness at all.

Looked quite nice when poured into the glass, medium size beige head on top of a deep ruby red body. Aroma is brown sugar then spice then dark fruit. Yeast stands out a bit more in the taste, some burnt meaty notes, light to medium in body, warming alcohol and a touch herbal.

Bottle shared with blankboy at Volo.  Dark brown, small slick white head.  Very sweet aroma - nutty.  Sweet taste, syrupy, yeast.  Nice, but simple and straight forward.  Pretty flat really.  Some bitterness at the end.  Alcohol as it warms.  Enjoyable, but nothing spectacular.

Bottle shared with tupalev at Bar Volo. Pours a murky reddish-brown with a small diminishing off-white head. Aroma of dark fruit, brown sugar, yeast, spices and alcohol. The flavour follows the aroma and is quite sweet. Thin bodied. Its O.K. but it used to be much better.

11.2 oz bottle:  This one pours a cloudy, opaque mahogany brown color.  There was almost no head on it, and it died off immediately.  The aroma is quite nice.  Many fruity scents in there, notably raisins, plums, and some others.  The taste is quite good also.  It is a tad sweet, and mainly consists of brown sugar, some caramel, a hint of alcohol, bananas and bit of yeastiness and breadiness.  A full rich flavor.  A very nice dubbel.

25.4oz bottle coded 09:16 K23K1. I have had this bottle in the cellar for 3-6 months. Served at 50° in my NB worthy glass. Reddish brown color, light bubbly haze, some floaties. Aroma is brown sugar, spice, banana bread, raisins, and dark fruits. The aroma seems similar to their quad. Smells really good. Full mouthfeel. The initial taste is dark brown sugar, raisins, plums, prunes, yeast, vanilla followed by the more of the same flavors along with some spicy bitterness and mild alcohol. The mouthfeel thins at the end. This is a good dubbel, but is not up to par with the belgian examples of the style.

Clear brown ale with  a creamy white head. Sweet caramel aroma with orange, nuts, and smooth alcohol. In mouth, tingly soices come out over the sweet candy malt, with light alcohol notes. Bottle at Pub Italia.

11.2 oz bottle, gift pack w/ a glass purchased 12/23/05:  Lasting beige head on a mohogany brown, hazy body.  Aroma is metallic, buttery (diacetyl from age), earthy and leathery.  This stuff is OLD!!!!!!!!  Some raisiny dark fruit, but mosty just old and buttery!  Well balanced, raisiny, buttery, toasty malt, and  a bit of alcohol flavor.  Higher carbonation, lighter med. body, and smooth.  Not the beer I imagined, but then again, it seems sort of old!!!  Will re rate if I get a better, more fresh bottle!!!!

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2006 Im all about the Beligians but I think I got a spoiled bottle here. It reeked of must old cellar and sewage and tasted about the same. Some Chimay-like notes shined through now and again, but the overall musty character was too much. Ill definitely give it another shot.

ReRate 06/19/2006: Still innundated with a musty cellar aroma, but no sewage tones. Similar to a lighter bodies Chimay, it just does not have the style or delivery of its contemporary. Dissapointing.
Dark red-brown colour, heavy aroma, herby some caramel. Yeast.  smouth and creamy palate, bitter and herby finish.

Dark brown beer with some red tones and a huge beige and creamy head with good retention. Aroma is pleasant, fruity and rich in malt with apples, pears, banana and small hints of nougat. Flavor is surprisingly bittersweet with notes of coffee, bitter chocolate and hazelnuts. Texture is a little thin but the mouthfeel is very good. Aftertaste is long and more bitter than sweet. Great with cheeses!.
11.2 fl oz bottle.  Dark red beer.  banana aroma.  Nice carbonation.  Smooth beer to drink.

Better than the Blond at least. Dark reddish brown body with a small fizzy head and absolutely no lacing. Berry dominates the aroma and flavor. I cant stand their yeast strain, it makes their beers like a musty basement. Not much for hops here. Blah.
This abbay dubbel has much more flavor than the one I tried yesterday. Nice dubbel beer of the trappist brewery Koningshoeven. Long lasting light brown head, dark body. Excellent beer!

Bottle: Poured a dark brown color ale with a medium off-white foamy head with average retention. Aroma of sugary malt with some Belgian type yeast. Taste is really good with a nice mix between sweet caramel malt and fresh cookie with a touch of Belgian yeast. The mouthfeel is a creamy but also watery and I believe this is the main default of this beer. Body is way too thin for the style.

Nose is great - gentle and sweet with strong banana overtones.  Very low carb with a weak head.  Taste is a nice, unchallenging Dubbel with the typical Trappist/Abbey complexity.  Finish lets it down a little with a flat and soapy quality a bit, but generally a fine abbey ale.

33 cl bottle. Yeast in the bottle. Reddish brown colour with a nice rocky head. Lovely aroma of sugar, dried fruit and some caramel. Nice flavour of complexity with toffee and raisins, but not so good as the aroma. Ends up with a warm feeling from the alcohol.
UPDATED: FEB 20, 2006 Dark ruby brown colour. Lasting tanned head. Fruity flavour leading to a gentle bitter finish. OK beer.

Whole Foods, Baton Rouge, La. - 11.2 oz bottle. Pours a very thick, dark chestnut brown with a very thick, creamy eggnog colored head. Thik, molasses like aroma with some chewing tobacco notes and a hint of alcohol. Flavor has plenty of dates, raisins, baked brown bread, sweet ripe cherries and a hint of alcohol. Tastes like a dopplebock. Creamy mouthfeel, strong finish.

Pours a nice dark red with a diminishing head. Aroma is banana candy with a hint of spice. Tastes of banana bread with a slight nutty quality (maybe from pouring the yeast?) and touches of sugar candy, licorice. Some bit of spiciness in the finish serves to balance the sweet aroma and flavor. Fizzy feel with a little alcohol burn. Fairly yummy Trappist brew.
Not one of my first choices for a dubbel, but not bad overall. Not too sweet and fairly smooth.

(bottle) Clear and dark, slightly hazy  red-amber colour with a mid-sized foamy tanned head. Dusty yeasty and sweet malty aroma with liquorice and cassis. Medium body, moderate carbonation, light bitter flavour. Moderately sweet toastmalty taste with fruits and a touch of bubblegum, light dry and moderately bitter aftertaste with notes of liquorice.

Bottle, in NL.
Ruby brown with small beige head. Aroma heavy malty (cokies, raisins, brown sugar, licorice), moderate hoppy. Flavour heavy sweet, moderate bitter. Medium body, oily, soft carbonated, the alcohol is felt. Very nice dubbel.

Bottled. Ruby brown colour, small beige head. Aroma of lum, raisins, licorace, weakalcohol and some other things. Flavour of sweet cookies, raisins, licorace and weak sting of alcohol. Also some bitterness and sourness noted. Lovely palate, except that the carbonation is a bit hard.

Aroma:caramel and fruit,nuts..
Appearance:dark brown,light head...
Flavor:caramel,nuts....
Very good....

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2006 Little  tan head and short lasting. Dark amber red  colour. Dark malt, caramel and dried fruity nose. Sweet and spicy flavour, again with dried fruit: raisins and brown sugar. Medium bodied. Sweet/ sour finish but no distinct bitterness.

Bottled. Ruby brown colour, small beige head. Aroma of lum, raisins, licorace, weakalcohol and some other things. Flavour of sweet cookies, raisins, licorace and weak sting of alcohol. Also some bitterness and sourness noted. Lovely palate, except that the carbonation is a bit hard.

50cl stone crock from Morrisons.  Attractive ruby colour with lasting beige head. Lovely hedgerow fruit aromas. Some good yeast as well. Good burst of yeasty hoppy herb in mouth but soft mouthfeel too. Finish has more brambley fruit and spicey hop tang and some really nice chocolate. Yes like this and far better than the blond

A very nice dubbel from La Trappe. Aroma is the highlight of the beer, being very hearty and robust, with artichoke, plum, cherry, a little sweetness. Pours a dark brown with a nice head that quickly fades, leaving a little lacing. Taste is veggies, belgian malt flavors, caramel, a bit of cocoa perhaps. Palate is nice but could be a good bit creamier.

Poured a reddish brown color with a thin, tan head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of figs, caramel malt, cherries, rum, raisins, spices, and light citrus.  Taste of caramel malt, some nuts, roast, dried fruits and alcohol as well.  Lively carbonation.  Thanks BrianO!

Bottle. Thanks to Pailhead for this! Cant believe I havent rated this yet. It hasnt been available in my area in at least 2 years, so that may be the reason, but Ive had this more times than I can count "back in the day". Pours a muddled reddish brown with a small tan head. Nose is malty and sweet with lots of raisins, figs, and perhaps cherries. Light cocoaa and hints of caramel. Taste is rich and chewy. Big sweet maltiness, caramel, more dark fruits (raisins, figs and maybe prunes), hints of cocoa and light hints of alcohol. Body is moderately carbonated with some smoothness at times. Finishes much the way it began - dark fruits, sweet malts, cocoa, light alcohol notes. Nice stuff and seemingly much like I recall from days past!

A Mes rate: 
Aroma is almost overwhelmingly of seafood and particularly mussels. Comes through in the flavour too. Soap suds and a little too bland in the mouthfeel. Iron filings in the flavour and a hint of sweetness at the finish. Nothing special at all and not a patch on their quad (or their blond for that matter). There are MUCH better dubbels.

Corked crock bottle. Deep clear red with a small head, aroma is sweet and mulled.Taste is ever so slightly...yes plasticy? It could be the bottle though, i bought 2 and the 1st one opened (this is the 2nd) was as flat as a witches tit, so it got poured.

Corked bottle. Pours a brown color with a thin off white head. Nose is yeasty, brown sugar, caramel, bready, and light alcohol. Taste is smooth, some light cinnamon, dark fruits and a nice touch of alcohol.

Bottle (330ml).  At Ciros - bottle probably 2 years old.  Poured flat light active brown with a huge flock of white floaties and a thin off-white head.  Aroma very yeasty, brown sugar / caramel malt, plenty of spices (cloves, nutmeg, pepper), raisins and prunes, alcohol - overall very sweet rich malty but a touch sour to my nose.  Taste is on the light side but very smooth, sweet roast candy malts, ripe apple, plum, apricot, spices (cloves, cinnamon, coriander), hardly any hop or alcohol bitterness - lovely, the yeasties dont detract at all.  Mouthfeel very lively, a bit sticky-sweet.  Apart from the visual detraction of the yeasties, a solid abbey dubbel.

Beer No 28 on the Wilsons Road Trip 2005. 500ml ceramic crock from Waitrose, Bath. Reddish brown, fair persistant head. Malty caramel spice aroma, not terribly complex. Thick mouthfeel, a little sweet for my taste. Chocolatey roasty sweet finish. Second pour reveals some cloudiness - appears more bottle conditioned than the tripel I sampled. Fairly standard dubbel - obviously professionally produced, but just not as complex as the real trappists.

Beautiful clean amber with a thin whitish head that leaves some lace. A heady mix of malt and a hint of spice hit s the nose, while the palate gets a complex array of flavours, with a rather sweet malt character dominating, and some fruit appearing at the end. A cracking brew. Morrison Hawick.
One of the 5 beers in the world still brewn in a monastery. Very good aroma. Perfect example of a good dubbel beer.

22 May 2005 - (Pub in Sevenum) - Strong hoppy malt aroma.  Cloudy brown-red colour colour, brown creamy head with suds lacing. Lighter sweet malt flavour than I expected, with melt in the mouth flavours.  Not overly sweet palate, resulting in a dry finish and a bit thin.  Overall - Lacks some oomph.
(Bottle 33 cl) Dark brown coffeish appearance with a handsome, creamy head. Very dry notes of roasted malt and - again - coffee. Pronounced bitterness and a touch of acid. 240599

Mohagany body is clear except for a few stray rafts of yeast. Small, frothy cream-colored head. Pungent aroma of figs, dark candy sugar, red wine, prunes, and a note of leather. Flavor comes across like a sweet liqueur with lots of fig and molasses. Lingering flavor of dark fruit skins which seems to contribute some bitterness. Medium full, sweet palate with chewy texture. A good dubbel.

The bottle poured a dark amber-brown beverage with a medium sized, creamy, beige head. The head didnt last very long and didnt leave any lacing. Unfortunately, I didnt know this was bottle conditioned and allowed sediment to get into my glass clouding things up. There was plentiful rich sweet fruity aroma with a slight spicy alcohol aroma. It had a medium body with a smooth texture and light carbonation. The flavor started off with rich malt, dried fruit flavors and a slight hint of clove. The finish was long and warm with a slight hint of pepper.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2013 Bottle from Stirchley Wines and Spirits, Birmingham. Rather darl brown, with only the preliminary sketch of a head. Smells like tobacco and tar. Petrol start then a plasticky, tepid veg, finishing on a sweet (oversweet) pastey wheat. Like a liquified plastic bag in fact. An uneven blend of none-too pleasant notes. I expect better from anything labelling itself a Dubbel. (original rating 25th July 2005). RE-RATED 23 May 2013. >> I must have been off my head when I scored this beer so low, way back in 2005. Tonight, I have supped a 500ml ceramic bottle of the stuff and I love it! I love Dubbels generally and this is a classic one - sweet, faint leather, molasses, feint heat from the alc. LOVE IT. REALLY REALLY GOOD>

Bottled.
Cloudy brown coloured with a beige head.
Sweet spicy aroma with notes of fruits.
Sweet flavour of fruits especially bananas and spices with notes of tobacco and alcohol.

Pours deep amber with thin tan head.  Nose is faint floral and soapy notes.  I see lots of "chocolate" ratings here.  I dont taste any... just dark fruits (figs, dates, plum), apple, and yeasty spice.  Rather thin, and                                                                                                                water aftertaste.  OK but not my favorite Dubbel.

Definitely a trappist beer (although Dutch).  Deep brown Ale with caramel chocolate taste.  Very smooth and strong.  Not as strong as some of its trappist brothers but in  the vein definitely.

Available at Downtown Wine & Spirits in Somerville, MA
Strong malt hop aroma. Dark brown colour with good head served in a very fancy glass! Smooth malt flavour. Fizzy palate.
Poured real dark with some sweet aromas.flavors of dark fruit like figs and some hints of chocolate, not much but slight.This was warming going down.very delicious

33 cl bottle, bbe June 2001 (thus, 4 years over date). Deep chestnut brown, murky and turbid, large and quite stable creamy beige head. Apparently not much sediment. Aroma of caramel and brown candy sugar with a sharp (a bit worn) estery note and a hint of chocolate. Flavour is soft, smooth and mellow, with prevailing chocolate, light tart and very subtly bitter. The tooth of time can be felt in the slight oxidation. Creamy and rich palate in the beginning, finishing with a light kefir (fermented milk drink originating in the Caucasus)-like prickleness.
Good beers like this would make for the best hair color colors.  Maroon color with a foamy head.  Prickly in the mouth with a tasty sweetness.

Wow, one super nice dark reddish color with a thick head and an appetizing fruity nose.  Very fizzy mouthfeel at first, but that slides away very quickly and is replaced by a medium-bodied maltyness.  Some cherry flavors in there as well.

Deep crimson with a large, soft head.  The aroma jumps from the tulip - cherry, apple, banana and sweet candy blend nicely.  More fruitiness quickly mixes with bitter chocolates before moving into a rather bland, disappointing finish. The body seems slightly stunted, as the flavors dont really develop fully.

Bottle:  Strong aroma caramel and raspberries with a slight chocolate note as well.  Pours a deep reddish-brown with lots of sediment.  Small off-white head quickly fades to a ring.   Lots of caramel and malt up front with a lightly tart raspberry finish.  Leaves a lightly tart and lightly hopped aftertaste.

Lovely dark red, almost brown color and a thin head on top.  Aroma is of dark fruits, fig and raisin, and a yeasty sweet bread, a-la trappistness.  Palate is very gentle, all around smooth but a tiny bit of alcohol presense.  Flavor is very hearty.  Heavy in the bread and dark fruit section.  Damn tastey Trappist offering.
Maroon red body with basically no head.  Sweet aroma with a slight raspberry taste.  Very thin palate.

Very little head and very very fine carbonation. Sweet honey like taste w/ a little earthy muskiness. Can taste the aclohol, but it isnt dominating. Very well balanced. This would be a good beer to introduce someone to a Tappist ale.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2005 [bottle from tesco with Magic_dave6] Nose was very fruits of the foresty, quite sweet , but still light,  with a little spiceyness. Body was a little thin, but had a certain liveliness.

Great bottle, like a clay jug, good start.
Apperance, a bit thinner than more trappist dubbels, but very nice all the same.
Aroma is just another trappist ale, which i may be bias on since i love all trappist ales there is.
Taste is wonderful, maybe thinner and less complex than others of this style, but dark fruits, wheat, alround goodness, im so glad i found this.
Alround great beer, not hitting any new levels of goodness as there r better out there, but nice and refreshing to see a trappist ale that u can have a few of without falling off your seat.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2006 This was an early favorite of mine, but it has not held up well as my beer experience has grown.  I suspect as well that this beer is not what it once was. Sampled from a 25 oz brown bottle this beer poured an opaque dark brown with lots of little floaters and a huge tan head. The aroma is musty, sweet, and has a molasses element.  The flavor is sweet with molasses and has a yeasty tang. There is a light fruitiness and some vanilla and chocolate. The mouthfeel is thick and creamy.

Pours turbid burnt sienna, with aroma of dark fruit, Brett, some hops, horse blanket, female gymnast feet.  Tastes caramel malty, with dark fruit (figs, cherry), some spices.  A Belgian Bretty and caramel finish provides some dopplebockish finishing notes.

Perhaps because its the first beer of this style that I have rated, I was quite taken aback by the aroma, an eclectic mixture of peppermint, old leather saddles and dusty books in libraries... and the seaside. Frankly it didnt look too great, but the taste ... I just dont have the vocabulary to put it in words...

The flavour is here, but its rather erm...watery? Kind of a taste killah. Towards the bottom the german rock candy throws any balance out the door. Best thing about it is its appearence and ease of drinking.
Bland and disappointing. A bit one-dimensionally sweet. Despite what the name implies, not a Trappist product.

Pours hazy maroonish-brown under a thin, whispy weak head. Pleasing aromas of rum, spices, raisin, fig, yeast and plum. First sip reveals a quite thin and watery palate for a Dubble which is disappoinitng. Sweet flavors of dark fruit, honey and caramel come through cleanly, but are too subdued and short-lived. A very drinkable Belgian Dubble, but lacks any complexity or depth.
Poured a murky brownish red color with a medium head.  sweet  aroma of fruits and spices. Flavor follows suit with a heavy dark fruit flavor of beets, figs etc.  medium to light mouthfeel.
found this one a bit sweet and cloying....much fruit on the back door of bananas and spice, tobacco, and too much rock candy.  we know which one is the best.....4 ring a bell.

Pours a reddish brown color with a thin offwhite head that leaves decent lacing on the glass. Decent but simple aroma of malt with caramel and chocolate. The flavor is similar, malt, caramel and chocolate but with mild alcohol vapors. Light to medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation (unlike La Trappe blond). Its ok but I feel theres something missing.

Bottle , temp too dam cold!This was my third dubbel at the local pub.This was almost a clone of the grimbergen dubbel
It was a sweet malty brew with some yeasty notes,lots a raisins and caramel
A little too sweet.It had a medium to full mouthfeel ample carbonation a very good beer but pricey.The Westmalle was 8 the Latrappe 7 and the grimbergen 5
in dollars.Since they are all served way too cold for noting complexities the Grimbergen wins!

Cloudy and rust in color with a loose and quickly falling tan head. Pleasant aroma of figs, vanilla, brown sugar. Fruity flavor with caramel and spice. A bit of a dopplebock flavor. Clean finish with a somewhat thin body, though very drinkable.
I normally like this style and judging from the other ratings, other people do also.  There was just something wrong with this beer.  It just wasnt what I expected.

This used to be so good.....Murky ruddy brown hue.  Bubbly fine head, mostly lasting, pale tan hue.  Nose of raspberry, bubblegum, esters, phenols, cocoa, rum.  These flavors follow through on the palate, but this is missing something.  The magic touch perhaps.  Sweetness is overpowering, caramel, dark candy sugar, rummy notes.  Fizzy mouthfeel, and slightly boring finish.  What happened to the Dubbel of my underage years?

In the 750 ml bottle. Pours a rich brown with a thick beige head. Aroma of raisens and chocholate. Body is a little lighter than it should be, but not by much. A good warm complex ale with a fruity strong flavor. Decent alcohol mouth for such a mid-range abv.
(Bottle)  Pours a dark brown body (w/ mahogany highlights) and an average-sized beige head.  Aroma of mustiness, raisins, and sweet malts.  Flavor of raisins and plum.  Smooth mouthfeel.

Bottle:  Pours a hazy chestnut with a small-bubbled off-white head.  Bready yeast and dark fruits in the aroma, full bodied with light carbonation and a slight stickiness, starts and ends sweet with a long rich aftertaste.

Pure brown with a small brownish head. A littel sour cherry on the nose though a bit faded. Med weight with a light sweetness. THough a bit old its softend up bit and the rich nuttiness is still aparrent. Yum!

750ml bottle, cork lacked the usually ensuring "pop" to it when removed, so I poured fast and got a one finger head which lasted mere seconds. I could tell the beer was a bit flat so my example likely isnt the best. The colour was murky brown. Taste was simple compared to the Belgian dubbels. Malty and orange dominate flavour, lacks bitterness and body. Easy drinking though, I think a good bottle take take my ratings upa couple of points..will give it a re-rate down the road.
From a small bottle.Dark blood and brown in colour.Little head.Old wine and north african fruits,strong malt.Computer says no.

Tea colored. smells of figs, plums, dark fruits and mayhaps some malt. taste was the same. very balanced like the blond, just darker, beefier flavors, same sweetness. right on par with each other. the tastes of heavy fruits mixed in with just a very slight bitterness and candy hints.

A very dark brown with a thin yellowish head. Light aroma of a sweet red wine and some apples. Not much else to detect. The taste is a dry pear and cinnamon. Appropriate for the style, but I am not a big fan of the style. Decent if you lke dubbels.

As Hunsell said this is a great supermarket beer. The head lasted well in the glass, everything worked well for me.

Also used it as an ingredientin a steak pie, worked well. :)

bottle from the gift pack with glass.  Looks great in the gold rimmed glass, dark red brown but little head.  Aroma of dark fruits and malt.  Flavor of bananas and raisin.  A little hoppy with a slightly bitter finish.  I love the taste, even better than the Chimay Rouge.  Quite flavorful and excellent.  A rater from the Netherlands says its a great supermarket beer..  I can only dream of such a quality brew showing up in a supermarket here in the vast beer desert of North Florida.
Poured brown with a thin off white head.  Aroma of dark fruits, bready, yeasty.  Flavors of raisins, plums, and malt.  Light to medium bodied.

Pours dark transparent brown with little head. Yeasty malt aroma with slight hint of banana. Flavor is banana with maybe some raisin? Very well balanced but did not have that syrupy feeling of a dubbel.
Very accessible and great for a supermarketbeer. Sweet bananataste, maybe a bit onedimensional but surely a nice dubbel.

Extraordinaire saveur de chocolat doux. Que dire de plus que cest bon. Ça me semble un bière de dessert. Comme cest la première fois que je la goute et que je ne semble pas être en accord avec mes collègues den bas, il va falloir que jen ouvre une autre pour être certain.
What aboring dubbel? Sweet rasin toffee aroma with similar flavour. Lacks any depth or complexity. Smooth medium mouthfeel. Not bad but really not a great beer.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2007 Been wanting to try this one for a long time now. Bottle says K12J2. Im assuming thats Oct. 02. Great aroma. Really nice smooth finish. Slightly dry & fruity but WAY WAY too sweet. Couldnt finish it.

GOOD stuff Maynard,Typical pour. Great nose of chocolate,dark malt with mild yeast background,hints of dark fruit.
Tastes like it smells except has a slightly dryish finish which takes it down a tad.Not a St.Bernardus but pretty damn tasty.

Bottle conditioned. Brown chestnut with tan head. Deliberately aged 3 yrs. Full rich winey beer with dark fruits and a sweet apple background. Sl sugary throughout with a dark malty roasted flavour. Plenty of alcohol though a slightly oily finish. Smashing beer.
Hazy with some sediment.  Very rich, sweet aroma and taste.   Malty and wine flavours.  Tasted more like a 10% than the 6.5% that is listed.  Drink one of these and your finished for the night.

Dark brown colour with a slim tan head. Fruity, sweet and malty aroma. Malty, caramel and liquorice flavour, also somewhat of a medicinal taste to it. Quite highly carbonated and medium bodied. Not bad.

Gotten for a song at Premier Gourmet, made a great sharing with a business assocaite. While not as tasty as complex as the quad and trippel, it was tod rink slowly form like a fine wine. Strong alcohol and quality yeast aroma. Winish red-auburn colour. Initial head and retained thin lace. Moderate malt, with raspberry mid-sip.

Poured deep reddish brown with thin tan head...smelled musty and prunes and raisins...taste is smooth with little carbonation...raisins, yeast...something is off though and I cant put my finger on it...bizarre finish too...

Draft in Amsterdam. Tan head, excellent lacing, uncarbonated, almost opaque, and a reddish brown hue. Malty, caramel and licorice notes in the aroma. Malt and mild licorice in the flavor. Smooth mouthfeel. Medium bodied beer.

The DM & Hotstuffs European Honeymoon trip beer number 106.   This bottled brew poured a small head of medium sized brown colored bubbles that left behind a good lacing.  The body contained no visible carbonation, was nearly opaque and dark brown in color.  Its aroma contained notes of strong vinous dark malty smoky scents with a touch of licorice .  Its mouth feel is initially strong smooth and vinous with a lingering  flavorful finish.  Its flavor contained good dark malty roasted  notes and was tasty.  All-in-all very nice brew.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2005 A dark reddish-brown body with a yellowed brown head, this has a dried fruit aroma with sweet malt undertones.  Its got a sweet/sour flavor with a definitie alcohol presence.  Nice medium body.  Tart finish.  Not bad.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Oak Lawn, IL<font size=-1>
Off-white long-lasting thick head. Red-brown clour, bittersweet flavour, fruity aftertaste. It is as much a pleasure to contemplate as to drink it.

A good dubbel, particularly after its been aged for a few years or so.  Otherwise this one can be a bit harsh, almost like Chimay Blanche somehow (which is odd).  Over time, though, this beer becomes at least as smooth as any decent triple-style beer.

Bottle, Best By 10/98. Man, was this awesome. Light bodied, smooth, tasty with just a touch of oxidation but it worked well. Mellow dried fruit taste. The aroma is like sticking your nose into a box of raisens. I wish I had another.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2007 Pours hardly any head so no lace.  Cloudy amber color.  Light-medium carbonation.  Medium bodied.  Nose is distinctly raisins, starts sweet but not cloying, finishes smooth and mellow.  Another excellent trappist.  750ml bottle for $7.99 from Hoosick St. Discount Bev, Troy, NY.

From my notes 6/6/2007 pours one-finger light tan head that fades quickly to a ring leaving a good lace.  Deep mahogany color.  Caramel nose.  Light-medium carbonation and medium bodied. Flavor is a nutty brown and some caramel.  On-tap for 2.40 ($3.29) for a 250ml chalice from Corner House Cafe Amsterdam, NL

(4 Jul 04) Dark brown/black liquor with ruby undertones and a large, creamy light brown head with excellent lacing.  The aroma is lightly alcoholic with notes of raisins and a heavy malty caramel.  The full and alcoholic body is oily and creamy with a slight chalky finish.

Reddish brown,not quite the robin red they describe,just a bit of head.some fizzles.Does have a nice blend of maltiness but also some sweer syruoy tones and lets not forget fruits inhtere also.Alcohol is that of a bigger beer.Maybe because the flavor it should have isnt quite as distinctive as it should be.Not all that impressed.soyur aftertaste.

Reddish tinted dark brown beer; yellowish-brown head, dissipating. Liquorice, mint, thick green leaves, blackcurrant, rich malts. Sweet, malty and woody at the same time. Liquorice, and a particular kind of sweet I used to know, blackcurrant flavoured. Nice flavour, but very simple, missing depth and complexity. Medium bodied, bit slick. Long sweetish-perfumed aftertaste. OK beer, but too one-sided for a Trappist, that ought to mean excellence;

Brown with mid-size tan head. Sweet
malt and fruity aroma. Flavor of dark
fruits and a sweet malt finish. Very little
hop bitterness.

Big head upon pouring, with a dark brown apearance.The head soon subsides. Taste is slightly nutty, with a very pleasant texture and lasting aftertaste. All round a very pleasant and well balanced beer.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2006 Draught
Dark ruby brown, lots of lace, not much head. Fruity, sahti-like banana nose. Sweet, banana flavor, a bit fuller body  than in Blonde. (7/4/7/3/14 3.5).

Re-rate, bottled (BB 01/2009).
Dark ruby color, big tan head. Raisins, brown sugar and some metal in the nose. Carbonated mouthfeel. Brown sugar, raisins and plums in the flavor. A bit too simple as "trappist dubbel" but drinkable. (6/4/7/3/13 3.3)

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2006 (Bottled) Hazy Coca-Cola color with a small, tanned, lasting head. Dunkelweizen-like aroma of caramel, banana fruitiness, yeast, some roasted malt, and hints of licorice. Quite acidic and roasted-malty, neutral flavor with hints of coffee and iron, plus an ashy, dry finish. A bit thin and ashy, light to medium-bodied palate with foamy carbonation. Very easily drinkable with no signs of alcohol. A quite weird combination of Schwarzbier, Abbey Dubbel, Sahti, and Dunkelweizen. Like the Blonde, its not quite up to the Trappist standards, IMO.
(Draught, rated 8/22/2004, was 7-5-7-4-14=3.7) Very nice, deep dark red color with a medium, beige head. Sweetish, malty banana-candy aroma. Very sweet, quite malty and fruity flavor with banana. Quite full-bodied, sugary palate with well-balanced carbonation. A quite nice, sahti-like dubbel.
Aroma has dried fruits, is winey and fruity. Taste has sourness, spices and a apple or cider note.
Dark brown. Ghost of a head maintained across the surface. Sharp nose. Alcohol up front and then fades. Malty and smooth.

duvel tulip glass: very dark ruby. brown, tight, and slightly rocky head. spicy, tart, and fruity flavor; slight caramel and slight raisin. medium body. refreshing. i feel that i sampled this brew at the wrong time. this reminds me of a very fruity brown ale. i prefer the quad. my palate had lasted touched Midas Touch by DH.
UPDATED: OCT 16, 2004 Red color, light sweet fruity aroma, spicy taste, medium body, sweet, to sweet finish.
Pours a nice red colour with a complex, spicy aroma. Taste is less exciting but still good, with spice, roast and hops nicely balanced.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2004 330ml Bottle. Not bad, easily bettered by other Trappist Abbey Dubbels I have had (Westmalle Dubbel, Chimay Red). A quarter of the bottle shot out of the top on opening, so didn't get to try the complete bottle. However, I drank enough to realise that this is sweet and fruity, with some spiciness. Decent beer, nothing compared to the Trappists though.
Nice red colour with very small head, looks almost as a glass of red wine. Aroma is sweet with lots of fruit. Flavor is very, very sweet, to sweet for my taste.
Nice deep copper red color with a nice tan head. Raisiny aroma, nice and pleasant. Fruity flavor up front but then really dry. Thin palate.

Has an 11:00 on the 750 ml bottle. Nov 2000? Pours a clear reddish brown with a tan head. Raisin aroma and pleasant. Big raisiny fruity flavor up front, but dries out quick with a wierd aftertaste. A little on the thin side.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Bottle: Cola colored deep brwon with fizzy off-white head and some lace. The aroma haas notes of caramel and smoked malts, raisin, prune, aromatic hops, brown sugar, and meaty. The taste starts very fruity with banana, prune, and black currents on top of a malt and suger base.  The finish displays a nice smoky and bitter nature with provides good balance. Could have more depth however. The feel is lively and crisp, thin-bodied. Overall a quaffable and refereshing trappist beer. Not earth shaking, but worth a try.

An old favorite, and, dagnabbit, I always stick by my first loves...
Deep cherry red color, creeping into a purple, and a great, creamy, long-lasting head. The aroma is thick, full and rich with fruit, fresh and uplifting, citrusy, soft, and vinous (meaning:grapey, grapey, grapey). Lively alcoholic notes, but,still thoroughly mellow. Texture is also delicious, and smooth, and, well, this is not too complex, actually juuuust right. Extraordinarily drinkable. This is deep, rich, full, utterly delicious, with a long and lovely finish. Small bitterness, huge, sweet, malt component. Spicy, and smooth, and, well, not dazzling, but dependably delightful.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2007 Ruddy brown colour beer with long lasting off white head.  The aroma is malty, smells like malt loaf with currants, raisins and spices.  The taste is similar with the yeastiness coming through.  A good beer but lacks a little depth.

Only my second dubbel so I dont have a lot to compare it to.  Pours a somewhat clear brown color with a smooth and decently lasting head.  Aroma is primarily malt, with notes of ginger and nutmeg.  Surprisingly complex taste, with malt, spice, caramel, raisin, yeast and bananna.  Spicy, bubblegum finish.  Interesting.
Pours redish brown, with aromas of bananas, spice and fruit. Taste is bananas, fruit, and brown sugar. Body is a little too thin.

Spicey aroma of burnt bananas, some plastics and some fuel, along with a bready cardamom aroma.  Palate is bubbly and full, a little sharp in the flavor.  Bananas and graham crackers and wheat.  Not bad.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2004 Bottle Conditioned. BBE May 2005. A dark red/orange beer, slight lasting white head. Fruity, slightly sweet, pleasent alcohol (not overpowering), slightly spicy. Suprisingly full bodied for the ABV. Very good beer, that is perhaps underrated due to its loss of trappist status.
Really tasty, but nothing compared to other dubbels. A good starter in the style.
La unica cerveza que conozco "de abadia" holandesa. Esta rica pero no llega alas belgas.

Nice dark color and long lasting head. Aroma strongly fruity. A little bland but very fruity and banana flavor. Some bitternes in the end makes a great balance with all sweetness. Leaves nice warm feeling to mouth.
poured brown little head no lacing sweet fruity with some malt.sweet tasting with a bit of bitterness some raisin. soft mouth feel. this is one of those beers that you want to enjoy once in a while

Deep red-brown hue.
Fruity aroma with tones of apricots.
A bit stale flavor with typical belgian acidic and almond tones.
Deep red/amber.  yeasty-sweet fresh nose.  The taste is a bit tart, and it feels a bit thin in the mouth.  Still worth the tasting.
Cloudy dark brown color with a medium beige head. Clove, fresh cut grass, metal and malt aroma. Sweet clove, grass, and malt flavors. Very tingly feel.

Deep, dark brown color with a medium (quickly dissipating) beige head. The aroma and flavor were of clove, grass, metal, and some brown sugar...pretty sweet. The feel was crisp, small bubbles...medium thick.

Bottled. Not a headknocker, but pleasant enough. Cream colored head itself has nice, spicy, candy taste. Nice brown beer with orange highlights, shows bubbles drifting up as sediment settles down. Taste brings out oranges, raisins, a bit of wine and light spiciness, on a well-warmed, rather that roasted, malt base. Comes off like a fresh barley wine. May not be the very best of its kind, but darn close, and its alcohol warmth makes a nice way to break a Lenten abstinence of over a month (and circumstances kept me away from home where I had a store of actual Trappist ales to enjoy on Easter. This was a good substitute).

33 cl bottle, served in Westmalle chalice.
Pours a deep reddish-brown. Decent head that rapidly fades. The aroma is full of pleasant fruitiness (banana, kiwi?). Taste-wise it's well rounded, again w/ banana up front, and a soft, pleasant maltiness. Nice mouthfeel and very good drinkability.
A fine dubbel, better than most I've tried.

Pours a murky amber brown body and a plume of kaki colored head. The nose is deep with malts and fruits… toasted wheat bread and apricot preserves. The flavor has lengthy notes of a buttery caramel, plums, apples, dates, and some raisins. It’s rather beady and yeasty, the toasty malts bring out a chocolaty likeness along with some coconut milk similarities. The palate is nice, it could be more creamy, but its buttery and inviting. 
 A good Trappist brew, but I want more intensity from the Quad I’m about to open!
Slightly complex fruity aroma, maybe a bit of smoke... Beautiful body... Very smooth round taste... Nice Aftertaste

Pours dark amber with a small tan head.  Aroma is sweet, dried cherries, spice.  Flavor is is sweet, cherries, plums and yeast.  Not much  hops but a little acid to try to balance.  Not bottle conditioned, so lacks the complex flavor and power that I love about the style.  Not a bad intro to the Belgian style, but way too generic for Dubbel fans.

12oz bottle that has the Koningshoeven label yet embossed with LaTrappe. Poured a reddish brown and clear with a thick head that reduces quickly to a thin film that is dense and creamy looking. Fruity aroma with big notes of cherry coming through. Smooth creamy mouthfeel with a crisp carbonated edge. Nice sweet fruity flavor with cherries again and slightly spicy, possible herb flavor as well. Overall one of the best Dubbels I've had in awhile. Quite a nice flavor.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text:
UPDATED: AUG 8, 2006 Secondary comments. Had with the Koningshoeven label unknowingly. Scored it 8,5,9,4,17. Very similar. Good, but not up to par with the "quadrupel".

A slight painty aroma, absolutely no head. Is that how its supposed to be? Not terribly interesting though.

Brown (deep red), clear body.  Brwonish, creamy head, which is fastly diminishing and almost not lacing.  Malty and spicy aroma.  Lightly sweet, lightly salty, lightly acidic initial flavour.  Lightly bitter finish.  Very soft mouthfeel.

Dark brown, cloudy apprearance.  Small but nicely laced head.  Aroma is sweet, with fruitiness, malt, and yeast.  Flavor is similar with caramel in addition.  Decent quality dubbel, but I have had much better, and definitely much better for the price.
A very nice Trappist,cloudy with a dark/red colour. Strong taste, but a little flat.
Middly coloured, really strong aroma and less strong taste but so long. So easy to find in bars and markets
Bottled(500ml). -ruby-red coloured with medium head, strong malty aroma, spicy-sweet aroma with slight and hoppy undertone
Hazy red amber body with a nice sweet aroma. Beautiful sweet candy (Brown sugar?) raisin molasses flavours. Nice mouthfeel. Easily my favourite of the La Trappe products.

Very malty and clean, almost bock like but with a slight fruitiness.  Loads of aromatic malt induced aromas, reminicent of cookie dough and loads of special B (raisin aromas and flavour).  This is amongst the most enjoyable Dubbels I've tried.  A little on the sweet side.

Dark brown/amber in color... fairly large head that eventually goes completely away. A bit of sweet licorice and raisin plus a toasty grain feel in the nose. Sweet dark fruit start with a carbonation that burns the tongue a bit. Sour finish. Is ok... reminds me a lot of the Lakefront Holiday Spice.
Cloudy dark ruby red colour. Big, slightly off-white head. Yeasty, fruity taste. Sweet maltiness. Tasted a bit more alcoholic than it is. Okay Dubbel, but not as good as the real trappist dubbels.

Dark mahogany and opaque. No head, and some quick diminishing lace.
Malty aroma, sweet berries. Tastes fruity, quite sweet, dry finish.

Fruity aroma, sweet. Hint of Twizzlers. A bit of coffee or toffee. Also a metallic/lactic aroma. Ruby brown cloudy with light off-tan foamy lacing head. Medium-high carbonation with medium watery body. Hints of bubblegum or melon when cool? Light Twizzler taste. Slighty sweet to start, lactic. Brown sugar, dark fruit. Good level of hops to give bitterness to finish. Alcohol is evident. Somewhat watery. Pleasant nutty bitter after.

Murky ruby-brown colour with a small off-white head. Sweet aroma with overripe fruit notes and some hot alcohol on the edges. Body is thin and has an odd character that I can only describe as "sticky". Flavour is pretty one dimensional, with some brown sugar and apple, and a sudden finish with no yestiness and no aftertaste.

Decent, but not one of my favorites from this brewery.  This is definitely not as good as it used to be, at least in the bottle.  A definite brown sugar, caramelized, candi sweetness.  Easy to drink, but does not have alot of true belgian flavor like I expected.
A pleasant abbey dubbel although not as outstanding as other la trappe offerings. Medium brown, malt forward, fairly soft in the mouth.

Standard deep nut brown color, decent head.  Caramel aroma but very musty, seemingly of a cellar.  Good carbonation, not exactly fluffy as with some dubbels, but vivacious enough to be interesting.  Malty smooth, sweet, but not as fruity or complex as others in the style.
Cloudy brown color. Sweet candy smell with fruit very strong.Sweet flavor of caramel and raisins.Malts are blended nicely and show up near the end.Finish is plain and very mild.

A cloudy amber brown with a huge off white head.  Very sweet aroma filled with cherry, apricot, plum, and caramel with hints of citrus and spice.  Medium thick creamy semi-syrupy - near perfect - palate. Medium amount of carbonation.  Very sweet flavor of raisin, apple, plum, clove, pepper, cinnamon, cherry and caramel.  A good beer, very malty and sweet but not too heavy.

Koningshoeven label- poured a very attractive ruby color with a fantastic head seated atop.  Head was quick to dissipate and left a nice layer on the beer through the end. NOse was very fragratnt with cerries and plums I think.  Flavor was very reflective of the nose.  If served too cold the finish is very metallic.  In fact as the beer warms it really comes together quite nicely.

Tasted in Toronto from the LCBO.  Tasted in Konings hoeven trappist glass.  Tasted at 10C.  Cloudy dark brown colour, very little head.   Aroma of alcohol, caramel, burnt toffee. Taste is fairly well balanced but slightly thin.  Slightly sweet and fizzy.  Starts off with a caramel taste and finishes slightly bitter.

Cloudy red brown pour. Thick cream head that didn't seem to be interested in staying for the duration. Aroma of plum and something else I can't quite put my finger on, though it is sweet. The body is full of caramel elements and perhaps some brown sugar. Rich finish, though not very complex. A worthy dessert beer, though not nearly as good as the "Quad"

Great reddish brown look with a persistent head. Aroma is fruity and vinuous. Flavour is extremely malty with ripe fruit undertones. A tiny bit of alcohol in the finish but you won't mind. Thanks Clark VV

Deeply clouded hazelnut brown color with a tall light tan frothy thick head. Fades slowly to a skim and a thick firm ring around the edge, some drippy lace with some sticking in small ink blot patches. Smell is somewhat darkly fruity with plum and dark cherry; caramel floating in and quite a nice spicy clove on top. Some alcohol pokes through upon bigger whiffs and swirling. Taste is mild, lightly roasty hints up front, with creamy caramel locked in battle with crisp dark fruit notes and citrusy hops with some yeasty spicyness. Nice smooth and clean mouthfeel thats close to medium bodied with a light carbonation. Across the palate this is a bit short lived, and not strong at all, quite mellowing and mild. A nice drinker, but could use a bit of a boost.

Slightly opaque chocolate brown w/ raspberry hue. Beige head which didn't last. Sweet, brandied fruitcake aroma w/ notes of caramel & molasses. Smooth, slightly oily feel. Sweet, chocolaty fruitcake flavour w/ notes of brandied plums & bananas. Some toastiness & spiciness as well. Good but somewhat lacking in complexity.
Brown color, creamy head. Light strawberry/chewingum aroma; banana. Light structure, a bit metallic, light strawberry/chewingum flavor as well; caramel and banana. Ordinary final.
Mahogany color, sweetish earthy, nutty, and I must agree with the bubblegum factor. I couldn't put my finger on it at first. Finishes sweet.
Definitely sweet with some yeast and bubblegum. Caramel and sugar are almost over the top in prescence. A bit overrated.

Sweet and with a malty sweetness and sweet, plus a bit sweet with a sweet finish, some cocoa, yeasty and a bit of the odd "otherness" , but mostly unidimensional in its sweetness. And I found it to be sweet. And it was on sale. I really liked that part.

Bottled: Dark amber coloured. Slightly dusty. Long lasting huge brownish head. Malt, yeast, some caramel, fruits and a bite of spices and alcahol in the nose. Sweet, fruity flavour. A little bland. Alcahol not very good hidden. Has a somewhat bananalike aftertaste.
eh.  smells good.  starts sugary/caramely, then... a little bitter and a bit boring.  not a whole lot going on...

33 cL bottle, goblet, 52 degrees F.  Enormous, off-white, creamy, rocky head is somewhat diminishing and sits or a deep garnet body.
