Nutty, caramel malt (M); perfume hops (L); bubblegum, pear, licorice, solvent aromas.  Flavor is mostly bubblegum, solvent and pear.  Moderately sweet, moderately acidic throughout.  Medium body, watery/oily texture, lively carbonation, moderately astringent.  So it's expensive and undrinkable...great.  The bottom line is: no monks = shitty beer.

cloudy dark brown colour, fine head and a nice lacing, malt and yeast aroma with stong notes of raspberry bubblegum (typical of the recent La Trappe products), tart and sweet, very creamy mouthfeel, the finish is dry and malty with a quite unpleasant bubblegum feeling - this brewery does not deserve to be called trappist anymore

Murky dark brown with average off-white head mostly lasting. Very malty smell with chocolate and toffee reminding me of the kwak. Very sweet chocolate, yeasty perhaps some nuts. Slight bitterness, more pointless than subtle. Watery texture and lightly tart. Pretty thin overall, disappointing:(

Dark brown with red. Thin tan head. Great smell: malt, oatmeal, chocolate, maybe sawdust. The taste is definitely different. Great burnt marshmallow flavor, chocolate, smokey. This has a great bitterness. I really enjoy this beer.

This one starts out with a very uninspiring head, for a Belgian, but a good color.  Nose is sweet, perhaps too sweet, but nice.  Flavor is also sweet, with a little dryness in the finish.  Overall, an average dubbel at best.

Deep chestnut, thin head and little lace. Nose of brown sugar, cookie dough, caramel and other phenols. Medium bodied at best, fairly lush feel, sweet brown sugar and caramel flavors melding not to gracefully with the hops, has an unpleasant acidity to it that doesnt fit. Fairly bitter in finish with phenols lingering. Ok at best.

Bottled. Sampled at Stockholm Beer Festival 2003.
Dark, redbrown. Airy, steady head.
A warm, dry aroma.
Softa and sweet alcoholic.
Flavour from prune and plums.
Reddish brown body, small tan head receding quickly, phenolic (I've learned a word here) nose. Somewhat blah sweet flavor and rather dead palate. Not very good at all.

Bottled. Sampled at Stockholm Beer Festival. 
Dark nutbrown. Rich off-white head. Yeasty, sugary, warming aroma. Sweet, sugary flavour with notes of plum. Warm and filling palate.

(Stockholm Beer Festival 2003)
Dark amber. Bir creamy head. Aroma is dry. Flavor is fruity, some plum, a sweet one.
Roasted aroma, light brown.  Flavor is sweet with fruit and a mild smoked taste.  Medium bodied.  It seems to be holding something back.
UPDATED: SEP 7, 2006 re-rate pending
Fruity apple, mild hop aroma.Chestnut appearance.Like all the other recent offerings this one has the familiar apple flavor with some slight chocolate and caramel at the finish.
Quite good. Ruby red in color. Sharp flavors when compared to the other dubbels. Very sweet.

Poured in his La Trappe glass, shows a beautiful slightly opaque, dark, ruby red color, with a rich, persistent beige head. Delicious aroma featuring caramel and ripe fruit(cherries). Taste is round, sweet, malty, with the finish only a little more dry and bitter. Sweetness dominates, as my bottle was not significantly spicy or acidic. Palate is a bit lighter than you would expect, and alcohol is a bit too evident, but overall it makes for a nice, drinkable and very aromatic introduction to the genre.

Beer pours (in Chimay glass) a medium brown-red liquid that can be seen through when held up to light with a small amount of near-white head that remains small but completely covers the top.  Aroma is a sweet peppermint cherry with vanilla.  Flavor is a multi-berry fruit candy lollipop with a noticable character of something unpleasant - that which tries to mask the alcohol, but can't.  I can't put my finger on it, but it has something to do with the sweetness of it.  The alcohol is not completely masked and when mixed with a sweet taste, is unpleasant.  Sampled at 71 degrees Fahrenheit.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2008 Dark red-brown with a fine creamy, but disappearing head. Berries (raspberry, blackberry, strawberry) and citrus dominate the aroma, a rather fresh dubbel, Id say.  Flavour is quite sweet, caramel and berries, and lacks the dry finish Id expect from an abbey dubbel. On the other hand, there is some hops that keeps it intteresting. Not bad, but not outstanding.

Dark red-brown color, with a creamy, fairly long-lasting head. Rich aromas of chocolate and caramel. Full-flavored with lots of spicy notes, more caramel and dark chocolate flavors, and zesty fruit. Nice malty aftertaste with more of the same flavors, but not overbearingly sweet overall.

my bottle was labelled Koninghoeven Dubbel. Poured with a large, long, lacy head over a dark brown heavily carbonated fairly clear beer. Aroma of roasted coffee and citrus, slightly burnt. Short somewhat disappointing  palate is dominated by carbonation, with a burnt coffee and malty bloom. Certainly puts Heinekins to shame, but not up to the complex quality of some Belgians. Drinkable, but average offering.
Orange and yeast nose.  Almost black hue with light brown head.  Sweet yeast and orange hints with toffee tones.  Decent beer.
Nice brown dubbel color. The taste is sweet fruit and caramel? It finishes with a bit too soon.
On tap at The Belgique in Amsterdam. Sweet malt, some spice. Good flavors of caramel, but not cloying. Good and wet for the thirst.
This beer has a dark brown body - hue with a acid initial flavor and a light body.

Nice light brown head dim. leaving lace. Unclear red-brown colour. Sweet predominates in aroma and taste. Also caramel, chocolate and fruit notes in the taste. Nice body. Enjoyable as are the other "Trappe" beers.

This one certainly is a lot better than the Blond.  Pungent aroma of wood, spices and dried apricots.  Delightful flavor of gently roasted malts, some yeast and more spice.  Moderate hops in the aftertaste.  I'll stick with the Quadruppel.
spicy/violet like aroma, dark brown hue with a magnificent frothy off-white head, malt and coffee, creamy texture, nice warming finish, enjoyable.

Last time i tryed one of these it damn near made me barf.Tall foamy tan head that lasted a long time.Malty,yeast aroma with some spicy hints.Dark amber color with some suspended yeast.Slight hint of olive juice again in the aroma.Malty flavor,spicy with a faint hop presence.Nice after taste of malt and hop's,heavy on the malt,but over all a pretty clean finish .
Good trappist ale, solid malty, not too hoppy.  Great aftedinner beer, very good.

Bottle. Drunk in its own amazing/stunning glass. The beer poured with little head. Dark crimson brown in colour, the caramalised sweet flavours are to die for. Hitting me straight away with its big bouquet of caramel & toffee flavours. It had a very smooth finish which was not too sweet.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2005 Fruity, vinous aroma, some malt sweetness, with very faint herbal hop, mint and alcohol.  Deep, dark red in color, head quickly dissipates.  Fruity sweetness carries over into the flavor, with hints of  apple, red grape, banana and plum.  Smooth, slightly acidic mouthfeel, very low effervescence.  Estery, spicy, sweet finish, some light yeast and faint hop flavors, but only the slightest amount of bitterness.  Sampled out of a Koningshoeven goblet.  Recommended.

Thins head which dissipates quickly into a thin ring of foam which last the length of the drink.  Decent carbonation throughout.  Color of murky black cherry soda.  Aroma is complex with hints of black cherry, molasses and alcohol amongst other things.  Flavor is complex (more than the triple) with rich malt character, alcohol and hints of various spices.  Finish is warming and slightly fizzy/frothy in the mouth.  A great beer with loads of character that should be tried by all.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2005 One of my favorites. I prefer less malt, but still love it.  I can taste a distinct hop character, almost like an oatmeal cookie, though not that yeasty.  Wonderful blackish/blue swirls mix with a deep red color.

What a find, and what a bottle. Ceramic cask like vessel with a cork. A burnt malted and not surprisingly dark ale. A ripper flavour that hangs in the mouth well after the last sip has been slurped. Well done to those Dutch brewers.

Pours a dark, clear brown color with a big tan head that lingers. The aroma is strongly malty sweet with hints of plums and raisons. Full body with low carbonation, the flavor is thick and richly malty, with hints of caramel and chocolate. The finish is lingering sweet with a touch of chocolate. One of the better doubles I have had, this one is nice and malty, much like a doppelbock. Excellent.
(Bottle) Pours a large white head and a deep brown body. Aroma of spice and ginger. Faint flavours when tasting but spice finish is nice. Very good!

A little bit vegetable in the aroma as well as hints of chocolat. Dark brown color, light brown head, very nice lace. Light sweet, light spicy, hint of chocolat, medium body, a little too much carbonation. Short finish with a little hop bitterness.
Brown colour and a creamy head. Chocolate aroma; Caramel flavour with a hoppy finish. the chocolate returns in the aftertaste. Strange but good!

Bottle.  Nothing like enjoying this beer in a glass made by the same brewery.  A deep red-brown color.  The nose has a nice Christmas like spice with ginger, peppermint, and chocolate.  A fairly light body but it leaves a pleasant spice in the back of the throat along with chocolate and burnt caramel.
Deep brown in color, Lots of head. A good Belgian Ale but the quadrupel is much better.
Dark belgian ale with a frothy head.  The flavour and aroma are both light with fruit and spice elements but not a great deal of over prominence of each.  A very easy drink.

Deep brown body, dissapated head.  Smells like abbey double.  Tastes like abbey double.  Perhaps a bit thinner than the others, but theres a lot of complexity.  With each sip, something different: anise, extinguished candle, charcoal, pineapple--no fooling.  I was impressed, not having expected much.

Cloudy reddish-brown in color, huge sticky foamy head, leaves a clingy lacing in my glass, a lot of floaties. Malty fruity yeasty bubblegum aromas, fruity caremel apple banana flavors, medium-full body with a creamy mouthfeel, finishes sugary sweet, a good solid dubbel.

Pours ruby-brown with substantial beige head, left very little lacing.  Malty aroma of dried fruit.  Flavor dominated by malt, but there are some cooked vegetables/cabbage flavors that are not appealing.  Medium mouthfeel.  Definitely not on par with the other Trappist breweries.  Ommegang and Unibroue (North American breweries) even produce better Belgian-style beers.
pours muddy brown with a lacy beige head.  aroma of dark fruit and mild yeast.  some berry-ish fruity flavours with hints of toffee and spice.  nice.

Bluntly put - now a standard double.  Almost to clean, even thought there is plenty of fish food.  Chestnut color, with a heavy thin light tan head.  Mild fruit and malt flavors. Quite smooth.  Nothing real complex.
Wow...Diasppointing is all I can really say. ALOT of Malt prevails in this. Alcohol is all over the place as well. This says Trappist on the label, but why?? Aromatic??!! Refreshing??!! Na...

750 ml.  Very murky, cider-colored, pretty much opaque, light film of bubbles.  Big yeasty aroma, matched by an apple cider vinegar / tomato juice thing going on...from a distance it smells like rotting garbage.  Sort of tastes like sucking on a coffee filter (I love how I write these descriptions when never in my life have I ever sucked on a coffee filter).  Well, Ive actually only had vegemite once, and I had a pretty strong distaste for it.  And this reminds me of vegemite.  Ugh.  It might have been nice to have when it was actually a Trappist product.  I got one word for ya:  Ommegang.

Nice rich brown colour with sparkles of red laced throughout. A beautiful aroma that just pulls you in as you drink. Doesnt have a long lasting head but nice beads around the edge of the glass. Plesant rich sweet flavour that has a bitter aftertaste to it. Not many other complexities about it. Just sweet and bitter. I remember this being better along time ago. Did their brewmaster fall in a vat and drown himself?
Deep brown/crimson in color with a tan fizzy head. Moderate bubble gum aroma and flavor. Fizzy in general. A little on the thin (ie not much complexity) side

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2008 Dec, 2002 Malt. Thats all. Just bloody malt. This is crude stuff - like a homebrew gone badly wrong. Malt. With alcohol. Not complex, delicious malt full of flavours - just malt. Malt. Malt. Malt. And alcohol. Why did the monks chose the Bavaria Brewery? Bavaria have no experience in top fermented brewing. This is dreadful. Just malt. I seriously cannot believe how bad this is. Because its called a Trappist ale and it tastes this bad this deserves the lowest possible marks. Just malt for christsakes! [0.5]
Nov, 2005 Surprisingly light bodied - quite thin in fact. Dry. Chocolate notes. Some dark bitterness. Not much of interest happening. [2.4]
Oct, 2008 Light bodied and dry. Light malt flavours. Lack of character. It’s bottle conditioned, but only just - has a clean filtered feel to it. Licorice, chalk, malt bread, orange and chocolate flavours. Awareness of alcohol. For a strong malty brown beer, the sort the Belgians make a lot of, there are plenty much better than this. [2.7]

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2003 Light brownish with amber shades, small head.  Nicely sweet, a little caramel and chocolate, plus light fruitiness (a little apple, maybe raisin, some banana) and a vague yeasty spiciness.  Primarily a sweet beer and lacking some of the oomph of some dubbels - a little light in body.  Some toffee/caramel notes appear as it warms.

My bottle has the same monestary on the label, but is called Konings Hoeven Dubbel, not La Trappe. Apparently, its not brewed in the same place any longer.
Anyway, I think, as I drink, that this is an excellent dubbel.
The aroma is a complex blend of rich, sweet malt, fuzzy, citrus and dark fruits, caramel, butterscotch and cocoa.
Its a really good looking beer. A deep, clear ruby hue with a small khaki head. The head is creamy and mostly diminishing with weak lacing.
The flavor reminds me a lot of Victorys V10. Ok, maybe its the much younger V10 that reminds me of this beer. Rich, sticky-sweet malt with bursts of caramel, milk chocolate and a dark fruit/fuzzy fruit blend up front. Slightly sweet, slightly tart and just a whisper of the hop addition on the backside.
Full-bodied with an oily mouthfeel. Fizzy carbonation with BIG bubbles. Long, creamy, semi-sweet, fruity finish. Awesome beer. Some seem to have knocked this beer down a few notches since the brewing location was switched to Holland. It must have been ambrosia previously. Get your hands on this beer. Its underrated at 3.67 (currently).
Reddish brown with tan head and small bead. estery alcohol nose with a sweet malt flavor throughout
UPDATED: MAY 30, 2009 Everything a dubbel should be. Dark ruby-red appearance. Nice lacing. Very nice malty nose. Full complex flavors, malty, raisins and a bit fruity. Smooth, long-lasting finish.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2005 Finally tried this beer since Bavaria NV took over the monasterys brewing operations - resulting in a steep downgrade.  First, its not bottle conditioned, which is unforgiveable for an abbey ale.  Muddy reddish-brown; estery, phenolic nose (bubblegum, apple, plum, raspberry).  Very sweet palate - bubblegum again, raspberry & apple, caramel, brown sugar.  Lacks texture, hop and yeast.

750 ml bottle.  Hazy brown, good head and lacing.  Lost of "bready" malt here among the too strong alcohol presence.  some tang and citrus - orange/almost grapefruit.  quite carbonated, but smooth on the palate.  I guess I would call this "average" for a Belgian - Ive had both better and worse.
Fine color and good taste. Lot of taste.

Re rate
One year later I decided to give another try. All I said about having fin drinking this beer is true but maybe it needs some refinement to be in top league. A bit light on aroma, sweet. Warming with characteristically Belgian ale flavours.

Dark reddish-brown, not much head. Spicy aroma. Flavor is a balance of spice, malt, fruit and hops, with an alcohol kick to the relatively clean finish for a Belgian. Very good, but still ranks behind the Corsendonk Brown.
Robust, but fruity.  Interesting flavors - caramel sweetness and mild roasted malt, with a little licorice added to a bitter finish.  Not bad.
UPDATED: DEC 12, 2005 Earthy raisin sweetness constantly oscillating between burnt caramel and milk chocolate...A rather sugary and yeasty soft introduction to Abbey Dubbels...

Nebulous brown red color. Frothy head dwindles quickly with small tats of lace clinging to the glass with great resolve. Sweet malt and toffee smell. Visid sweetness with fruity undertones. Complexity sprouts as it warms. Alcohol and hops on the finish.
A gorgeous looking ale! Dark red and almost tea-like aroma, with hints of butter cookies. A plum-y sweetness to the body and an almost alcohol dryness in the finish.  This was an incredible beer!
Sweet malty taste. Aroma is sweet, slightly yeasty with caramel flavor.
Deep ruby body with big beige head.  Aroma is sweet, slightly yeasty,caramel, and undoubtedly Belgian.  Sweet malty flavor, rich.  Develops chocolate and roasty characteristics as it warms.

La Trappe is one of the best breweries on earth, but this is definately NOT one of their better offerings. Attractive brown ale appearance yet lacking in the candied sugar taste/molasses that is usually evident in abbey dubbels.  A weak example IMHO
Amber coloured with a big dissappearing head. Strong malty aroma. Strong molasses taste.

Trying a few dubbels to see if my brown ale fetish extends into the Low Countries.  Not so far as La Trappe, apparently.  This simply wasnt fun to drink - dark, murky, confused stuff with too much white wine dryness on close.
Very solid sweet malty taste.  Easy drinking and with a wonderful flavour, comes very close to living up to its belgian cousins.
Not bad for a trappist, very good for 6.5%.
The earthy, tobacco tones in the nose come through as gritty and malty in the taste with hints of chocolate. Dark red color says “drink me.” Heavy body and round mouth feel. Pretty damn good beer.
Malty and dusty, earthy tabboco aroma. Wonderful dark brown - red-dish body with a rocky head. Taste malt, raisons. Also smokey. Fullmouth.

Rerate: Actually one of the better doubles i reconsider. Nice perfume of roasted malts. Still lacks some remaining palate, but for a commercial brew it is definitely very good! 
Original rate: Decent double, but it lacks some remaining palate.
Sweet, fruity taste. Quite good  for a supermarketbeer. Well balanced taste and a nice dark appearance. Aroma is complex.

Very good belgian ale.  Darker and nuttier than the other La Trappe offerings I have the pleasure of drinking.  Still very nice aroma and texture.  Good appperance and a nice finish. An above average ale.
Reminds me of chewinggum
Sweet and spicy. An average dubbel.
Very ordinary dubbel Belgian Strong Ale. This wannabe-trappist-brewery really tries to live up to the name. They almost succeeded.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2005 Had this beer on tap while traveling through Amsterdam.  Its less champagne-like on tap than out of the bottle. Fruity, like many trappist style beers, but not sweet. Excellent!

Cloudy auburn color.  Sweet malt and hints of raisins with touch of chocolate.  Spritzy mouthfeel, alcohol, sweet malt and just a touch of dark fruits.  Fairly dry, but still one of the better Ta Trappe beers, I still think the blonde is the best (and underrated here.)
A nice dark amber color with a nice off-white foam and little lace.  Yeasty aroma with a sweet fruity flavor.
A beutiful dark brown beer with a good head. It has the aroma of yeast and fruit - and is very fruity in the taste. It is missing something to round off the taste of fruit.

Cloudy dark ruby-brown in color.  Amazingly complex aroma of raisins, green apples, dark candied sugar, caramal, spice and maybe just a hint of cherry.  I was a bit let down upon tasting because its nose was so impressive.  The first thing I noticed was its sweetness (just a pinch too much) but I did appreciate this beers tartness.  Not bad overall just not as tasty as it looks or smells.
Appealing Maroon color; Head dissapated quickly; Nose of raisins. Thin palate is the first thing I notice. I really wanted to love this beer, but its lack of depth hindered me.

I drank this beer out of very high recommendations from my friend, who has it at the top of his list.  It is an excellent beligian with a wonderful blend of spices and fruit, but it wasnt as strong as I was hoping.
definitely has that Belgian funk

muzzled and muscular in its golden  helmet  and wire manacles.  decants with fiery hues like a redwood burl, some deep umber and black cherries. it remains clear even with  minimal swirling of  interstellar debris.  i confess im nursing this one, tho the term is not apt, this beverage requires no soothing, succor  or sympathy, its as vibrant as a race horse. but its character has developed over an hour: formerly understated and foamy at cellar temp, now its malty, doppelbock- like alcohol aroma is pronounced, while the head is just a wispy beige laurel. big cidery and polished furniture aroma, a farmers market of fruit notes, finally like a lightly hopped, medium bodied barley wine.  at twenty five cents a swallow, its to savor while we dreamily anticipate the quadrupel.

Dark red/brown slightly hazy colour with a creamy large rocky island reasonably lasting tan head. Ripe fruits (pears/bananas), light caramel malt, cough medicine and faint cured meat yeast aromas. Big yeasty sweet and bitter smooth start but mellows too quickly to light nearly bland middle and soft sweet finish. I cant beat Guslers eloquence on this one not great, but good

This dubbel poured a nice dark red color and formed a nice light tan head that left some nice lace.  Some citrus, spice and hops aroma to it.  Finish seems to have some sweet elements to it.  Seemed to have a light to medium body to it.  Some spice elements and malt.  Couldnt detect any alcohol.
its okay but it is not the trappist beer in my book.
Definently better than la trappe tripel

Nice appearance. Well balanced. Slightly sweet and smooth ending.
But its not full-bodied enough for a trappist.
Well balanced.  Tastes of caramel.  Sweet at first but has a smooth finish.  Wonderful example of the style.
Beautiful color and head.  Balanced with both malt and hops.  Not a bad Belgian Ale.
An extremely well balanced beer. Beautifully malty and an amazingly pleasant aftertaste. Tastes of caramel and spices. A great Belgian Dubbel. BRAVO!

deep red-brown colour, stiff beige head, lot of lace.
nose of malt and caramel.
Initially comes off as being too sweet and syrupy but  has a mild hop bite which balances all the great malt.
very smooth and a great subbel.
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2004 Excellent colour, lace, head, aroma and flavour overall. It was the first Belgian dubbel Ive ever had, and I was quite impressed.
Nice dubbel. Beautiful dark red/brown colour. Fruity aroma and flavour. Somewhat like Westmalle Dubbel, but I certainly prefer the latter as La Trappe Dubbel (imho) is a bit too sweet.

This one certainly has a lot more going than the Blond/Enkel. Moderate aroma of oak, spices, dried fruits and English pipe tobacco (before smoking!) Delightful flavour of gently roasted malts, some yeast and spices. Moreish indeed, I hate myself for buying only one bottle! Moderate hops in the aftertaste. Im looking forward to the Triple!
Not complex enough for my liking.

This was my first foray into the world of Belgian and Trappist ales. It was a wonderful experience. Medium-dark reddish brown in color, the Dubbel has a nice fruity complexity in smell and taste that I had been previously unfamiliar with. It was also missing the spiciness of the alcohol and unusual yeast flavor present in many belgian ales. The only reason it took me so long to rate it was because the bar had it listed as simply La Trappe Trappist Ale. Just recently found out from the bars website that it was the dubbel.
Malt, fruit, caramel greet the nose. Burgundy colour, very small head. Port like taste, also sweet, toffee. Full bodied, complex. A fine beer!
Light brown color. Fruity aroma - comparable to the blond. A hint of yeast in the taste, but easy drinkable.

I dont know what to say...I dont think I am supposed to rate this beer this high, but after drinking it, I could not help but make it my number one beer.  It had a pleasant spice aroma with lace that clung to the glass as I drank each sip.  The sweet fruits hung around my toungue and made me crave another sip.  I found nothing wrong with this beer, I want another!
Floral, citric aroma.  Well balanced hoppy taste, somewhat tart, a little bitter.  Nice, weaker than their quad but much more drinkable.

Sweet porto aroma with raisins and apple. The taste is very sweet and fruity and a little bit tart. A slight porto burn is present. Bitter finish. Nice to drink, but real trappist ales are for more complex.
HUGE head. head almost looks like a whipped topping for the ale! lots of floating particles. has a plum color. fruity aroma and taste.

12 oz. bottle:  A classic dubbel.  Firm in body and very fruity in taste and aroma.  Aroma also hints at candy apples, grapes, plums, and sherry.  Probably the most complex dubbel tried to date.  Warm alcohol kick to boot.  Nicely done!
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Nice maltiness and a slight amount of spiciness.  A lot easier to drink a few of these than the quad.

Very rocky, foamy head that lasts and lasts.  The aroma is pretty simple and sweet, but cleaner than some Belgians Ive tried.  Color is a reddish brown/copper color, depending on the light it may look like coca-cola in the glass.  The taste is a little more hoppy and sour than some others of this style, more citrus and yeast as well.  If one drinks this with food, it becomes musty and rootbeer-like, and I like those flavors here.  Alcohol and acidic flavors normally dominate the finish, which to me is surprising considering the ABV of 6.5.  I do like how easy it is to drink, though, and unlike some others before me I am a fan of the grapefruity hops...a big fan.  This one is good---not great---but good, and I will try it again to be sure.  I have a bottle of the quadrupel in the fridge as well, so we shall see.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2006 750ml bottle.
Head is mostly lasting. Body is dark amber. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted nuts, caramel, molasses), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of overripe banana, clove. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation. The pre-rotting fruit smell is a bit off-putting, and its quite sweet, but overall not too bad.
Good, but not my favorite La Trappe beer.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2003 Complex aromas of blackcurrant, malt, spice yeast and that cheese mold you get on Brie. Deep red brown colour with good head. Flavour dissapoints slightly but is bready and spicy with a powdery dryness in the finish.
Not as good as the trippel.

I had a miserable brewpub Dubbel tonight as well and was hoping this beer would show me what the style is supposed to taste like.  Sadly, its pretty weak out of the bottle, not much taste at all, just a hint of spice, and poor carbonation.  What flavour there was was decent, but so small.

Pours a nice deep brown, Imagine That, beige head that dissipates quickly, the lace is adequate. Nose is as Trappist said grape like, some chocolate tones, along with a bit of malt. Start sweet, the middle thin, and a bit sour, the finish is acidic, mild carbonation, hops present along with the alcohol, dry, winish. More thin than I would normally like, not great, but good none the less.
Fruity uncomplicated flavor, no head to speak of. Packs a noticeable alcoholic kick.
My first Belgian ale. Dark red with liitle to no head. Fruity, wine-like aroma and taste. Different, but very enjoyable.
Pretty stuff. My first dubbel. Takes some getting used to. Winey/champagney aroma, taste, mouthfeel. OK...second try...very nice.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Somewhat of a disappointment, as I had fond memories of this (and all of the La Trappes -- my first Trappist ales).  Nice dark red color; big head dies quickly.  Smells of bread, yeast and wine, but not very potent.  Flavor is also a little on the weak side, though more complex:  bock-like in character, with some maple-dark bread characteristics, wine again and some hoppiness.  Finish is very smooth, clean and sweet.  Certainly worth trying, but not on the level of, say, Orval or Westmalle.
Sickenly sweet
Dark reddish brown, almost grape colored. Fruity aroma of grapes present. Didnt seem overly complex. No real spicy flavors jumped out at me, just once again grape. Still a good beer.
pretty decent ale - made for malt lovers - not real complicated, but tasty
A good dubbel...not in the league of the Chimays but still enjoyable. Fruity aroma, dark brown body, moderate head with a smooth finish.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2004 i expected sweet and i got sweet. shitloads of caramel and chocolate coated bananas. thankfully the caramel taste isn't accompanied by the expected syruppy mouthfeel, it's quite drinkable. As it warms it gets nicely brandyish and plummy, and the malt tastes a bit spicier. It's far too sweet and simple but has its good points I guess.
If you see the Trappist Brothers from the Abbey of Koningshoeven, send them my regards.  This Dubbel rocks!

Rich chocolate and malt aroma accompany this deep, dark red beer with a persistent head. Creamy mouthfeel with heavy malting, including plum, brown sugar, and oak with an underlying yeastiness.  Mellow finish with very little alcohol presence make this quite smooth and enjoyable. 2000/2001 Vintage.
In the bottle this smells alot like a chocolate chip cookie. Rich and malty, with some spice and fruit notes. Very smooth, with light alcohol taste and robust mouthfeel. Quite tasty.
Deep rich red color. Medium head. An almost vinious (sp?) aroma. A lightly fruity flavor of plum perhaps. Pretty good.
Refreshing, beautiful dubbel. the 11.2 is appropriate for one person. The 750 should be for two or more though. Very sweet and spicy. A good buy
Deep, rich, brown color with a heavy nut flavor.  Clean, smooth after taste.  Excellent after dinner desert beer.

The sweet, almost sugary-like feeling of the dubbel was much respected.  I noticed the elevated sense of self-esteem after three of these, along with the immense flavor that accompanied it.  I wish that I could only describe it better.  I am a growing fan of Belgians!
Complex beer, but not very well balanced.
Thick creamy head that lasted till the end of each glass.  Very complex
A little sour. SOmewhat flat tasting. Overall, pretty good but not impressive.
This one had an extremely sweet smell, but the taste was more sour than anything.  Good thing I like sour.  Very good beer.
slighlty bitter, but heavily carbonated.
Great sour flavor and aroma.  Impressive head.  Nice smooth finish with an enjoyable aftertaste.
A refreshing beer, but happily not too sweet
